PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the business of the House be suspended this day from 11 a.m. to 11.02 a.m. in order to allow Members and others within this place to commemorate Remembrance Day in the traditional manner by observing two minutes of silence.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians have observed the significance of the eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month for generations. It is part of our heritage and a moment of great significance. It is a tradition which should be preserved and honoured. I am delighted that the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) is seconding this motion, thus demonstrating the bipartisan support that this motion enjoys. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

—I second the motion. In doing so, I note that it is right and fitting that this motion be adopted by this House. I acknowledge the presence in the chamber this morning of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer); the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford); the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), a former a Minister for Defence; and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Price).

PARA.TAB: It is pleasing that this motion will be adopted unanimously, because it commemorates in our country an event which brought blessed respite to the infant nation so long ago. In virtually every town and city of Australia there is a memorial to commemorate the subject of this motion. In every little hamlet right across the country there is some memorial. Under this motion, which I believe is the first in my time as a member of this House, Remembrance Day will be observed this day in this place so that we shall never forget the sacrifice made by those who served Australia in times of war.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PRICE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present supplementary explanatory memoranda to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1992 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992.

PROCTEXT.PARA: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —These two Bills provide funding for government and non-government schools. The first Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, is to provide some additional funding for this year. The second Bill, the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill, is the principal appropriation Bill for school funding for both government and non-government schools. This second Bill appropriates a very large sum of money, some $2.87 billion, which will be used for recurrent and capital purposes, the Government's so-called national equity programs, school language programs and other joint programs.

PARA.TAB: Taxpayers are entitled to ask what they are getting for the money. It is clear that the expenditure foreshadowed through this legislation is accompanied by a great deal of activity and, one must say, an increasing number of committees and regulatory authorities. But there is a bottom line to these debates, that is, what are young Australians actually learning? Are they learning what they need to know to function effectively in modern society? Are they being adequately prepared for an internationally competitive world? This is obviously the key criterion. It is what the Australian people want to know about the expenditure of this money. Is it being well spent? The measure that this criterion provides enables us to assess the Government's success or failure in its school policies over its almost 10 years in office. Measured against this criterion, the Government has failed—and failed miserably.

Because this appropriation is essential for the running of schools in this country, the Opposition will not oppose it. But I will be moving a second reading amendment in respect of the second Bill which condemns the Government for its failure to pursue policies which will lift standards of education in Australia to international levels and for the unnecessary and unjustified restrictions which the Government is imposing on the right of parents to choose the appropriate school for their child.

It is an extraordinary fact that, after almost 10 years of this Government, up to one in five Australians do not have functional literacy or numeracy. Many of these, very disturbingly, are young Australians fresh from school. Anecdotal evidence of this is accumulating into a massive pile. The Government throughout its term of office, for reasons which I shall explore in the course of my remarks, has failed to show any great interest in attempting to measure and monitor the standards of learning which are actually being achieved. But the evidence is nevertheless becoming overwhelming. I would like to take a few minutes to inform honourable members of some of this evidence so that they can gain a feel for the consequences of the Government's failure to keep its eyes fixed firmly on the ball in education.

A survey of the Regency College of TAFE in South Australia found that 40 per cent of apprentices and 51 per cent of pre-vocational students had reading comprehension ages of between only eight and 12 years. Thirty-four per cent were unable to pass trade relevant maths set at year 10 level. The Government, to its credit, appointed a committee headed by Brian Finn, the Managing Director of IBM, to investigate post-compulsory schooling and training. The Finn Committee came up with a very disturbing conclusion. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is firm evidence that a significant number of school leavers do not have even very basic literacy skills adequate to their training or work contexts.

Last year, the University of Melbourne decided to test entrants' skills in mathematics. It found that of those students whom the university admitted less than half, when they came to their first year studies, had the required training for tertiary study. Only 44 per cent of first year students passed the test that the university had set down. Honourable members from Victoria will not be surprised to hear that the results showed that the maths ability of students with the Victorian certificate of education was 14 per cent lower than that of students who had studied under the old higher school certificate. The test covered skills from basic problem solving to sophisticated calculations.

PARA.TAB: A recent study of adult literacy found that 68 per cent of those who attempted to articulate the issues behind a newspaper editorial were unable to do so. Sixty-eight per cent, according to this study, found it difficult to read and understand a newspaper editorial. Thirty-one per cent of those who attempted to calculate the change from a $5 note after ordering two specified items from a menu were unable to do so. Twenty-two per cent could not enter the date correctly on a bank deposit slip, and 46 per cent were unable to work out from an aspirin packet the correct dosage for a child.

This is a very serious situation. It is not one which has emerged suddenly in the national consciousness. It is a problem which has been there for a number of years. The message to the Government has been clear. Action, and urgent action, is needed to lift the standards of learning in this country, and to give people the knowledge and the skills they need to function effectively in Australian society. The Government has failed to take such action.

It is clear that these problems relate not only to basic and functional literacy and numeracy but that they extend also to core areas of knowledge, such as science. The Australian Council for Educational Research published last year the results of a study which compared the levels of science achievement of year 10 Australian students with the levels of achievement that were being achieved in 1970 and with international levels. This study found two things: it found that the levels of achievement had not declined since 1970, compared within this country, but it found also that the relative standards of achievement of Australian students had dropped quite markedly when compared with the levels of achievement of their peers in other industrial countries.

Australia is falling behind, falling behind in a world which does not owe us a living, in a world in which we have to compete. Yet we are equipping our young people less and less well, according to the results of this study, in key areas of knowledge which must underpin an internationally competitive economy.

Young Australians' cultural literacy is as big a problem as their command of their language. A study by the Australian newspaper, which surveyed some 4,000 year 9 students, found that only 33 per cent could locate East Germany—which, of course, then existed but now no longer exists—on a map. Only 18 per cent of them could name Mr Hawke as Malcolm Fraser's successor to the prime ministership. A study by the Institute of Public Affairs of year 10 students in both government and non-government schools found that only 22 per cent of 232 students surveyed could name the three levels of government in Australia, and only 28 per cent could identify the event commemorated by Anzac Day. Only one-quarter could name the two Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. Only 42 per cent could identify the service provided by Bankcard. Eighty per cent were unable to name the year of Federation.

So we have a generation of young people in this country who are not learning sufficient information about the nature of the country and the society in which they live to function in that society. They are unable to comprehend the discussion of public issues in the media and one in five of them do not have the basic functional skills needed for the workplace. Of course, as we know, unemployment is very much related to the quality of the skills and training that young people have.

So we have a record, despite this immense expenditure and despite these scores of committees, of dangerous and damaging educational failure. How has this occurred? The Government will tell you that its record is enormously positive, and it will refer to the growing numbers of young Australians going through the schooling systems. It will tell you that participation rates have risen. It will tell you that it has worked closely with the teachers unions to encourage the development of national teaching, curriculum and professional requirements.

What are we to make of these claims? Take participation. Participation has been rising for decades. It rose from a 22 per cent retention rate in 1967 to 40 per cent in 1983. Let us make no mistake about that. The claims in this House by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about the record of the previous coalition Government are totally false and are readily exposed by consulting the information. Participation has been rising for decades, it continues to rise, and it will rise whether this Government wants it to rise or not. Tragically, in recent years it has risen very rapidly because of the gross economic mismanagement which has deprived so many of our young people of the opportunity to gain experience in the workplace. To that extent, what has happened in recent years is actually a measure of dramatic policy failure on the part of the Government rather than any educational success.

Let us not be fooled by this. Every Australian knows that the real issue is not the number of people who are being processed through the system. The real issue is what they are learning, and whether they are gaining the knowledge and skills that they need to survive and to get jobs in an internationally competitive world. The answer is overwhelming; even the answer from the Government's own committees is that they are not doing so.

The reason is that the Government has lost sight of the main game in education. It has pursued an agenda which has been largely irrelevant to the educational needs of this country. Its education agendas have been dominated by its dependence on its allies in the Australian Teachers Union and other unions. It has been much more concerned to pursue national industrial awards than it has been to pursue national standards. Those unions—and, unfortunately, many in the bureaucracy—have positively resisted the effort to give the public the information that it is entitled to have about the quality of learning that young people are achieving. The Government has pursued national uniformity and curriculum, even if this means national mediocrity. The Australian Mathematical Sciences Council has made clear that, if it is adopted, the national profile for mathematics that has been developed may well lead to a significant decline in mathematical standards in this country.

The Government has pursued a concept of equity which means that it is better to have uniform deprivation and uniform low standards than to encourage the best from every pupil. Until very recently, under immense pressure from the Opposition, it was ideologically unacceptable even to suggest that something should be done to bring the best out of the gifted and talented students in this country. We all know that, despite the Government's claims to be helping the disadvantaged, the most disadvantaged group in the country—students in rural Australia—has been significantly neglected by this Government and its policies.

The Government has simply failed to address the crucial questions in education. What is it that produces excellence in schooling? Under pressure from the Opposition, the Government's rhetoric has begun to change. It has begun to say rhetorically, `Yes, we do care about quality, we do care about excellence, and we are doing something about it'. The record speaks for itself about the effectiveness of what has been done.

Let us look at what the Government has done. I will mention a couple of initiatives that have been taken in recent years. The Government set up the national project on the quality of teaching and learning. It has a very fine sounding title; but when you draw aside the veil on this national project, what do you find? As we would expect under this Government, we find the employers lined up on one side of the table and the unions lined up on the other side. When we ask what contribution this national project has made to the quality of teaching and learning, what do we find? Virtually nothing of any significance has come out of it.

But one thing has come out of it. We now have a proposal for a national teaching council to build up a professional structure for teachers in this country. That sounds good. Without a high status and highly respected teaching profession, a very professional teaching order, there is no possibility that we will have education of international standards. But is this national teaching council the mechanism to achieve that? Of course not. If we look at the documents that have been issued to support it, we find that this is an attempt by the Australian Teachers Union and its mates in the Government to hijack the move towards professionalism. This is not even to be a council which fully represents teachers; teachers are to have a bare majority on the council. For a long time there was a view that perhaps teachers would not even have a majority on it, but we in the Opposition criticised that and the Government has tried to amend its proposal in some respects.

This is an effort to gain national registration of teachers, to lock teachers into uniform and rigid national awards to make sure that any move towards teacher professionalism which might give teachers a degree of independence from the industrial relations system is nipped in the bud and that the whole process is captured and controlled by the Australian Teachers Union and its mates in the Government. This is unacceptable, and the people of this country know that this is not the route by which to achieve excellence in schooling.

Last year we had the great initiative of the good schools project. There was $10m to be allocated over several years to find out—to find out, mind you—what a good school was. As if we did not know that a good school is a school with effective educational leadership, with clear educational goals, with values of achievement and with harmonious staff relations, which is prepared to monitor and evaluate its own performance. That is what a good school is and everybody knows that. We did not need $10m to find that out. Now, after a year or so, this project has been completely changed because the Government knows that that initial brief was given solely for propaganda purposes and had no substance to it.

The Government's approach to schooling, increasingly centralised controls and bureaucratic regulation is not the road to achieving improved equality of education. We need self-managing schools in this country where principals have the ability to offer leadership, where staff conditions and employment can be handled without endless bureaucracy, where there is freedom to establish proper discipline policies, where confrontational industrial relations are left at the front gate and where there is a determination to achieve and a willingness to demonstrate and evaluate high excellence. A basic principle is that parents should have the right to choose the school to which they send their child and that schools should be accountable to parents and not to the bureaucracy.

The Government's record in establishing these conditions for excellent schooling is one of unmitigated failure. It has positively set out to diminish the exercise of parental choice. It has done nothing to encourage the development of effective school based management, or outstanding teaching, or satisfactory monitoring of standards. The Government's failure has done considerable damage to state school systems. It has encouraged parents to vote with their feet to leave the state school systems, to go to non-government schools where they can have confidence that a disciplined environment will prevail and that classrooms will not be disrupted by industrial action and where they know their values will be reflected.

It is a condemnation of the Government that in 1991 there were fewer pupils in government schools than there were in 1976, while over the same period the number of pupils in non-government schools had risen by over 30 per cent. There was a message in this, but it was a message the Government failed to heed. The response of the Government's union mates was to establish a policy designed to stem the tide—to make it difficult for parents to transfer their students from government to non-government schools; to make it expensive to exercise choice—

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish.

—The honourable member knows that that is true. The policy was also designed to prohibit parents from establishing a new school or expanding an existing one unless it posed no threat to numbers at existing government schools. This is the notorious and infamous new schools policy. This legislation embodies these policies and, while making some adjustments to them, retains them in place.

PARA.TAB: The Government set out to address the symptoms, but not the substance of the problems. As a consequence, in attempting to make non-government schooling more expensive—to prevent low income parents from exercising choice and to discriminate against them in the system—the Government allowed a decline of some 30 per cent in the real value of capital grants to non-government schools. It also froze per capita grants to a number of categories of non-government schools, with a highly divisive policy. Per capita grants were not increased. In the higher fee schools, parents—many of whom are not high income earners—are prepared to sacrifice their holidays or to have both parents working in order to finance the education that they want. But members of the Government would not recognise that. They divide society into the rich and the poor and do not pursue policies which help low income people, discriminating against those who make an effort and who place a high value on education. Let us have none of this divisive rhetoric that we constantly get from the other side of the House on education. Where per capita grants were increased, they were not increased at a rate that compensated for the disastrous impact of the recession on low income families. As a consequence, many low income families have found that they are increasingly unable to exercise educational choice.

The cost of non-government schooling has been increased by a whole range of government policies—by the training guarantee levy, by the superannuation guarantee and by the impact of the fringe benefits tax. The fringe benefits tax on car parking is going to cost some non-government schools half a million dollars a year. Is that what the Government intends? Does it intend to impose this added cost—the cost of new levels of award salaries and new curriculum—on the right of parents to choose these schools? The increasing difficulty that parents have in exercising educational choice flows directly from the policies of this Government.

There are some increases in per capita grants in this legislation, but they are nowhere near adequate to give real choice to many low income families. The divisive policy of freezing grants to some, while increasing them to others, is maintained. There are some increases in capital grants but they are only half as much as we in the coalition judge to be minimal to allow non-government schools to meet the immense pressures of educational change. The increases in per capita grants are totally unsatisfactory. Throughout the rest of this decade, parents choosing a school in the non-government sector will receive from the coalition some $1 billion more than they will receive under the policies projected in this legislation.

The new schools policy in this legislation—the policy designed to lock parents into the government system—is modified in only one respect. The Hudson report on five Greek Orthodox schools in Melbourne showed that this policy was destroying the financial viability of these schools. Many parents wanted to send their children to those schools but were prohibited from doing so by the maximum numbers imposed, under this policy, on those schools. Those numbers have been lifted for the existing schools. However, this grossly inequitable policy is to be maintained for new schools and, indeed, has been tightened up.

As honourable members may know, this policy freezes funding for new schools at what is described as needs level 6, even though the resource needs of many of these schools are much greater. These schools are being discriminated against, not because they are wealthy, but because they are new and because they recognise the fact that parents are not satisfied with what is happening in education at the present time. They are discriminated against, and yet the Government says it supports needs funding. This is a lie, as it applies to pupils attending new schools under this policy. This policy has no reference to the needs of schools. Many thousands of low income parents are making an immense sacrifice to set up the school that they want. This Government is discriminating against them, even though it knows that the needs of those schools would justify and entitle them to needs funding at a much higher needs level.

This new schools policy should be completely abandoned. The coalition will abandon it and we will give parents the right to choose their child's school. We will do that not just in making a choice between the Government and non-government sector, but we will do a great deal to expand the right of parents to choose their school within the Government sector as well because, in the end, the quality of education in this country is going to depend on the quality of the Government sector schools, where most students will continue to go.

It is not surprising that there is so much discontent with the Government's performance as it relates to the Government school system. One of the important developments in schooling in recent times has been the growing interest of the business community which has recognised with deep and growing concern the failure to which I have referred. The Industry-Education Forum, recently established, has issued a declaration of goals for Australian schools. In launching these goals, Brian Loton, the former managing director of BHP, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If we truly believe that Australia's future depends on becoming competitive, then one of the first things that must be set right is the education system. We cannot have a world class workforce without world class schools.

The Industry-Education Forum stated a number of goals, including the measurement and reporting of standards against national and international standards—something the Government has failed to do. The Industry-Education Forum, in a significant statement, concluded:

Australia's public school systems, as traditionally structured and managed, are unlikely to achieve the necessary improvements to be at the forefront of world standards. Centralised control, bureaucratic procedures and industrial relations constraints have typified traditionally organised public education systems and have restricted their possibilities for improvement. . .

The Industry-Education Forum puts forward a whole agenda for devolution of authority to schools combined with a proper monitoring of standards. The coalition strongly endorses these views. It is wrong, as the Government has done, to neglect the tremendous potential of the Government school systems. If schools are given the autonomy and accountability for their own performance, they can, and they will, achieve at international levels.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has made an enormous commitment to education in Fightback. It is one of the top priority areas within our whole program. We will be making a major effort not merely to ensure that education in this country is resourced at the levels it needs to be, but that the structural reforms which are necessary to create top quality, self-managing schools to give parents the right to choose their schools, because they are the best monitors of the quality of their children's education, and to provide a system whereby the Australian community will at last be given the information to which it is entitled about the quality of learning that is taking place in the nation's schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —How seriously is this House and the people in the gallery expected to take the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp)? He talked about the participation rates. His mathematical literacy is pretty limited. I will read out the table on participation rates under the last coalition. In 1975—this is for the benefit of the people in the gallery—the participation rate was 34 per cent. In 1982 it had grown dramatically to 36 per cent. This is the effort—
—What was it in 1983?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The honourable member for Goldstein has spoken. He should not interject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable member for Goldstein to hang on for a moment. It went up 2 per cent. That was the effort when the Opposition was in government. Those opposite do not take education or schools seriously. They actually believe that children are to be accounted for when they turn 15 or 16. They have no attitude to young children nor to the school sector in Australia, and they never have had. The provision of these two Bills, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill, provide ongoing stability and security to all Australian schools. This security and stability of funding is something that both Government and non-government schools have come to expect and enjoy under the Federal Labor Government.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Goldstein seems to be very sensitive about the teacher unions in this country, and no wonder. Let us listen to what Dianne Foggo, the President of the Australian Teachers Union, says about the Opposition's education policies—I know the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) does not like this either. On the education policy of the Opposition, she states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the most unbelievable attacks on education and training in this country's history.
She goes on about the proposals of the Opposition and she describes them as follows, and I quote again for the honourable member for Wakefield:
The proposals are really about the destruction of the school systems as we know them.

The Opposition's attitude to the new schools policy is ample evidence of that. For example, take an area like mine in Port Adelaide where there are established Catholic, established independent and established state schools. Its policies supported the program funding—taxpayers' money, the money of the people in the gallery—to white ant those existing schools and to just wipe them: do not allow them any resources; do not upgrade them; wipe them out of the way; spend taxpayers' money irresponsibly; do not help the status quo; and just wipe the problem under the carpet.

PARA.TAB: It is a little bit like the attitude of the honourable member for Goldstein to quality learning. When he talks about quality learning, he is talking about, in a taxonomy of education objectives, the lowest intellectual skill possible, knowledge. He does not talk about comprehension, insight, perception, analysis, synthesis, problem solving, translation, or prediction. He does not have an attitude about learning. He comes from a blinkered view and he thinks that learning is something that is just knowledge. Has he not heard of a library? People can get skills and information out of a library that are far more important in having positive relationships with their peers and with adults, and being able to know how to learn, not what to learn. Learning changes dramatically over a period of time.

The honourable member made comments about the new broad-banding arrangements which were recently endorsed by the Australian Education Council and which will be introduced in 1994. I know that some schools in my electorate are pretty wary of change, but they all acknowledge that the disadvantaged schools program in particular needs an overhaul. This new broad-banding arrangement will provide the financial assistance under four elements, focusing on the issues of access, equity, incentives and national priorities. These new elements will involve a broad-banding of some existing targeted programs from 1994 subject to adequate agreements being struck with school authorities in the matters of accountability, information and evaluation network.

It is interesting that in the recent presidential election, education was very high on the agenda, along with health. Of course, they are two issues that seem to have passed this Opposition by, because I suppose Governor Clinton's victory in the recent presidential election was a victory that really emphasised the points of view that are going on in this Government, namely, that it is a victory for the common good over those selfish individual interests espoused by the honourable member for Goldstein; a victory for the common good; a victory for the community over the individual; a victory in terms of taking every one into account in the nation; and a victory for cooperation over divisiveness.

The very matters that the honourable member for Goldstein raises, if carried out—if this country were so unfortunate as to have a coalition in government for the next three years—would bring up the divisive State aid debate, would it not? That is what he really wants. This Federal Government, through its policies, has a dual system, respected throughout the world, and it has entrenched that because it is based on needs and on children. It is not based on some ideology that splits and divides and conquers.

We see the evidence of the policies of those opposite in Victoria—confrontation and divisiveness. They are their policies, and they love those practices. They love people out on the street, dividing and arguing amongst themselves, when the issues are in fact children and quality of learning. They just give token knowledge to all that information.

In Fightback the Opposition did not mention the 5 per cent cut to the States' general recurrent grants of $750m. Why did it not mention that? It went very quiet on that. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the honourable member for Goldstein would engineer a massive shift of public resources from government schools to the privileged non-government schools. They show no care, acknowledgment or valuing of the small Catholic and independent schools.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the coalition, I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not opposing the passage of this Bill, the House condemns the Government for its failure to give priority to raising standards of schooling in Australia to international levels, and for the unjustified restrictions it continues to impose on the right of parents to choose their children's schooling".

SPEECH.PARA: The speech we have just heard from the Government reveals the problems that I have been talking about: the self-deception, the failure to address the facts, and an attempt to obscure the issue that vast numbers of young Australians are not learning even the basic knowledge and skills they need. The honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) talked about the fact that there is more to education than this; indeed, there is a great deal more. But let us get the beginnings right at least. Let us give these young people a chance to get their first foot on the rung so that they can climb up, develop themselves and achieve the best of which they are capable. Unfortunately, far too many of them cannot even do this.

PARA.TAB: We have heard the standard ideology from the other side that somehow or other the coalition is neglecting the neediest in the community, and in education in particular. That is totally false. We heard mention of the state of the Catholic parish schools, the low income schools. We should look at the fact that under a coalition government and our program these schools over the rest of this decade would receive some half a billion dollars-plus more than they will under the program that the Government has announced. The vast bulk of the increase in funding that we are providing to education for parent choice will be going to these schools. The neediest students in this community will be much better off under our policies than they will be under the Government's policies.

The honourable member for Port Adelaide talked about the proposal of the coalition in Fightback to produce a reduction in recurrent grants to the States, and said, `Oh well, this is going to rebound on education'. He should have a look at, and read, what we say in Fightback!. He would find out that we can deliver the Commonwealth government programs at substantially less cost than they are delivered at the present time. We can cut taxes and improve services and, at the same time, increase expenditure on education. It is all a matter of priorities—he knows that, and every State government knows that—and education has to be one of the top priorities.

The honourable member referred to the Victorian coalition Government. The Victorian coalition Government has a very imaginative policy to give parents in the government school system the right to school choice and school autonomy, and that is welcomed. I will finish my remarks there to give the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) time to second the amendment.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

PROCTEXT.PARA: SALES TAX IMPOSITION (IN SITU POOLS) BILL 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from some minor changes to the sales tax laws and the extension of the availability of the sales tax exemption for UHF transmitters until 1 January 1994, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Sales Tax Imposition (In Situ Pools) Bill are concerned with the reimposition of the 20 per cent sales tax on swimming pools constructed in situ. The House will recall that earlier this year the High Court ruled in the Mutual Pools case that the legislation purporting to impose sales tax on swimming pools constructed in situ was unconstitutional and was, therefore, of no effect.

PARA.TAB: The result of that decision was that manufactured swimming pools were subject to sales tax because they are sold as goods, whereas no tax was payable on pools constructed in situ. This was the anomaly that the Government originally sought to rectify with its legislation in 1986, which was subsequently found unconstitutional by the High Court of Australia earlier this year. Now the Government will have another go at imposing the sales tax measure with legislation of different design but intended to have the same effect as the original legislation introduced in 1986.

The two Bills will impose sales tax on swimming pools, spas and hot-tub shells that are constructed in situ, at the site. A pool builder or owner-builder will be liable for sales tax immediately after the construction of an in situ pool shell is completed. In the case of a builder, this will be so if the pool contract was or is entered into on or after 1 January 1993. In the case of the owner-builder, this will apply if construction of the shell commences on or after 1 January 1993.

It is to be hoped that this legislation when it comes into operation will be more workable than that which it replaces, which was an unmitigated disaster for all concerned. The previous legislation was an object lesson in the iniquitous nature of the wholesale sales tax regime and how not to run an indirect tax system. Unfortunately, it is not a lesson taken to heart by Labor, as it continues to foist onto the Australian people a nonsense wholesale sales tax system. It is worth recounting the history of this measure since it is an excellent example of the wholesale sales tax system at its worst, and joins the list of other equally pernicious wholesale sales tax disasters such as the 50 per cent sales tax that was introduced on expensive vehicles not so long ago, and which was subsequently abandoned after it devastated the high priced car industry, with all the implications for employment and jobs in that sector of the motor trade.

The 1986 legislation implementing the then new tax on pools built in situ deemed that a concrete pool constructed on site was a good for the purposes of the sales tax law, and imposed a complicated set of artificial deeming provisions by which the sales tax value for the pool was to be calculated and the tax then collected. These provisions were extremely complex and difficult to apply in practice. Numerous errors were made in either overpaying or underpaying the tax, and there was also widespread avoidance of the tax, taking advantage of a loophole whereby owner-builders were not obliged to pay the impost. This led to a remarkable proliferation in the number of so-called owner-builders at the expense of legitimate pool builders, who paid the tax and lost business as a result.

The Swimming Pool and Spa Association of Australia obtained legal advice that the 1986 tax was unconstitutional, and subsequently launched a challenge to its validity in the High Court. In February of this year, the High Court handed down its decision in what became the Mutual Pools case. In that decision the Court ruled that the 1986 amendments to the sales tax legislation did not conform with a requirement in section 55 of the Constitution requiring that laws imposing duties of excise deal with duties of excise only. The tax was thus found to be constitutionally invalid and said by the High Court never to have legally come into effect.

The Government was then faced with the task of refunding some 10,000 swimming pool owners for the constitutionally invalid impost that was paid on swimming pools built between 1986 and early 1992. The Swimming Pool and Spa Association claims that its members are entitled to a refund of $8m paid under an agreement with the Australian Taxation Office plus $2m in interest, and that its members paid $20m to the ATO in the period from 1986 up to mid-1990, when the agreement with the ATO was entered into. Millions of dollars in sales tax was also collected from non-Association members.

While the High Court challenge was in progress the Swimming Pool and Spa Association advised its members to stop making payments to the Taxation Office—not unnaturally—and to pay those moneys into a trust fund instead. The fund was designed to protect members against the possibility that the High Court challenge then under way might fail and that the builders would have to pay the outstanding tax to the ATO, in which case the payments could be met out of the trust fund. On the other hand, if the High Court challenge were to prove successful for the Association, the funds could then be returned to Association members, undoubtedly on better terms than those provided by the Tax Office in such circumstances.

The Tax Office agreed to this arrangement, but for about three months only before changing its mind and demanding that payments be resumed by way of monthly returns. The Association's accountants, Ernst and Young, and the Tax Office then entered into an agreement whereby pool builders would resume making payments to the Tax Office, including the funds accumulated in the trust fund. But these trust funds were to be fully refundable under the agreement if the Tax Office lost the High Court case, plus interest at the rate applicable to overpaid tax. It was on the basis of this agreement that pool builders resumed making payments to the ATO for the illegal tax and handed over the money that the Association was holding for the pool builders in the trust fund. This agreement is well documented in an exchange of letters between Ernst and Young and the Australian Taxation Office dated November 1990.

One of the effects of the High Court decision is that pool builders who were able to pass on the sales tax impost to their customers in the form of higher prices for swimming pools would in theory be able to get the benefit of the refund from the Commonwealth as a windfall gain. Refund legislation introduced by the Government earlier in this sitting sought to ensure, according to the Government, that any refunds paid by the Commonwealth went to those people who actually bore the tax, rather than to the builders who paid the tax to the Commonwealth but then passed it on to their customers in the form of higher prices. That legislation imposed a condition on the eligibility of the pool builder to a refund by requiring that where the sales tax impost was passed on to the customer the refund must also be passed on.

The legislation also provided that pool builders be paid interest for the period that they were out of pocket as a result of the High Court decision, although it contained no such consideration for the pool owners and did not even begin to repay the costs incurred by pool builders as a result of their legal ordeal with the Tax Office. The coalition supported the idea of refunding pool owners and builders for payments they had made to the Tax Office under what turned out to be an illegal sales tax impost. Unfortunately, the refund legislation that was subsequently passed by this Parliament does not even begin to bring about that result. In fact, it achieved the very opposite outcome, enabling the Tax Office to keep the money, including the trust fund moneys handed over in good faith by the Swimming Pool and Spa Association. Furthermore, it would appear that this had been the intention of the Government and the ATO in this matter all along.

Ever since the High Court decision, there had been considerable confusion about the mechanism by which the Government would be able to refund swimming pool owners. On 31 March this year, the Tax Commissioner issued a press release in which he referred to some of these difficulties. In that release he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision has raised a range of complex legal issues surrounding the questions of how and under what conditions money which has been paid as sales tax by professional and private pool builders can be refunded. These issues must be clarified before any decision on the payment of refunds can be made.

However, the subsequent refund legislation did not even attempt to address the problems created by the High Court decision. Instead, what we got was the bottom of the pool scandal, whereby the Tax Office sought to misappropriate the funds that rightfully belonged to those swimming pool owners and builders who in many cases bore the tax.

PARA.TAB: David Koch, money guide writer for the Australian newspaper, has aptly described the bottom of the pool scandal as `an intriguing litany of secret deals and fights'. It sounds typical of Labor in government in Canberra and in general, does it not, Mr Deputy Speaker? That aside, one of the problems with the first attempt at refund legislation was that the Commonwealth is liable to make a refund of tax paid only if the Commissioner of Taxation receives a declaration from the pool builder that the amount paid was not passed on to the pool purchaser or, if an amount was passed on, that amount has been refunded to the pool purchaser.

The obvious problem with that provision, however, is that it relies on the pool builders to make the necessary declaration, something which they have absolutely no incentive to do if the proceeds of a claim are not theirs to keep. As well, the pool builders must sign a declaration, subject to severe penalties for misstatement, that either no sales tax was passed on, or that sales tax has already been refunded to the owner if the pool builder is to get a refund. But most pools have been installed under the lump sum contracts which do not make identifiable provision for the sales tax.

Pool building is a very competitive industry, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, and has been made even more so due to the widespread tax avoidance that took place under the illegal sales tax problems in 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many pool builders wore the tax out of their profit margins rather than passing it on to consumers, or they only passed it on in part, and so there is often no accounting for sales tax either paid or not paid by the pool builder. Also, there is absolutely no incentive for the pool builder to make such a declaration since the total value of the refund goes to the pool owner and the builder is stuck with the administration costs. There is no compensation to the builder for the time and expense involved in preparing and lodging such declarations, processing the refunds and substantiating claims in the event of an audit by the ATO.

PARA.TAB: A pool builder would probably have to borrow at commercial rates in order to refund a pool owner until the refund from the Tax Office came along, something which just does not make business sense when the Tax Office is only paying around 14 per cent interest on overpaid tax, which is itself then subject to income tax. The Bill leaves pool owners, who may have borne the tax, without any recourse if the pool builder refuses to process a declaration which, as I have made clear, he has every incentive not to do.

There is also no recourse for the pool owner if the pool builder has since gone out of business, and many pool builders have due to the effects of the recession we `had to have' on a fiercely competitive industry. It would be impossible for these pool owners to obtain a refund, even if the pool builder were available and willing to process the declaration.

But of far greater importance perhaps than the lack of incentives for builders to process refunds is the fact that the refund legislation served to nullify the agreement between the Swimming Pool and Spa Association and the Australian Taxation Office for the refund of moneys collected illegally by the Tax Office. While this was not expressly provided for in the Bill, it was the effect of the drafting of the relevant clauses.

In collusion with its Labor masters, the ATO ratted on its agreement with the Association and sought to retrospectively deprive builders of their rights under the agreement to a refund of the moneys illegally collected by the Tax Office. Not only is this a great injustice to pool builders who handed over the money in good faith to the Australian Taxation Office; it sets an incredibly dangerous precedent for the administration of taxation law in this country.

Agreements between the ATO and taxpayers are an important part of the functioning of the Australian taxation system. They are a regular feature of relations between taxpayers and the ATO. By nullifying the agreement between the Tax Office and the Association, it is the first time that the ATO has reneged on such a major agreement with taxpayers.

Taxpayers will never again be able to trust a Tax Office agreement, to the great detriment of the administration of taxation law in this country. If businesses cannot trust the Tax Office to live up to agreements that it has made with them as taxpayers, then they have little choice but to pay tax on demand and possibly sometimes go out of business as a result. The reality behind these measures was admirably described in the Australian by Mr David Koch when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It appears the Treasurer and the Tax Office have pulled a swifty on everyone. They have broken an agreement with the builders, won political points for giving the refund to the owners but made it so hard to claim that the Tax Office will end up keeping the money.

That is about the size of it, is it not? That is a measure of the integrity with which the Australian taxation system is administered by Labor. It should be remembered that, the day after we first debated the refund legislation in this House, Mr Justice Spender of the Federal Court in Brisbane said in a judgment:

If the Commissioner were an ordinary citizen, it would, in my view, be unconscionable for him now to decline to do which he promised to do in 1990. Questions of unconscionability, estoppel and breach of warranty of authority . . . would be relevant.

The solicitor for one of the major pool building companies was even more damning in the evidence he gave to the Senate Select Committee that gave consideration to the refund legislation. In evidence, Mr Winter had this to say:

The Bill is the product of the most disgracefully dishonest or deceitful conduct by the Australian Taxation Office that I have witnessed in acting for and against government agencies in all my years of practice.

PARA.TAB: I say that the conduct is more disgraceful because the deceitful activities of the Australian Taxation Office have apparently been systematic rather than isolated.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the background to this legislation. As I said at the outset, this debacle is typical of several such disasters that have characterised Labor's administration of the wholesale sales tax system in the course of this Parliament alone. That Labor continues to inflict this iniquitous, burdensome and inefficient wholesale sales tax on the Australian people is nothing short of a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Sales Tax Imposition (In Situ Pools) Bill will alter the imposition of sales tax in three principal areas: firstly, it provides the introduction of sales tax on swimming pools constructed in situ; secondly, it grants a 12-month extension of the sales tax exemption on ultra high frequency transmitters; and, finally, it makes several minor amendments to the sales tax laws to ensure that they operate in the manner originally intended by the Government.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members would be aware that previous legislation which sought to impose a sales tax on swimming pools was ruled of no effect by the High Court earlier this year. This led to the inequitable situation where prefabricated pools were subject to the wholesale sales tax while pools constructed in situ were not. This legislation addresses this inconsistency by reimposing sales tax on swimming pools, spas and hot tub shells that are constructed in situ. A pool builder will be liable for sales tax immediately after a pool is constructed if the contract was entered into on or after 1 January 1993 or, in the case of an owner-builder, if the shell was commenced on or after 1 January 1993.

In addition to the further extension of the exemption from sales tax of ultra high frequency transmitters until 1 January 1993, this legislation also includes several other minor amendments. These changes are not intended to raise additional revenue but are rather intended to make sure the sales tax operates in the manner intended by the Government. Raising revenue is essential if governments are to be able to provide the many services that they currently offer to the community. While every tax system has its faults, the one thing that governments must aim to do is to ensure that a tax is fair and equitable. A fair and equitable tax system has been a very important part of this Government's reforms, and will continue to be so.

Those opposite have spent a great deal of time recently trying to undermine the wholesale sales tax as being imperfect. The present sales tax system may not be perfect, but the GST—the goods and services tax, the consumption tax; call it what you like—that is being proposed by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is not just imperfect, it is also rather unfair. It is important that we have a taxation system—it is essential that we have a taxation system—that is fair and equitable.

In order to understand how a goods and services tax is unjust, it is important to comprehend the advantages that the wholesale sales tax has over the goods and services tax. Since its introduction by the Scullin Government 62 years ago, the tax has been changed significantly to give effect to the various government policies, including measures to prevent double taxation of goods. The wholesale sales tax is a useful way of taxing a variety of goods at the point of wholesale as distinct from the retail point of sale. The wholesale sales tax is a single stage tax on goods manufactured in, or imported into, Australia for consumption in Australia. It applies only to goods; it is not restricted purely to the sale of goods, with the leasing of goods or the private use of goods by the wholesaler also being covered by the tax.

The sales tax does not apply to the basic necessities of life, such as basic foodstuffs that would be covered by the Leader of the Opposition's goods and services tax. It does not apply to most services, such as fresh food, houses and buildings, goods manufactured primarily from recycled materials, second-hand goods, and goods that are exported from Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: this is a very specific measure. Its title describes the legislation: Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill 1992.

PARA.TAB: Sales tax is relevant to this issue and the other matters that have been put forward. It is often suggested that a wholesale sales tax is more expensive than a goods and services tax. That is not so because the wholesale sales tax is applied at the wholesale level, and it is important to remember that. That is what happens with the swimming pools we are referring to here. For instance, a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax rate would, in many cases, be less of a burden on a consumer than a 15 per cent GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I have listened carefully. I do not recall mentioning the goods and services tax in any of my remarks. I repeat: this is a very narrow and precise piece of legislation. I urge you to ask the honourable member to address the legislation.

—The honourable member is not confined in his remarks to the statements that you made. —I know my colleagues opposite do not like to hear too much about the GST. They are running away from the goods and services tax at a hundred miles an hour. I cannot blame them for doing that.
—Do you want some support on the back bench? I can get it for you.

—Not again today; we had all that yesterday, did we not? Those are the sorts of tactics that members of the Opposition want to apply. They complain that we do not have enough time to debate these things. (Quorum formed) Every time I mention the word GST in this place, those opposite go to water. For the benefit of my colleagues who have just come into the chamber, the Bills before us are the Sales Tax Imposition (In Situ Pools) Bill 1992 and the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. They refer to the sales tax on these pools, which is what I was referring to earlier before I was rudely interrupted.

PARA.TAB: When we talk about the sales tax which is being reapplied here it is important also to talk about the case which actually took the sales tax away in the first place. That challenge has been referred to by previous speakers. When talking about sales tax, it is very difficult not to broaden the aspect a fair bit. But I will try to restrict my remarks in order to accommodate those honourable members opposite. We have limited time to debate this legislation. I know that the honourable member for McPherson wants to make a few comments and I do not want to take up too much of his time. I believe in fair play in this place, but that does not always seem to apply to those opposite.

We cannot talk about sales tax without referring to some of the things which are being put around the community at the moment about the difference between a sales tax, which has been applied to the swimming pools referred to in this legislation, and what those opposite would propose with a goods and services or consumption tax. There are great strengths in a wholesale sales tax in that it allows some goods to be taxed at a lower rate than others. People pay less for the necessities of life than they would under a GST.

The item we are talking about today—swimming pools—would be considered by many to be a luxury item; it certainly is in my community. Luxury items are generally taxed more heavily than other items and this ensures a fair degree of equity in the tax system. We talked earlier about an equitable tax system and this Government is very much committed to that.

Another advantage of the wholesale sales tax system is the low cost of collection and administration. That is important because it is a tax which is applied at the wholesale level. Contrary to some of the propaganda of the Opposition and the untruths which are peddled around the community, the costs associated with the wholesale sales tax are relatively low—only some 0.5 per cent of the revenue collected. That contrasts quite distinctly with the goods and services tax if it is to apply. Despite what those opposite would have us believe, a consumption tax on swimming pools would be quite regressive for the builders who would have to collect that goods and services tax on those pools.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think this legislation does to builders?

PARA.TAB: I wrote recently to a number of small businesses in my electorate explaining to them the problems that have occurred with the goods and services tax in Canada. PARA.TAB: The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill which we are talking about today is very crucial legislation. PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—I call the honourable member for McPherson and may we congratulate you on the addition to your family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—A late starter—or an early finisher!

—No, I am still going. The Sales Tax Imposition (In Situ Pools) Bill 1992 is very important legislation. It is a very grave matter that we now have three minutes left in which to debate this legislation seriously. I am not even sure that it is worth making a serious attempt to do it. But it is important from my point of view. As the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) observed, I have probably as many swimming pools in my electorate as I have constituents. I have been involved in this matter since day one, and in this legislation today we have just another step in the whole sorry saga of government mismanagement.

PARA.TAB: The way in which this legislation has been approached is really a joke. We now have another attempt to patch up the wholesale sales tax system. The honourable member for Oxley tried to argue that there was some merit in the wholesale sales tax system. If ever we needed to look to just one place to see why the wholesale sales tax does not work, we have only to look to this legislation.

The lengths to which the Government has gone to try to make it work are quite ridiculous. In order to actually levy the tax on an owner-builder the tax has to be defined in terms of a comparable in-ground fibreglass pool shell sold at a wholesale price. The Sales Tax Assessment Act, from start to finish, is trying to make the wholesale sales tax work in a situation where it does not work. The net effect of a value added tax in respect of this matter is that it will be fair and equitable.

I acknowledge to the honourable member for Oxley that the net effect of a GST or value added tax on the final price of a swimming pool will not be vastly different from what it is now. It will be around the same price. But the way in which the tax will be levied in respect of an in-ground swimming pool will be much fairer and more equitable. The problems which the legislation goes to great lengths to try to solve—that is, whether the pool is built by a pool builder or an owner-builder—do not exist with a value added tax. It is a very simple and straightforward mechanism for the collection of that tax. So the honourable member cannot argue in the context of this legislation or any other that a wholesale sales tax is better than a goods and services or value added tax. It is not better in this case and it is not better in any other case.

This legislation is supported by the pool industry. There has been consultation and the industry is as amazed as anybody that the Government has actually listened to it. So we have here legislation which reflects the pool builders' wish that the whole industry be treated equally and fairly. In-ground pools will be taxed in the same way as fibreglass pools and the problem we had formerly with owner-builders avoiding the tax will be overcome.

But the result of this legislation is nevertheless second best. We must ask the question: why do we tax swimming pools at all? The implication of imposing a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax is that somehow these are luxury items. I put it to the House today that for many people in this country swimming pools are not luxuries. They might be luxuries for people who live in Melbourne; but speaking on behalf of Queenslanders and people who live in hot climates and the remote areas of Australia, swimming pools are almost as essential as refrigerators.

I pose this question to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin), who is at the table, in case he gets a chance to sum up: why does the Government not tax tennis courts? There is no wholesale sales tax on tennis courts construction. There is no wholesale sales tax on landscaping. Why pick on swimming pools? The other thing I would like to say in the 10 seconds that I have left is that this legislation is an attack by this Government on small business. The way the Government expects pool builders to collect this tax is an absolute disgrace, and I hope it loses the High Court action that it is taking against Mutual Pools.
