SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill is designed to implement the measure announced in the 1992-93 Budget to tax certain car parking benefits that are received by employees from their employers. The Bill amends the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 by imposing the fringe benefits tax on these car parking benefits conferred on employees.

PARA.TAB: These benefits are said to arise only where a car used to commute from home to work is parked at or near the employee's main workplace for more than four hours between the hours of 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. If the employer reimburses the employee's car parking expenses, the value of the benefit will be the amount of the reimbursement. If the employer provides car parking facilities to an employee, the value of the benefit will be determined in accordance with the mechanism that is perhaps the most controversial part of this Bill. It specifies that the value of the fringe benefit will be the value of the lowest cost all-day parking available at a permanent commercial parking station for the public's use which is within one kilometre of the employer provided facilities.

The Bill also provides for the Income Tax Assessment Act to deny employees a deduction for similar car parking expenses which arise from parking a car used to commute to work at or near the employee's main workplace for more than four hours between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. The removal of the deduction is designed to ensure that the overall tax effect of providing either a car parking benefit or an allowance to an employee to cover his or her car parking expenses is substantially the same.

In anticipation of the many unintended consequences that this legislation can be expected to have, the legislation provides that the provision of certain car parking facilities can be exempted by regulation. These exemptions may include parking facilities provided by employers that are of a minimum value or parking facilities which would not normally be considered commercial parking stations for the purposes of the legislation. It is expected that these measures will raise an additional $90m in 1993-94, $253m in 1994-95 and $203m in subsequent years. The provisions of the Bill will come into force on 1 July 1993.

To say that this new tax measure has been badly received by employers and their employees would be something of an understatement. The cause of this bad reception is not just the additional tax burden that the tax will impose on business, although that is obviously one of the main objections. The problem that most businesses have with this tax is that it is simply unworkable, given the way in which it has been designed by the Australian Taxation Office and embodied in the legislation. Mr Stephen Harrison, the Executive Director of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The whole basis of the tax is so ridiculous it is hard to believe the Government's proposals are serious.

The Institute of Chartered Accountants has gone so far as to call this a Monty Python tax because it will see employers walking around the city streets with measuring wheels, trying to calculate the distance between their offices and the nearest parking station. Can you imagine it? It is the one-kilometre proximity test that is of special concern. The Institute of Chartered Accountants said:
The proposed method of determining liability for this tax is clearly unworkable.

Businesses and the Tax Office have enough trouble with our current fringe benefits tax laws without having to cope with ridiculous new rules which will see business owners trudging around the city streets with measuring wheels.
The idea is so comical it is hard to believe that the Government fully understands the implications of this legislation.

The Bill will require employers to carry out a number of burdensome compliance measures at their own expense in order to meet the requirements in this legislation. Firstly, employers will have to actually measure the distance between their office and the nearest commercial car park. They will then have to continually monitor car park developments in the area of their office or workplace to determine whether they thereby incur a fringe benefits tax liability as a result of a new parking space or facilities becoming available. Such an event would give rise to unwanted and unplanned for fringe benefits tax liability, which for the marginal firm could be a financial disaster.

PARA.TAB: The Taxation Institute of Australia has pointed out that large, regionally based employers may be subject to economic ransom by unscrupulous operators who may seek to gain advantage by establishing backyard stations nearby. One does not have to have much imagination to know what I am talking about. The proposal to deal with these problems by means of regulation is a totally inadequate solution to problems that might arise. Businesses will also have to monitor the regular and severe price wars between car parking stations so that the lowest all-day car parking rate can be ascertained to minimise the subsequent fringe benefits tax liability.

The position of a business that has only a premium parking station within the one-kilometre radius is particularly onerous and discriminatory. For example, commercial car parks in suburban areas are often located in shopping centres where the parking tariffs are structured to discourage long term parking. This may result in the all-day rate being as high as $20, which will be more expensive than many city car parks, even though the benefit to the employee will be worth much less than that obtained from a central business district parking place. There is also a potentially enormous compliance cost associated with keeping records to meet the requirements of the legislation.

The fringe benefits tax is a self-assessing tax, and that should not be forgotten. Employers will be required to maintain records of parking benefits provided, calculate the value of those benefits and assess the tax payable on those values. Fringe benefits tax returns must be remitted annually, and employers must pay quarterly fringe benefit tax instalments in anticipation of each year's liability.

Under this legislation employers will need to keep records of car parking bays made available and the use or uses to which they are put. They will need to keep records of the lowest fee charged by the commercial parking stations within one kilometre of their own parking facilities, which is something that changes all the time. They will need to keep records of payment of reimbursements of parking expenses incurred by their employees. They will also need to keep records of whether such parking expenses qualify for concessional treatment as either `otherwise deductible' to an employee exclusively incurred in producing the employee's salary or wages or subject to a contribution made by the employee reducing the taxable value.

The time and expense involved in meeting these record keeping and other requirements is probably far more burdensome and onerous in many cases than the actual amount of tax which will be payable. The Taxation Institute of Australia has also observed:

SPEECH.PARA: This proposed legislation is more onerous than the initial motor vehicle fringe benefits provision and the record keeping requirements are greater and will be extremely difficult to administer in their current form.

All this must have been what the Government was talking about when it mentioned that the new tax measures contained in the Budget and its tax policy statement would result in additional but unquantified compliance costs. You can say that again!

PARA.TAB: Not only is this legislation essentially unworkable; it is potentially highly inequitable in its application. The intention of the legislation is clearly to tax those highly paid executives who receive valuable car parking benefits from their employer without having to pay tax on those benefits, while many other employees must pay for their use of car parking facilities out of their after tax income. That is the clear intention, I believe.

While this might have been the original intention of the legislation, or at least the official rationale for its introduction, it has little in common with what will be the actual impact of the Bill. The amount of revenue that Labor anticipates raising from this tax and as a result of changes to the valuation of the fringe benefits tax base strongly suggests that this car parking tax will have a much wider impact than Labor's usual spiteful anti-business rhetoric would have one believe.

The new method of calculating fringe benefits tax treats fringe benefits in the same way as cash for company tax purposes by effectively raising the fringe benefits tax to the same level as the top marginal tax rate. This means that employers who do not pay company tax at the rate of 39 per cent will not have the same fringe benefits tax offsets available to them as do many businesses, perhaps businesses with which they are in competition. These employers, other than those in business, include schools, universities, hospitals, various government bodies and any other organisations that one might care to name that commonly provide parking to its employees. So while the effective fringe benefits tax rate for business will rise by a considerable 9c in the dollar, there will be a massive increase in the fringe benefits tax burden faced by these other employers.

In many cases, the fringe benefits tax rate will double. The impact on tax exempt bodies will be particularly severe, since they do not get a tax benefit for the fringe benefits tax paid. A tax exempt body that currently faces no costs in relation to providing parking to its employees and which has available $10 lowest cost parking within a kilometre will incur a fringe benefits tax liability from 1 April 1993 of $5 and a $9 liability following the change to the fringe benefits tax valuation law from 1 April 1994.

The employment consequences of this measure, particularly with the high levels of unemployment prevailing at the moment in the recession we had to have, are most unwelcome. This tax will hit many employers of blue collar workers in factories, airports and the like that provide off-street parking to their employees.

It should be noted that the tax bears absolutely no relation to the value of the car parking space to the employee and is based solely on the cost of commercial car parking available within a one-kilometre radius. This will give rise to a number of distortions and absurdities. For example, the relevant commercial car parking station may provide a facility that is of a higher standard than that provided by an employer, so that there is no real relationship between the amount charged by the commercial parking station and the value of the benefit provided by the employer in his workplace to his employee.

The commercial parking station may provide under cover security parking, complete with valet and other services, perhaps, and it will set higher prices accordingly. At the same time, an employer within one kilometre of such a facility may simply allow his employees to park on open vacant land or on the premises, yet under this legislation, it is assumed that the employee receives a benefit equal to the charge applied by the commercial parking station with the valet services, a far superior quality of parking. Of course, the reverse could also be true. Employees may be receiving the benefit of high quality car parking facilities from their employer and, yet, the employer may only pay fringe benefits tax according to the charges set by a nearby poor quality parking facility.

These measures will not just hit employers in central business districts. As already indicated, many car parking stations have been built in inner and outer suburbs, so many employers outside the CBDs will be hit for fringe benefits tax on their employee parking. At the same time, the tax may force some employers out of a CBD into the suburbs to avoid the high rates charged by central business district parking stations, and possibly to avoid local parking stations and FBT altogether. Obviously, this would be contrary to the many other urban planning policies, State and Federal, which try to encourage commuters to use public transport.

It is well established that people who work outside central business districts are far more likely to use their cars to get to work. It is also possible that this measure will further exacerbate the downturn in central business district commercial property values that has occurred in recent years, as employers seek to escape the tax-heavy CBD areas of our capital cities.

One of the reasons why this legislation may prove to be particularly burdensome is that many employers have been required by local planning laws to make provision for parking for their employees. Having incurred these additional costs required by local planning laws, these employers are now faced with an additional fringe benefits tax liability as some sort of negative reward, as it were. It is in these ways that the fringe benefits tax on car parking facilities becomes yet another tax on jobs. It increases the tax penalties for employers taking on more employees at a time when we need employment promoting policies and an employment promoting tax system such as proposed by the coalition in Fightback.

This legislation exposes the hypocrisy of Labor's attack on the equity of the coalition's tax reform proposals by demonstrating its willingness to slug blue collar and other workers with new taxes and at higher rates than those applicable to the employers of senior executives when it suits Labor's money-grubbing purposes. There are many other mechanisms available by which Labor could have sought to tax the fringe benefits of senior executives in receipt of unduly generous fringe benefits of this type, if it were of such a mind. The most obvious of these would be to levy the tax as a percentage of the salaries of those provided with free car parking by their employers. The Taxation Institute has said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential that the proposed legislation should permit employers to calculate the value of the benefit on an actual basis, as an alternative to the method currently specified.

That is, the method specified in the Bill. It is not clear why this or many other possible approaches have not been adopted, but one suspects that it has more than a little to do with how much revenue could be raised through the various options that were available to Labor to tax the car parking benefits of employees. There is a lot more revenue to be had through slugging a wide range of blue collar and other workers than in targeting the relatively small numbers of well paid executives who are the ostensible target of this legislation. That is the only conclusion that can be reached from Labor's revenue projections associated with this legislation, projections that will be blown out considerably by the change in the fringe benefits tax valuation base that is to follow a year later.

PARA.TAB: We all know that Labor is in a particularly severe revenue bind. It is faced with the almost insurmountable task of collecting enough money over the next year or so to be able to deliver on both its promised `One Nation, One Job' tax cuts and its promise to return the Commonwealth Budget balance into surplus in the year 1995-96.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's got no hope.

—It has no hope, as my friend correctly says. The Government is already in trouble in its attempt to meet these two targets. That is plain. Every scrap of revenue it can squeeze out of the Australian people between now and then will be welcomed by Labor and pursued relentlessly. Clearly, the widespread application of this fringe benefits tax measure is part of the Government's revenue grab for the 1990s. It includes a variety of new enforcement measures and extra tax collections designed to fund the Government's pre-election promises.

PARA.TAB: Despite the promised tax cuts in the `One Nation, One Job' statement, the Government has given absolutely no undertaking to lower the overall tax burden on the Australian community in the 1990s. As with unemployment, which is invariably on the way up under this regime, so with taxes. We can expect a range of new taxes after the next election, including the introduction of a de facto consumption tax in the form of a wide expansion of the wholesale sales tax system.

It should also be noted that this legislation is quite out of step with the taxation of car parking benefits in other countries. In the United Kingdom, parking benefits were taxed until 1988 but are now treated as exempt. I wonder why! In the United States, parking benefits are assessable, but deductions are allowed if incurred in business or employment related activity. In Germany, employer provided parking is exempt from any such tax. In Holland, employer provided parking is exempt if owned by the employer and where the employer rents the parking a benefit is then assessed. Generally, these countries do not recognise a benefit in employer provided parking and do not raise a tax liability on it. The conclusion of the Taxation Institute of Australia is:
The proposed legislation neither meets the tests of efficiency nor equity and needs to be substantially reviewed.

If enacted in its present form, it places substantial and onerous administrative burdens on employers and, therefore, would represent a failure by the Government in meeting its duties to the community in enacting fair and reasonable legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again, the coalition will not be opposing the Bill. Nevertheless, we will be encouraging its referral to a Senate committee to iron out our many problems with it, and in the hope that a more workable proposal may be reached.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to be as brief as I can, because my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) also wants to contribute to this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill 1992 this morning or perhaps this afternoon. I want to respond to a few comments made by the Opposition spokesman on this issue, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). He claims that this measure, which attempts to place a fringe benefits tax on car parking spaces provided by employers mainly within central business districts, is an example of Labor's usual, spiteful, anti-business rhetoric.

PARA.TAB: This alleged usual, spiteful, anti-business rhetoric is, of course, the fringe benefits tax. It is a tax which the Government introduced after the Tax Summit in 1985. We believed that it made the tax system fairer. We believed that it was wrong and unfair that people on usually very high incomes were receiving benefits from their employers for overseas holidays, luxury company cars, private school fees for the children of the employees—as people in the gallery would know, it was not people on average wages who were getting these free holidays and BMW cars provided by the boss, it was usually people on very high incomes—and were getting those benefits from the employer tax free, when ordinary wage and salary earners were having to pay tax on all of their income. That is why we have a fringe benefits tax.

The Opposition today is taking a more responsible attitude to the fringe benefits tax than it took in 1986, because in those days when the Government introduced fringe benefits tax the Opposition totally opposed it. The Opposition said it was wrong that employers should have to pay a tax on these fringe benefits. There is now a bipartisan attitude to this issue that the fringe benefits tax should apply to people who get these benefits.

The question is whether extending fringe benefits tax to car parking is a good or a bad measure. The Opposition has outlined its case as to why it considers this to be an example of Labor's usual, spiteful, anti-business rhetoric. The only problem for the Opposition is that I, like the member for North Sydney, come from New South Wales. In New South Wales we have a Liberal government—which could not be accused of having Labor's usual, spiteful, anti-business rhetoric—which has introduced an annual $200 a year levy or a tax on all car spaces within the Sydney and, I think, the North Sydney local government areas. This is an example where a Liberal government at the State level believes that it is in the public interest to ensure that perhaps there is an incentive for people to leave their cars at home and use public transport or, in addition, that perhaps those people who provide the car spaces and who encourage people to drive into the central business districts contribute towards the upkeep of traffic lights, roads and all those sorts of things.

The basic question is one of fairness. Will this measure seek to ensure that those people who get a benefit are paying their fair share of tax and are treated in the same way as the great majority of wage and salary earners? It is my view that this measure does introduce an improvement in fairness. If any people in the chamber have ever tried to park their car in a commercial car park in Sydney, they would know that they have to drive up four or five storeys before they can find a car parking space which a member of the public can use. The car parking stations sell reserved spaces to employers who provide them to their employees for $2,500 to $3,000 a year. That is a benefit that those employees are getting from their employers tax free.

If someone else, who works in the company but who does not get the annual parking space provided by the employer, wishes to park his or her car at the same parking station, he or she has to pay $2,500 to $3,000 a year out of his or her own after tax income. There is a great difference between the executive, who gets that car space provided by the employer, and the employee who uses his after tax income to try to secure parking at the same commercial car park. Once we recognise that that is a benefit in a commercial car park which should be subject to FBT, it follows that we also have to extend that same FBT to a car parking space which is on the premises of a company. Otherwise, we could have the ridiculous situation where employers who purchased the annual car parking space in a car parking station are taxed, but in the office block next door the car parking would not be subject to FBT.

It is very clear that this measure does seek to improve the fairness of the tax system and does seek to ensure that the companies, whose employees are getting this benefit tax free, are subject to fringe benefits tax. When this measure was first proposed I looked at the possibility of whether this tax could be limited to specific areas. I know there are some people in the chamber who believe that it should be limited only to the high-rise central business districts around Australia. The reason why that cannot be done is that the Constitution prohibits location specific measures in legislation.
The High Court has made a number of rulings on this issue. One is not able to pass a law which says that a tax applies only in a particular location. The tax has to treat all locations specifically.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's exactly what you've done.

—The shadow Minister at the table, the honourable member for Barker, might argue that perhaps there are some pieces of legislation that are area specific. If the honourable member is a lawyer, I might suggest to him that that legislation may not withstand challenges at the High Court, given the High Court's previous decisions on this matter. The fact that there might be some legislation currently on the statute which is area specific does not guarantee that all measures which might be proposed would withstand High Court challenges.

PARA.TAB: I also want to respond to a couple of inaccuracies in the contribution of the shadow Minister. He claimed that public hospitals would have to pay this tax. That is not true. Public hospitals, as public beneficial institutions, are exempt from fringe benefits tax, so we will not see public hospitals having to pay FBT on the parking spaces provided to their nurses or doctors. Private hospitals will be subject to FBT. Since they operate to make a profit, they should be treated in the same manner as other companies that seek to make a profit.

I think it is important to realise that this measure will raise $200m. It will raise that $200m largely from people who receive a benefit from their employer in that they are provided with annual car spaces in commercial car parking stations in the central business districts of Sydney and Melbourne. This measure improves the fairness of the taxation system and seeks to ensure that the executive is treated in the same way as the employee. For those reasons, the Bill has my strong support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the concept of removing subsidies from parking has to be supported on both equity grounds and traffic grounds. Parking has always been the main determinant of traffic. The subsidies for parking spaces in inner urban areas are one of the main reasons for traffic congestion in those areas. Legislation such as the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill has the potential to dramatically reduce the use of private cars in peak hours in inner Sydney.

PARA.TAB: The costs of providing for the use of cars in the inner city are very substantially detracting from many other good uses which that money could be put to, both for Australia's road system generally and for many other activities. Most people are not aware of the enormous subsidies that we are providing. One example is the two-lane Cullerin bypass on the Hume Highway, which is worth about $6m a kilometre. The recent construction of the Gore Hill Freeway link cost $43m a kilometre. The construction of the tunnel cost, in effect, $1 billion a kilometre. This is the massive extent of subsidy that we are giving to the car driver in inner cities, which is detracting from all the other good uses of funds around Australia. In principle, I think this Bill has to be supported both on equity grounds and on traffic grounds.

As the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) has pointed out, there are very serious problems with this measure. The heart of the problem is how to determine valuations of car parking spaces. I appreciate the efforts the Taxation Office has made to relate it to the use of commercial car parks, but, judging by all of the objections that have been advanced, this has already raised a number of distortions and inequities in the system.

I can see that in my own electorate it will even start to determine where people locate their offices, because in Neutral Bay people will pay no fringe benefits tax but in Crows Nest they will pay it. We will create a race of consultants who will go around determining where people should locate their offices in order to avoid this tax. It will have a very dramatic effect on local government, because it is the main supplier of commercial car parks, probably because they are all subsidised.

There is some scope for flexibility in the Bill, but that in turn will raise a whole range of objections and problems. I am worried that, because we have this difficulty in determining the valuations in a manner which will not create distortions, the Bill will fail, either in the Senate or elsewhere. The principles of it are extremely good and should be pursued. I am very pleased to see that it will overcome the problem of the Commonwealth Government's subsidy of the $200 per car space tax in New South Wales. As things stood, the Commonwealth would have been providing $78 of that tax to the New South Wales Government. I am also very pleased to see that it will apply across the board; that it will apply to government bodies—local and State—as well as to private enterprise. I feel that we have to find some other way to get around the distortions and inequities in the valuation system.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Ms McHugh) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Robert Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill amends the National Health Act 1953 to address an anomaly regarding the nursing home benefit payments scheme. This scheme is based on cost reimbursement; that is, funds are advanced by the Government during the year to owners of nursing homes to help with costs of patients and their maintenance. At the end of the year, where the owner has spent less on providing nursing home care than the Government advanced, the amount of unspent or overadvanced funding must be repaid. However, the money is not legally characterised as recoverable debt or entitlement.

PARA.TAB: This idiosyncrasy in the principal Act means that such amounts can be recovered only by fee loadings and not as debts. Thus proprietors who accrue a liability to the Commonwealth for overadvanced funding and then sell their nursing homes cannot be pursued for that overadvanced funding following the sale. However, the new proprietor is required to repay the amount from his fees, irrespective of the earlier amount.

This Bill seeks to change the system so that the person who accrues the liability can be pursued for the money. Overadvanced benefits will be legally characterised as a debt recoverable through the courts. This amendment is welcomed by the coalition and the industry, but there is some concern that the Bill changes the system only prospectively. Many nursing homes around the country have suddenly found themselves liable for huge debts—sums of $250,000, $300,000, $150,000 and $96,000. The Government says that services rendered several years ago by the home, often under earlier management of a different proprietor, cannot be proven, yet those debts are effectively part of the new contingent liabilities of the new owner.

Overadvanced Commonwealth funds are now being clawed back. The Government is only now carrying out across-the-board assessments to see whether money advanced to nursing homes as far back as 1986-87 can be substantiated by receipts. If so, hopefully the funds will be regained. The Government should have been doing these assessments every year. Surely taxpayers are entitled to know that the Government of the day is monitoring how it is spending their money. Similarly, nursing home owners could then continue their operations for the next year with full knowledge of their financial situations, commitments and responsibilities.

I have two examples of the problems caused by the Government's policy to date. The first is a nursing home operated by the Association of the Blind in Western Australia. It has recently been presented with a bill for $250,000 for overadvanced benefits dating back to 1985. The money is being clawed back at the rate of $5,000 per month. As a result, the nursing home is operating at a loss and is facing possible closure.

Another example is a nursing home in Sydney which was purchased last year. The new owner is now being hit with a bill of close to $150,000. She was not advised by either the previous owner or the Department of the possibility of this additional debt. The Commonwealth is reducing the daily per patient subsidy until it reclaims the $150,000. The owner is therefore taking legal action against the Government, but in the meantime has to maintain an adequate standard of services to the patients.

Another amendment in the Bill addresses the problem of disclosure of debt when the nursing home is sold. The amendment requires that an owner has to identify outstanding overpayments and fee loadings prior to the sale of a home. The owner also has to disclose this financial information to prospective purchasers.

The Government will be able to recover overpayments at the point of sale and from the proceeds of the sale. Owners will be required to give notice of sale to the Government and will be deterred from completing the sale within 90 days of giving notice. Purchasers will also be required to give notice of their intent. The period of notice under the legislation will enable the vendor's claims, books and records to be scrutinised so that a fair estimate may be made of any overpayment and any anticipated fee loading which could relate to the period until sale. Prior to the sale, the purchaser will be required to pay from the purchase price the amount of the estimated overpayment.

These changes are intended to afford greater protection of the rights of the Government to money owed to it, and the rights of purchasers to information about the nursing home they are buying and to a home unencumbered by liabilities accrued by the previous owner. Although the industry says the proposals should be retrospective, the Government has chosen not to go down this path, presumably because it thinks that it is up to the current owners to take action against previous owners for non-disclosure of debt. However, I would like to point out that the owners of nursing homes are often small business people and would not be able to afford the significant costs of legal recovery action. Nevertheless, the protection in the Bill for future buyers is welcomed by the Opposition. The changes are sensible and will avoid recurrence of examples I have already related. The Opposition will support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government welcomes the Opposition's support for the National Health Amendment Bill. It is an important piece of legislation which shows very clearly, I believe, to those who might be listening to this debate and to those who are interested in this particular area, that there is an important role for government in the oversight and scrutiny of the practices that occur in our community. Nursing home proprietors receive Commonwealth benefits in advance during the year. These benefits are applied to the running of the nursing home and to make sure that the people who are residents of the nursing homes have sufficient and adequate care and attention.

PARA.TAB: It is the case under the present structure that at the end of the year the costs that are actually incurred are acquitted against the money that has been advanced. It is very often the case that there has been an overpayment to a nursing home. As a result of that, there is a requirement—an obligation, as I believe most people would agree—for that money to be repaid. Under the present structure that money is repaid according to a negative fee loadings system by which, during the subsequent year, the fees of the nursing home are varied according to the previous overpayment. This particular structure provides some problems, and it is by a legislative quirk that it is the case that such debts, which all of us would see as debts, are not recoverable as debts; they are not legally characterised as debts. So it is not possible for somebody who purchases a nursing home, and finds that the circumstances are such that debts have been accrued, to take action through the court to collect what might be seen by most people as a debt.

It is the case in the sale of nursing homes—and the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) outlined a couple of cases—that these circumstances have prevailed. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), in a press release in August of last year, suggested that there needed to be original proprietor liability which meant that the new purchaser should not hold liability for any debts that had been accrued by a previous owner. The entitlement to the benefit unfortunately did not crystallise until the Commonwealth was able to determine what was owed by means of an audit. It was the delay process, or the time to determine the debt, that caused such problems.

The money was paid in advance, but there were no means whereby this could be determined as a recoverable debt legally. What will happen in the new provisions is that this money will be paid in advance on a provisional basis. Once the actual expenditure is determined it will be possible for the Commonwealth to recover the debt by law. What we are seeing here is a change in the way in which nursing home funding is administered. It is a change which is brought about by legislative fiat, and it is something that is the job of this Parliament; it is the mechanism of government.

The Opposition is at present coming into this place and flying around the country suggesting that government does not have a place, suggesting that we need less and less government in this nation. But we find, rather paradoxically in respect of this legislation and many pieces of legislation that come into this House, that it accepts the necessity for us to legislate to oversee such practices as the provision of services by the Commonwealth in nursing homes.

There is an inconsistency in the position that is put by those opposite because in many areas they are suggesting we need less government when the empirical and theoretical evidence would indicate that this would lead to huge cost blow-outs. It is inconsistent on the part of those opposite to come into the House and to say how they are looking for efficiency and how they believe we can save money by getting out of the business of government yet, at the same time, in many cases saying that they understand there is a role for government, that it is an important role and something they support.

There have been many examples, as I have said, of nursing home benefits provided by the Commonwealth being used by proprietors for purposes other than the support of residents. When the nursing home is sold the difficulty arises for the new purchaser. Many of course would say that this is the classical case of caveat emptor: let the buyer beware. If the buyer is disappointed with his purchase then the responsibility lies with him. But the particular circumstances of nursing homes, the way in which they are funded and the constitutional responsibility of government require that our first consideration should be the care and attention given to those frail aged people who are resident in nursing homes. Our second consideration must surely go to the taxpayers who provide the funding which is so important to the provision of adequate frail aged care and care in nursing homes.

It was in autumn last year that we required the disclosure of relevant information for purchasers. That change to the legislation enabled prospective purchasers to obtain from the Commonwealth information about the status of nursing homes and the particular position of a nursing home before they purchased. Unfortunately, that still did not go far enough. In this legislation we require notice of sale to be part of the sale process of a nursing home. This will require a period of about 90 days during which it will be possible for the prospective purchaser of a nursing home to find out exactly what is going on, what the details are and who owes money to whom. As I have indicated, there have been many cases where this has not been adequately pursued. We are hopeful that the requirements for notice of sale will bring about changes.

The arrangements of the sale will have to take into account all of the details which relate to a particular nursing home and all overpayments and all debts owed by the nursing home prior to the sale taking place. The person who accrues the debt will be required to pay it. It will protect taxpayers' money which is applied to this very important purpose of providing care for the residents of nursing homes. It will, of course, protect the rights of purchasers. For those who work or who are involved in the nursing home industry and involved in buying and selling, it will clarify the situation significantly. For those who work in nursing homes and who are residents in nursing homes, it will be an important consideration.

It is the case that there is a debate in this country about what role the Commonwealth should have in respect of health care, aged care, pensions and a large number of such issues. Last night the Opposition spokesman on health care, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), suggested in this place, in very dulcet tones—quietly, meekly—that one of the great dilemmas in our health care system related to waiting lists for hospitals and that these had not previously been a problem. Had I been in the House—unfortunately, I was in my room—I might have said to him that, when I was a resident medical officer working at a large general hospital in Perth in the late 1970s, it was very clear to me that one of my responsibilities was the management of waiting lists for elective surgery. The waiting lists went for some months—some for as long as six months or a year. So it is the case that waiting lists have always been a method used to efficiently run hospitals and utilise the resources applied to health care; waiting lists have been a part of our structure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you justifying waiting lists on that basis?

—Absolutely! There would not be a system anywhere in the world which would have it any other way. If I have a car repair business and my mechanics are sitting around with nothing to do for a lot of the time, that is a very inefficient way to use my resources. If I can have a constant flow of work for them, that would be a much more efficient use of resources, of their capacities and abilities. Those opposite may not like the analogy but it applies in exactly the same way to filling hospital beds and using hospital resources and health resources efficiently.

PARA.TAB: Other countries have other systems. The problem with the shadow Minister is that he says that what we are doing is using waiting lists and Medicare to hold down costs and that the Opposition would remove all those and still hold down costs. Unfortunately, that would not happen. All of the empirical and theoretical evidence anywhere in the world suggests that that would not be the case.

If we want to eliminate those waiting lists—and I think we probably could—we would have to spend twice as much on health care. That would have to come from either taxpayers or individuals paying massive premiums for private health insurance. If that is what those opposite want to do, they should stand up in this place and say so—and say so all over the country. But they should not come into this place and suggest that they can do twice as much and spend the same amount of money, because it is impossible unless the money that is presently applied is being hopelessly and inefficiently applied—and that is neither my experience nor, I believe, the experience of most practitioners in the field.

Most other countries do have systems whereby they ration the application of resources. In the United States they ration it by price. The things that we take for granted in this country as basic requirements for medical health care are not available to people in the United States unless they are very wealthy or very well insured by their employer. Indeed, health insurance is a cost to business. We have not heard those on the other side screaming about it yet, but it will become part of a condition of employment and it will be something that employers will be required to pay here. It is a cost to employers in other countries which have the sort of structure that those opposite are wanting to determine. They should consider that. In the United States they ration by price. There are 30 million people in the United States without adequate health care, and the most common cause of bankruptcy in the United States is ill health.

In the United Kingdom they have a different structure; essentially, they ration by time, as we do, but they also have limits. People over 65 years cannot get their hips replaced in the public system. It does not matter how bad it is, or what the circumstances are, they cannot get that done. Kidney dialysis machines are not available to people over 60 years. So the United Kingdom rations much more viciously than we do. If people fall outside those guidelines, then it is price that operates again.

We have a very compassionate system in this country, a system that works and rations according to time. It is not ideal. It would be better if everybody could be served immediately, but the costs of that are something that we cannot afford. Just as local budgets have to be managed, this Government has to manage the budget of this country. That is a consideration that really needs to be taken into account. Those opposite have come in here and said, `There is no role for government; market forces can work'. Unfortunately, in the area of health care and in the provision of these very important services, market forces do not operate in the same way as we would like them to operate.

We come to the area which is important here, the area which relates to how we will look after nursing homes. If we look at the sorts of things that the Opposition has said about aged care, the sorts of things that it is wanting to do, we find that there are lots of platitudes in Fightback!. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We want to ensure that the sick, the old and those genuinely in need receive the assistance they deserve but we want to put an end to the rorts and abuses of such assistance by people who can, and should, provide for themselves.

Those are very laudable sentiments. I was here in 1984. We had an election at the end of that year, and the big issue—the thing that hurt the Labor Party, and I admit that it hurt the Labor Party—was the assets test on pensions. We said, `Okay, if you have $300,000 or $400,000, maybe you do not require the Government to pay you a pension every week. If you are a millionaire in this country, then maybe we cannot afford to pay you a pension every week'. We saw a most vicious campaign by the Opposition against the assets test, which was a fair and reasonable test by any account.

PARA.TAB: What do we ask of the Government? What do we ask of legislators, and what do we expect of the people who come to the Parliament in that role? We expect them to be consistent in their arguments. We are seeing incredible inconsistency from the Opposition. We expect the people who make the laws in this country to have a sense of justice and fairness. It is not fair and just that those with very substantial means should have received the pension. It was a change that needed to be made, should have been made, and was made. My experience in this place is that, every time that sort of suggestion is made, we look for the political chance—we look for the puny motive. The assets test debate was a debate along those lines.

When looking for people who we think will legislate well for us, we look for people who understand that there needs to be efficiency and prudence in the way in which money is applied. That is clearly the case. The Opposition suggests in its policy that we need to put an end to the rorts and abuses of such assistance by people who can and should provide for themselves. We do not have any difficulty with that. We have been in this job now for nearly 10 years. One of the things we have tried to do is to make the system fairer, to make people accountable for the benefits they receive. We have done that in a substantial number of ways. We have tried to improve the taxation system so that there is a fair and just way of making people pay their responsible dues and pay what is fair.

Yet we see the Opposition proposing—and, indeed, it is the central plank of its policy for the next election—a goods and services tax. It is a tax which will be applied across the board on food, clothing, housing costs and many other services. Going to the football, having a haircut, and going to the movies—all of these things—will be taxed; in particular, food and clothing.

I heard the argument from the other side: `Well, lots of other countries have a goods and services tax'. Many countries do have a goods a services tax. I agree with that. But in almost all of those countries there is a differential rate for those things which are considered to be the necessities of life, those things which are believed to be essentials and important for everybody's ordinary everyday living.

It is not the case that the Opposition's proposal wraps up anything like that sense of fairness which has been captured by every other country which has a goods and services tax. We have across the board taxation, so a family of four with an income of $30,000 supposedly eats much less than a family of four with an income of $100,000. That is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —What relevance is this?

—Does the honourable member want to talk relevance? I will get back to it. I am talking about fairness and the role of government. Those opposite are suggesting that government should not have a role, except when they think it is a good idea. I believe it is important that we consider these issues. The issue in respect of this legislation, if those opposite want to get back to it, is about the role of government, and those opposite are supporting us on it. They come into this place and support us on lots of pieces of legislation like this, but they are inconsistent.
—When you're right.

—No. There is a moral principle that runs through it and it is inconsistently applied by those opposite; that is why they are all over the place. That is why the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is in trouble; that is why the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) sits behind him and does not giggle and laugh like the rest of those opposite—he understands what is going on and he knows that what the Opposition is proposing is vicious and unnecessary.

PARA.TAB: There is a role for Government in respect of this legislation. It is reflected in what we are doing here. I believe that, with the support of the Opposition, it should have the support of all honourable members. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1992 will be discussed together. I was interested to hear the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) reinforcing the fact that this Government has been in power for nearly 10 years.
—And has done a good job, too.

—We will see about that in the not too distant future, I understand. These two Bills, after a period of 10 years, now purport to improve the anti-dumping arrangements in Australia, after all that time. I will say at the outset that there is absolutely no doubt that this Government, in the early stages of its career, viewed the people who took anti-dumping action or countervailing action against subsidisers as arch protectionists. There is no doubt in industry that that is the view of most people. It has led to a situation where—and those opposite will remember—the timeframes have been brought well back. At one stage we were facing a series of procedures which took between 300 and 400 days to get to some fruition in a decision about anti-dumping or about subsidising. That timeframe has been brought back by this Government—not far enough—to a total of 245 days. It is not short enough, and the same problem still exists in industry; that is, most people who wish to run an anti-dumping or a countervailing action against people who they feel have been cheating in the international market—in other words, exporting products from the country of origin at less than the normal value or the normal price—are put off by the fact that the timeframe and the cost of that timeframe are just too great. I will come back to that a little later.

PARA.TAB: These two Bills propose to amend the Customs Act 1901, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 and the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988. The Government says that these Bills represent the final change in Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing provisions. This will not be the final change, because when the Government changes we will make significant other changes which, amongst other things, will change to some extent the material injury test and certainly the timeframes in which people can confidently expect a result and, more importantly, confidently expect an interim result, which is what really matters. The Government has said that this will be the last change. There will be more to come.

As the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) said in his second reading speech, goods are said to be dumped if the export price of the product is less than the normal value; that is, the comparable price for the like product in the domestic market of the exporting company. Anti-dumping action can only be proven if it is established as a result of inquiries by Customs and the Anti-Dumping Authority that goods have been dumped and that the dumping is causing or threatening material injury to the Australian industry. That is quite true.

These Bills change the manner in which duties are imposed and collected after one has been proven guilty, if you like. As was said in the Minister's second reading speech, the current legislation—those arrangements which are in place at the present time—imposes a dumping duty which represents the difference between the export price and the normal value of goods or, where the Minister directs, a lesser amount sufficient to remove the injury.

Under the present regime the duty is not payable if a correction is made by raising the actual export price to the level of the normal value determined at the inquiry. That is seen to be a shortcoming, and we agree that it is a shortcoming. This after 10 years of the Labor Party being in government, and after probably seven or eight years—five at least—of the community saying to the Government time and time again that these anti-dumping procedures are just too long, that they are too onerous, that they are too expensive, that they do not work, and that even when we get an anti-dumping measure in place, which is what these Bills are about, all of a sudden we find that somebody makes an adjustment and they slip around the net.

So the Government has chosen to bring in some measures which agree in substance with the sorts of anti-dumping and countervailing systems that are used in the EC and, in a general sense, in the USA. As I said, we do not disagree with the changes, but they have taken so long. Here we are, after all this time, making some changes because the community has demanded them and because the Opposition has changed the timeframes and the Government has suddenly decided it had better do something about it.

People say to us, `Well, you have changed the timeframe from 245 days total to 155 days. You have changed the time in which, if you have a case to answer, you can get an answer from the Customs Service. You have changed the time from the preliminary hearings'. The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) probably totally agrees with all the changes that we have made but he is not able to say so. He might—if he is honest enough. People say, `You have changed the time for the preliminary findings to 60 days'—and a grin tells a lot.

People say to us, `There is no doubt that you are getting to the fine edge of the time slots that are needed for proper evidential procedures to take place', and we agree. Sixty-five days in total or 60 days for the preliminary hearing is getting to the close edge of the time slots, but I think it is a matter of instruction and resources. The Customs Service has a lot of resources, and it is a matter of rejigging those resources to make sure that those people who feel they have been besieged by people dumping or—as is very likely and as has no doubt been happening in this country—sending subsidised goods here from the other end of the world have a set of procedures which they can get to quickly, which they can trust and which will not unduly affect them financially.

I believe that the 60-day measure, which is the Opposition's policy, is possible, and that the timeframes the Government has finally, after all this time, been brought to are not needed. After all these years the Government is finally down to having the preliminary hearings in a total of 125 days—prima facie 25 and preliminaries 100—compared with the coalition's 65. The end of those preliminary hearings will give people the confidence of knowing that they will either get their case thrown out or get a measure in place which they can trust, and that is very important. In previous legislation the Government agreed with us that the sunset period of five years needed to be brought in, and that has been done.

To come back to these Bills, I have said that the method of collection has been changed. Each time there is an importation there will be a system whereby the dumping margin can be collected. In other words, people will not be able to solve the problem initially and have it go away if they have been in the business of cheating. This is important because, as protection comes down in this country, predictably and transparently so people can see it, those people competing in this country with the rest of the world must know that the treasuries of other countries cannot be used against them without retribution being applied to those exporters from other countries who are using either internal subsidisation or export enhancement, the American system. Where companies dump for whatever reason, people must feel that in fact they can overcome those problems.

There is a great deal of fear out there. It is not a fear of having to compete in Australia. Many people now understand that we will have to compete in the international market. If we want to be exporters it is no good sitting here behind a barrier of defensive mechanisms saying, `We will just increase the defensive mechanisms if we cannot compete'. People understand that we are in the world marketplace, but they need to know that there is a mechanism to defend them against the international cheats who use a dumping mechanism where they just get rid of their excess supply into those countries that will take it or, alternatively, use their countries' largess, their countries' treasuries, as we have seen so many times.

There is no doubt that these two Bills will help people increase their confidence. I repeat: I wish that this Government would seriously take on board the problem of the timeframes. The timeframes in these anti-dumping procedures are too long. There is no problem with the onus of proof in the initial hearings: the onus of proof is upon those persons who say that somebody is cheating. In the second and final hearings the onus of proof in fact changes. Once there is an anti-dumping duty and interim penalty upon a person, in the second and final hearings the person has to prove he was in the right. In other words, the onus of proof changes at the second hearing.

There is no doubt that these two Bills will increase people's confidence. I repeat that I wish this Government would seriously take on board the problem of the timeframes. The timeframes are too long in these anti-dumping procedures. There is no problem about the onus of proof in the initial hearings. The onus of proof is upon those persons who say that somebody is cheating.

In the second and final hearings, of course, the onus of proof changes, because once there is an anti-dumping duty and interim penalty upon a person, then in the second and final hearings that person has to prove that he was in the right. In other words, the onus of proof changes at that second hearing.

My final comment about these Bills for the time being is that it is about time. This Government has been dragged to the positions that are enunciated in these Bills, after effluxion of time, by the market saying that the Government is too slow and unfair, and by the Opposition changing a lot of policies which the Government has finally had to follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, will be absent from Question Time today and tomorrow. In his absence, questions should be directed to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples. I also inform the House that the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Mr Kerin, will be absent from Question Time today and tomorrow. In his absence, questions should be directed to the Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's recent comments on reducing violence which children can see on television, for which he has my full support and the full support of the coalition parties. I ask the Prime Minister: does he agree that AO programs should not be run on TV before 9.30 p.m? Will the Government legislate if necessary to achieve that objective? Further, given that the Commonwealth has the power to ban X-rated videos, will he join with us in recognising community concerns and ban X-rated videos throughout Australia, including the Northern Territory and the ACT?

—Naturally, I would welcome the support of the Leader of the Opposition on a matter such as this. But again, a matter such as this—which has changed over the years as community standards have changed and as the television networks have believed standards have changed and have exploited those changes—requires at least, I think, a discussion with the networks and requires us to look at the whole question of classifications as well.
—So you are wimping out.
—Order!

—The Government does not need an offer from the Liberal Party to again pull the smoking gun out to push a piece of law through quickly as a way of solving problems. This is the point we have been making to Opposition members about Victoria. The idea that you can legislate or drop a press release in the press boxes to change ingrained social attitudes or institutional attitudes and practices belies the sophisticated nature of the problems. There is a notion that we can just fix this by whipping a Bill through. It may well be that legislation is appropriate, but I have written to the—
—Make it up as you go.
—Order!

—Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, to let it know the Government's view. It has asked to see me, and I intend to see it. The fact is that the problem goes beyond television. It also goes to films and to videos. Part of the problem is that the M category is so broad that we have films such as Crocodile Dundee and Silence of the Lambs all categorised as M. I made the point this morning when speaking on the two-day seminar on families and issues associated with the families, which is being promoted by Ita Buttrose, that the M classification is too broad and that maybe there should be a split in that classification so that not just the softer end of products are listed under classification but there is also a subpart of the classification in which there are penalties for selling such products to children under the age of 15 years.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the M classification is an advisory classification; it does not have any restrictive quality. It means that there are no penalties for exhibitors or retailers who disregard it. I think that is something that we should and could think about, and I said that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the Prime Minister.
—I did not hear any of you talking about the subject until I did.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—You are all now a bunch of little Sir Echoes.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Just hear me out. I also said that the setting of classifications is a Commonwealth-State matter and that at the 7 December meeting of the Council of Australian Governments in Perth I will ask my colleagues, the State Premiers and Chief Ministers, to list film and video classifications as an agenda item so that we can talk about the problem.
—What about X-rated videos?
—I know that you are such a goody-goody about these things.
—Are you in favour of banning them?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—Here you are again trying to make a cheap political point by way of interjection. I am trying to put a position of bipartisanship on this—
—Here we go; a personal attack.
—No.
—Yes, usual form for you.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell!
—I am trying to put a position of some bipartisanship while we have el cheapo interjections from the front bench. Part of the real problem is this dual system of categorisation.
—Are you in favour of it or not?
—Order!

—Let me make this point, Mr Speaker. I am not about telling Australians what they can watch; I am about seeing it categorised properly and having the proper timeslots on television. That is what we are talking about. We are not, as usual, doing the paternalistic routine that you are quite happy to do—mostly between midnight and the early hours of the morning beyond the realm of public discussion.

PARA.TAB: We now have two competing systems. We have a system which obtains in movie houses and video stores and one which obtains on television. They are not the same. The former Australian Broadcasting Tribunal recommended that we adopt a common system. It favoured replacing the present film and television system with one, splitting the M classification along the lines I have already described.

I should think that getting to a single system rather than a dual system and getting a tighter handle on that single system in respect of that material which is categorised as M, or what we may term as other categories of M, and at the same time seeing to what extent those classifications and changes of time presentation materially advance the removal of a lot of this material—particularly violent material—from children, is a useful, sensible thing to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a paper tiger.
—I beg your pardon?
—You are a paper tiger.
—Order!

—In other words, if we do not accept your offer of ramming an amendment through the House we are not being real about this; is that right? We have not heard from you about it. Is this not just like the Liberal Party—no consultation, no discussion, and no taking account of the views of anyone who matters. It would never occur to you that to have the cooperation of the television stations in removing material from films is perhaps more important than even the timeslots. It would never occur to you that their active cooperation would be of any benefit.

PARA.TAB: It has certainly occurred to me and to us. That is why I will see Mr Campbell and FACTS and any of the other broadcasting interests which want to see us. If we believe that it is then worth legislating, we may take up your offer. But it will be after some thought and will not be a knee-jerk reaction to climb on board an issue which in the past you have shown no interest in.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is also about Australian families, is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister assure the House that the Government's continuing approach to enterprise bargaining will ensure that no working families will be worse off as a result of workplace reforms?

—Over the last day or two I have said that the number of enterprise agreements concluded under this Government continues to multiply. The new Australian Airlines flight attendants' agreement, for example, raises productivity and at the same time introduces a provision allowing special leave for employees to take care of sick children. I commend this sort of provision to the Parliament because it demonstrates that we are recognising in the workplace the special needs of families when more and more mothers are in the paid work force and more fathers are taking responsibility for the care of children.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that the Australian workplace is rapidly being transformed with greater flexibility and higher productivity. Part of that greater flexibility will enhance the convenience and reward of work for women employees, many of whom are juggling child-care with part or full time work. I referred earlier to the family summit organised today by Ita Buttrose. This morning I nominated how we as a country could go about reconciling work and family as a vital issue for consideration during the International Year of the Family, which is coming up in 1994.

I can understand that women in this community are now quite deeply concerned about changes to the industrial relations system after what we have seen in Victoria. Under Victorian awards, working women have already lost the annual leave loading and very soon they will lose weekend penalties. They know that these benefits have not been lost through consultation or on any bargain basis or with any compensating benefit. For occupations like nursing the effects are going to be quite catastrophic as a substantial proportion of the working week is in penalty time and for which they have been paid. I noticed on television the other night that Mr Gude was quite proud of the fact that it will be a criminal offence—can you imagine this?—in the State of Victoria to fail to comply with any provisions of one of the employment contracts. It is not a matter of industrial disputation to be industrially bargained. It will be a criminal offence if someone breaks an element of the employment contracts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—It is unbelievable that these Dickensian provisions—
—You blokes over there are so quiet. What is up with you?
—Order! The Minister will cease interjecting.
—Order!
—like some extract—
—Name him! Throw him out!
—Order!

—from Oliver Twist are in the industrial laws of a country such as Australia in 1992. But women know that under the Federal Opposition's policy every employee in the country will be forced off his or her current awards and into individual contracts, unless the employer chooses to remain in the award.
—The honourable member for Higgins!

—Women know that there will be no protection of weekend penalties, overtime rates, leave loadings or overaward payments when the employer offers the contract. They know that under the common law system proposed by those opposite they can be sacked at any time for any reason, and that they will have no recourse to the courts because there is no such thing as an unjust dismissal under the common law. So long as you get a day's pay for a day's work, that is all the employer owes you. So women are concerned about industrial legislation and how their families will cope under such a system.
—Oh!

—I hear groaning from people opposite, who are always talking about families. But the Opposition supports families who can support themselves. It does not support families that need support. That is why it does not care about the impact of its industrial legislation. It supports traditional associations, presumably those of the distant past where we had a more traditional construction for families. But where social justice is defined, the association between employers and employees would be reweighted against the employees as it was a century ago.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal Party supposedly supports family traditions, but it does not support women in Australian families who are going to have their incomes cut. It does not support them as we support them with an ambitious government program of child-care to give them the opportunity to work. It supports the idea of the family but not its substance. It does not support the essentials of the family's existence.

All of this legislation basically attacks penalty rates and other conditions of employment such as we have seen in the Australian Airlines flight attendants agreement which raises productivity and at the same time allows provisions for women particularly to look after sick children. All of that goes in the industrial legislation proposed by the Opposition, the same Opposition which tells us ad nauseam that it believes in the family.

This is just another example of how, under this Government, industrial agreements are being negotiated flexibly to really look after the patterns of work that are needed in the workplace, particularly to look after the interests of Australian women, those with children, looking after families. Some of the children are sick. They are being taken care of under our industrial relations policies, but will be totally ignored by the Opposition's policies. The Opposition believes in pushing eight million people on to common law contracts where all of this sort of thing goes.
Next the Opposition will tell us that it believes in the family. But it is only a family that does not need support, not one that needs any support or consideration—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—It is quite happy now to remove any consideration and convenience from Australian families, most particularly and especially those which support Australian women.

PARA.TAB: Mr Reid interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bendigo will cease interjecting.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Speaking of taking care of families, I refer the Prime Minister—

—Order!

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Mr McGauran—What are you doing? Why don't you shut them up?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting as well.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Members on my left will cease interjecting. The Leader of the Opposition will complete his question.
—They do not like it, Mr Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—That 18 of them had to pawn or sell something to get cash; that 17 of them could not pay insurance on their house, its contents or their car—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—that 20 of them had to get financial help from family or relatives to pay for day-to-day needs; that 18 of them got behind in their mortgage rates or rental payments; that 15 of them got behind in their hire purchase payments?

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Will the Prime Minister please explain to the House why all Australian families should not be allowed to treat the next election as a referendum on the pain and misery you have inflicted on Australian families?

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—What about them? Look at what is happening over there.
—Order! The House will come to order.

—That referendum point has stung you, has it not? You are shying away from the idea of a referendum on the GST like Dracula from a wooden stake. Back you are going from any notion of being taken to account on this question. How you believe, in detailing that list as you have, that a 15 per cent tax on their food and clothing would help is beyond me; how it would help by taking $7 billion, or nearly 2 per cent of GDP out of the Budget—
—Order! The House will come to order.
—A lie.
—Order!
—how it would help them to deny medical protection by destroying Medicare—
—A lie.
—Order!
—Another lie.
—Order!

—so that they have to privately insure themselves; how it would help them as you go into zero tariffs and see the jobs which are sitting there in a couple of very substantial industries disappear for those people so affected. I mean, how would it help them if they were unemployed? You would knock them off benefits after nine months.
—Not true!
—These are all things which I think you had better come to terms with—
—Not true!
—Order!
—before you direct these sorts of questions to me. You are not supporting a social security policy which provides support for people in these positions.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—You are not supporting unemployment benefits to people until they find employment. You are not supporting the kind of public system which provides family allowance supplement support per child for low income families.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—You are not supporting that. You are going to hop into the social security system and cut $10 billion from it to pay for tax cuts up the other end while you use the GST money to cut the price of petrol.

—They are going back to the policies of inclusion, of keeping the American family together and caring for one another, as Mr Clinton put it. You are saying, `It is survival of the fittest. PARA.TAB: I noticed you saying a couple of months ago to some Liberal Party forum that the notion of pulling the poor along with you was to drag the rest of us down. That is what you said.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a disgrace!

—When I said, `Let's put an arm out and pull them up behind us', you said, `Yes, and drag the rest of us back'. That is the view you put. You are on the record as saying it. You are on the record as saying that you are quite happy to have an underclass in Australia. You want the rich moving forward and you want to see the links break.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—You do not want to bring them together because you think it is to enforce mediocrity. You said that to bring the top down is to make us all mediocre.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.
—That is what the Labor Party is always about: the equal sharing of things, dragging people back rather than letting the wealthy and the smart advance. That is what motivates you.
—You are sick.

—So do not get up here with an insipid look and crocodile tears in your eyes asking questions about people who are in genuine dire circumstances, because there is only one party in this Parliament with the structure in place to look after them until they find work, and that is the Labor Party. It is only the Labor Party. I regard it as one of our greatest achievements that, at a time when the prevailing wind from the northern hemisphere was blowing cool with the rationalist breeze from Washington and from London, we stood up in the 1980s and put together one of the finest social policies in the world.
—Order!

—We knitted together one of the finest social policies in the world, but we did it with the third lowest tax share to GDP ratio in the OECD. —Order! There is far too much noise. The honourable member for Mayo!

—Rubbish! You are a liar.
—The honourable member for Lowe will cease interjecting.

—when he wants to put 15 per cent on their food and clothing; when basically he wants to grind them into the dust. When you drop those heartless policies, maybe then and only then will we listen to you.

—Can the Treasurer inform the House whether taxation of the VAT or GST type has a markedly different impact on families than other major tax types? Was this part of the reason behind the Government's decision not to seek to introduce a VAT type tax in Australia?
