PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question asked for a matter of fact.
—What a surprise!
—Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Mitchell!
—Any party or any government contemplating a major change to the tax structure should be concerned about the impact that it would have on ordinary families and ordinary individuals in the community.

PARA.TAB: Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor!

—That would be the consideration that you would expect the Opposition to have undertaken when it decided to put forward its proposal. But what it has been doing is trying to maintain that it is only tourists, foreign tourists and smokers who will be worse off as a result of this great tax shift.

PARA.TAB: There are all kinds of different families in Australia: there are wealthy families, there are middle-income families and there are poorer families. If you do the analysis, as the Treasury did, on the effect of this great tax switch, you will find that some families do better under the proposals of the Opposition. They are the families whose income is over $90,000 a year. They are the ones who do better. They are the Liberal archetypal families. Those are the families which the Liberals care about: the ones who are in the $90,000-plus bracket. It may come as a surprise to the Leader of the Opposition and those behind him to hear that there are some other families in Australia. There are quite a lot of them—indeed, there are millions of them—who come in at much less than that.
Mr Sharp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—That is why one needs to look at the impact on those families of these kinds of tax shifts.

PARA.TAB: Dr Kemp interjecting—
Mr Snowdon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Goldstein! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

—What is the impact on a family of a tax which will raise the cost of building a house by nearly 4 per cent? What impact does that have on a couple trying to create and form a family? It will raise the cost of buying it by even more than that when you include the real estate agent's fees, the conveyancing costs, and so on. Then we come to the cost of just sustaining a family; for example, the cost of food. Bread and milk will be up by nearly 10 per cent; the cost of kids clothing will be up by 11 per cent—
—Not at 15 per cent.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor!
—the cost of a packet of cornflakes will be up by nearly 10 per cent; the cost of apples will be up by 10 per cent; and the cost of electricity to keep the family warm will be up by 11 per cent.

—Order!
—There are many other instances in which this kind of taxation shift would impact on the lives of ordinary families. The cost of swimming lessons for the kids will be up by 15 per cent.

—Order! There is far too much noise. The honourable member for Lowe, the honourable member for Mayo and the Minister for Resources!

—Whether the families are young or old, this kind of tax will impact on them all. The old families, in their retirement, trying to undertake their recreation, will again be taxed. —Why should average Australian families be expected to stand by and watch their lives and their country destroyed by you and your militant trade union mates who are only concerned to protect your own jobs and privileges and to whip up a scare campaign to try to get yourselves re-elected?

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. There is too much noise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That question could have been asked in 1962, it could have been asked in 1932, it could have been asked in 1912, and it could have been asked in 1892. It is the same sort of rubbish from the same sort of people. The notion of scare means that the things that the people of Victoria were demonstrating about yesterday are fictitious. The word `scare' implies that they are trying to say that something is happening which is not happening; that is, that they are referring to a condition which is a figment of their imagination or to which they are alluding for ulterior motives. The fact is that these things to which they object have become law. They have become law in the dead of night in the Victorian Parliament at the hands of a Government which did not have the courage to mention them in the election campaign, for which it has no mandate. The Liberal Party now knows that, despite the fact we had a total break-out of industrial peace in Victoria—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—to all intents and purposes the Victorian labour market is as peaceful as any of us could have remembered it, the national inflation figures are showing the national inflation rate under one per cent—

PARA.TAB: Mr Riggall interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for McMillan!

—and we are seeing a 2.6 per cent rise in national productivity, which is a huge increase. Why is the Victorian Government talking about legislating for criminal law against ordinary working people? Why have those people who are affected by the recession now become the villains in the piece? Why is it that holiday leave loadings and penalty rates have all of a sudden become the focus of the Liberal Party, and why does it or anyone else believe that this is the matter that will promote a Victorian recovery?
—You have bankrupted Victoria.
—The honourable member for Moore!
—In fact, the cooperative processes which have been going on between companies, industries and Victorian unionists and workers—
—They have killed Victoria.
—The honourable member for Lowe will cease interjecting.

—have seen business go from one productive plateau to another, rising from one to another, as these cooperative agreements go into place with the whole notion of cooperation. We see the captains of Victorian industry sitting down with their employees talking about how they can get contacts abroad; how they can do things at home; how they can be more productive—and all of this with the recovery growing in Victoria. It is now spiked by the Victorian Liberal Government with its vicious legislation without a mandate, and ordinary people march, as they have to. If they say, `We are not going to show any basis of objection', then it is going to be game, set and match for the thieves of the night in the Legislative Assembly who are pinching their conditions. Of course they are going to object, but to have ordinary people branded by those opposite as militants who are going to hold the place to ransom is to have the sort of talk that has come from the cosy conservatives over the years, the people looking for a bygone era in industrial relations when there were bosses on the top and workers on the bottom. That is all over. At the Best Practice awards, which I had the pleasure to present a couple of months ago—
—I thought you were going to—
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins!

—there was the chief executive officer and the chairman of major companies, and the employee representative, sitting at the table and proudly accepting the award together. That is the difference between us and you. The fact is that the Leader of the Opposition does not understand when ordinary people feel that they have been set upon unfairly and unreasonably without consultation and, worst of all, without any authority. I notice that the Leader of the Opposition said the other day at the Grand Prix ball in Adelaide:

ANSWER.PARA: It is wonderful. It is really nice to get out and mix with the real people, away from the politics of Canberra.
Other real people included the stars of tomorrow night's post-race concert. At over $300 per ticket, the entertainment was appropriately lavish.
So the Leader of the Opposition is falling out of an 18-footer on Sydney Harbour, bolting up the wheels on a $200,000 race car, playing grease monkeys or sitting on the sidelines—

TALK.START.PARA: —Personal abuse—shame!
—Order!

—in Adelaide or flouncing around the balls. Those are the ordinary people that the Leader of the Opposition understands. He thinks that the 150,000 who walked through Melbourne streets yesterday are militants who are going to bring the system down, when he knows that that action was perpetrated by his own principled friend, the Victorian Premier, in the Legislative Council in the dead of night.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.
—Those utterances are just the utterances of a rancid conservative—

PARA.TAB: Dr Kemp interjecting—

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can he provide the House with examples of the approach being taken by the Government to strengthen recovery and boost employment in Victoria?

—The Opposition Leader ought to be aware that this community understands exactly who was responsible for the strike activity in Victoria yesterday and for industrial unrest.

PARA.TAB: Dr Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Goldstein will cease interjecting.

—Those opposite can come into this place, meander around with an imagination founded in the 1960s and think that out there there is some applause for them. But people know them and they know exactly who is responsible, and exactly why—

PARA.TAB: Mr Connolly interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bradfield!

—you people have to be rejected. If you want any further evidence of it, you are getting cartoons like this one today in that well known radical journal the Brisbane Courier-Mail, with Jeff Kennett tiptoeing through the wreckage of 10 years of industrial harmony.

PARA.TAB: The tragedy of what is happening in Victoria is that many of the difficulties in Victoria are a direct product of the fact that that State more than most others has to go through a period of substantial structural adjustment in its industry. The reason it has to go through that, and has been going through that, is that over the years work practices have been built up and structures have been put in place in those industries which have made them uncompetitive.
Mr Costello interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.

—They have been going through that period of industrial adjustment through this last decade. Indeed, in one of the portfolios that I held, defence, I conducted very lengthy negotiations with John Halfpenny because we had reached a position in the Williamstown naval dockyard, for example, where the work force had to be adjusted downwards from some 2,300 people to 700. There was strike activity associated with that, but we went through that on the basis of discussion and agreement—
—You privatised it.
—Order! The honourable member for Bruce will cease interjecting.

—and we now produce frigates cheaper than does Germany as a result of that adjustment based on that cooperation. Great store has been set by employers and employees in Victoria on the notion of working through these issues and dealing with employment issues on a basis of cooperation, not confrontation—and it was working. Although Victoria's unemployment figures are high, if we look at the advertisements for skilled vacancies and the other areas that my Department assesses as indications of improvement in the labour markets, we see that for the last six months Victoria has been showing solid, substantial improvement.

PARA.TAB: All of that is now placed in jeopardy by what has been decided. Part of that cooperative process and part of what was producing those figures were things such as the jobs 92 program which mobilised the community behind employers and employees in local government. So far, as a result of that campaign and program based on cooperation between management and labour, 20,000 jobs have been created in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some adjustment! Ha, ha!
—Order!

—As far as reform in industrial practices is concerned I will go through the position in the Port of Melbourne Authority and on the Melbourne waterfront. There has been a 118 per cent improvement in terms of containers handled on the Melbourne waterfront—

PARA.TAB: Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.
—and, as I have had occasion to remark in this place before, container movement is now comparable with best practices in Europe, and even in some Asian ports.

PARA.TAB: I will take that a point further. All those changes have been produced. In 1988-89 there were 3,452 days lost. All those changes took place on the Melbourne waterfront with nil strikes, nil days lost, as a result of industrial disputation.
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—What was the position in Victoria back in 1982-83? Per thousand employees, 689 days were lost in work annually on average. That was under Fraser. This has fallen to 176 under us. It is the highest fall of any State. The best industrial changes, the best performance, with regard to days lost due to strikes, has been in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister talked about best practice. We have this record on best practice: 14 Victorian companies to date—
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—have been identified under the Government's best practice program. Again, that is a product of industrial cooperation between management and labour. We even had the situation which you used to wear around your own necks like a flag or badge of honour—the changes in SPC. If you want to see a frightened manager talking about a situation that he found himself confronting, I would suggest that you go and read over the transcripts of the ABC interviews with the manager of SPC yesterday. Even though his workers narrowly voted not to destroy the strike, he was saying, `Well, I don't know what is going to happen in the future, but I hope to God Jeff Kennett starts doing a bit of consultation around the place, because we don't think this is the way industrial relations ought to be done'.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Then we go to the areas of apprenticeships and traineeships. In Victoria, traineeship commencements were up 241 per cent in the September quarter. That is almost twice the rate of increase of any other State and almost three times the national average. The comparable figures for apprenticeships show a 66 per cent increase in Victoria; the third highest amongst the States.

PARA.TAB: One thing that has to be said about apprenticeships and traineeships is that their structure and capacity to develop very much depends on the effective functioning of the award system. The New Zealand experience dramatically shows, because there have been huge drops in apprenticeship commencements in New Zealand as a result of changes that have been put in place, that if you are going to get effective training in the work force and you go hell for leather knocking over awards, the first thing that is going to go, after salaries, is training.

One of the problems that these developments in industrial relations in Victoria have created was that there was an absolute determination in the media that they were going to see the Kirner Government out at the end of the year. There was that absolute determination right through this year. Unfortunately, that concealed an enormous improvement in performance in Victoria. That was a performance based on cooperative endeavour.

I have had many discussions with Victorian businessmen as well as Victorian trade unions. They all recognise that their State had to go through structural adjustment; it had to go through these massive changes. They wanted to do it on a basis of total decency. As far as they were concerned, the product of that cooperative attitude was being delivered. Dropped in amongst them is a maniac out of the nineteenth century, lying to the public—let us not mince words about it—about his industrial relations intentions; throwing a bomb into a problem that did not need fixing.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you over there support him.
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory.
—Do not think for one moment that that is not understood either by Victorians or around the rest of the country.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

I ask: is the Prime Minister seriously trying to suggest—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—that no one has a right to ask you questions about something as fundamental—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—as the heartbreaking fact that 680,000 Australian children are growing up in homes where neither parent has a job?

—Mr Speaker, you would think that if the Liberal Party and the National Party had a policy of promoting an economic recovery, of distributing national tax proceeds equitably, of not only maintaining but enhancing the equity and efficiency of the social security system, such a question could be asked, but not when they want to damn such important things as Medicare, basically break the social security system, put a 15 per cent tax on the food and clothing of the people—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Liar.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.

—whom the Leader of the National Party refers to—do all of these things—and tip people off unemployment benefits after nine months. How can you ask this question when those who are unemployed, through no fault of their own, you say after nine months will have to go to a voluntary agency?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—
Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. The House will come to order. The honourable member for Bennelong!
—Those opposite would turn people off unemployment benefits after nine months and tip them onto the support of the voluntary agencies. It is in this context that we see the question.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—If one looks at the benefits which are paid now to Australian families, one sees that they have shifted enormously under this Government by way of the family allowance supplement, by way of rent assistance, by way of the other benefits which we are giving to students under Austudy—all of the general structure of benefits which have been increased massively under this Government.
—We'll double the family allowance.

—Yes, but you are going to put a 15 per cent tax on families—a 15 per cent tax on their food and clothing, which will rob them of more than you ever seek to give them, which is why you are totally insincere when you talk about supporting low income people or people who are unemployed. At the same time, those opposite want to cut 2 per cent of GDP from the Budget. You would swear blind, Mr Speaker, too, with the haughtiness with which the question was asked, that the Liberal Party and the National Party were always the champions of employment. —Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.
—Today that work force is nearly eight million. The National Party is about—

—zero tariffs, as my colleague interjects from behind me. It is about a fiddle on petrol, about making people in the cities pay for a petrol cut.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—How he thinks this will help low to medium income families is beyond me. —We will see what is in the Bill and we will see how many other ordinary people's rights you try to snip off them while you get up here with crocodile tears asking questions about their best interests. I have said in the House before, and I will say it again—

PARA.TAB: Mr Broadbent interjecting—

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. In the light of unsubstantiated claims by the Leader of the Opposition that the education system in this country is `collapsing', will the Minister outline to the House the outstanding achievements in education by the Government over the last 10 years?
—I thank the honourable member for his question.

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have mercy on the House—

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—It has become part of the litany of the Leader of the Opposition. No longer do we have argument with him on the policies that he pursues; we have him standing up here making assertions. PARA.TAB: Dr Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —His solution for those kids who cannot get university places is to produce a charge on them, to compel them to pay $5,000, $6,000, $7,000—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition and the Prime Minister will cease interjecting.

—I also heard the Opposition spokesman on education say today that what we had to achieve was international best practice. It has to be said that the education system can always be improved. There is no question about that. It always ought to be under constant review. So it is with us.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, it is our education system which gives us one of our most important competitive advantages as a nation. We have a good education system that can be made better. We do not have an education system in a state of collapse, and there is nothing, except the silly anecdotal stuff that he was on with today, for example that, basically, our education system is in collapse because kids cannot do trivial pursuit games effectively enough. That was his position.

Let us deal with statistics, instead of anecdotes. This is what you get: the level of educational attainment of Australians aged 25- to 64-years is ranked at one of the highest in the OECD countries. Australia's rate of upper secondary completion was around average, while Australia is ranked fifth out of 20 countries in terms of the ratio of higher education graduates to population of the theoretical graduation age.

In Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the United States, more than 30 per cent of the population has attained some tertiary education, whereas the figure is less than 10 per cent in some OECD countries. We are in the top four. When it comes down to participation in formal education, expressed as a ratio of persons aged 2- to 29-years, Australia is exactly on the half percentile of OECD countries. We are up there still amongst the best. Of the 21 countries contributing data on participation in upper secondary education, upper secondary education enrolment is 90 per cent or higher in 11 countries, including Australia at 91.5 per cent.
Dr Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for Goldstein interjects again, I will deal with him.

—I move on to questions of attainment. The Opposition spokesman said today that the Government boasts of improvement in participation, but that they have been going up for decades. I have news for you, sport! They went up 2 per cent when you were in office, from the beginning to the end. They have virtually doubled under us. Those are the statistics, not your anecdotes.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member wants to see evidence via the processes in which he delights, that is, anecdotal in terms of actual performance—in other words, not only who is in the system, but what the system is producing—I will match my anecdotes with his trivial pursuit questions any day of the week. Here are a few of them.

In recent years Australian teams have been bringing home larger and larger swags of gold and silver medals from the international academic olympiads. In the physics olympiad this year, we won our first ever silver medal and were ranked tenth out of 42 competing nations. In chemistry we won our first gold medal this year and we were ranked in the top 10 per cent. In mathematics, the largest olympiad, we won a gold, a silver and two bronzes and were ranked nineteenth in the world.

We ought to be proud of these attainments of our kids. The fact that we have an education system that is producing in this way is a matter of some pride to us. It is not laurels which we rest on. Since we have been in office we have devoted increasing resources to language and literacy, improving the capacity of our young people to emerge from the system literate. We do it on a cooperative basis with the States.

We have been getting in place a structure for a national curriculum, and that has been done again on a cooperative basis with the States. We have reached agreement on national education objectives. We are getting to the point, which is so important to parents in this country, where people can shift through the Australian education system—again on a basis of negotiating with the States—and end up more or less at the same level in each particular State. Those are the positions that we are adopting.

The Opposition proposes to cut education expenditure effectively via the cuts to the States and to charge university fees as a means of answering a level of demand of young people to get into universities. It also proposes to take back from the State systems the $720m which we are giving them to improve TAFE and turn it into a voucher program for kids who go out and negotiate their one-off contracts with business around the place, as though a kid would be in a position to know what to do with it.

The Opposition then says, but without saying how it will do it, that it will impose national standards. I can just picture you, if you ever get into office, turning up in New South Wales, meeting Virginia Chadwick and saying to her, `Well, Virginia, have I got a deal for you. With my Commonwealth Education Department I am going to impose a national standard on the New South Wales education system'. I have had one or two dealings with Virginia Chadwick and I know what would happen: she would take a bit of a look at you, reach into her bag and take out a little piece of garlic, wave it in front of you and drive a stake through your heart. She knows when she is dealing with the living dead, and she knows exactly what to do about it when she confronts it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

—Yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) referred to my campaign. I am delighted that the Government is so interested in my campaign. Today the Minister for Tourism (Mr Griffiths) also referred to it.

—the GST, a point on which I corrected the Prime Minister. The Minister for Tourism obviously was not in the House yesterday, because today he claimed that none of my literature mentioned the GST.

—I point out to the Minister for Tourism that of about a dozen pamphlets, on a rough count, eight of them directly mention the GST.

—No, the ones in the letterbox.

—that in the last couple of months I have had 14 meetings in my electorate, all of which have been on the GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for Maranoa continues to interject, I will deal with him.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The Government's total incompetence in delivering reform and appropriate economic management, epitomised by the failure of the One Nation statement.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder that the Minister for Tourism (Mr Griffiths) and the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) are so sensitive today, as their One Nation statement fails them, as their policies continue to fail them and their electorates, and as members of the tourist industry vote with their feet in favour of Fightback and a GST.

PARA.TAB: I want to give details to the House of a snap radio poll taken in Cairns this morning on 4CA, an independent station which covers, in part, some of the area in the electorate of Leichhardt and a little of the electorate of Kennedy. I am happy to tell the House that the poll on the award winning show conducted by John MacKenzie, who has won many awards and, as far as I am aware, does not have any particular political bias, resulted in the following outcome: those in favour of GST and Fightback, 331; those against, 220. The total number of respondents was 551. Quite a sizeable number for Far North Queensland!

The truth of the matter is that the honourable member for Kennedy knows that he is a oncer; the honourable member for Kennedy knows that he has lost in every sector of his electorate; the honourable member for Kennedy knows that just two months ago in Mareeba there were 4,000 people demonstrating against the Labor Party in respect of tobacco issues. In his own electorate, some 4,000 people turned up to demonstrate and protest against the Labor Party, particularly the Labor Premier Wayne Goss and the State Labor Party tobacco tax. They also paid out on the Federal Government.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I wonder when the Leader of the National Party will get to the topic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!
—Order! The Leader of the National Party should address the topic.

—Under the Standing Orders, the MPI is particularly carefully worded. It refers to the One Nation statement and to the total incompetence of this Government. As such, the honourable member for Kennedy and the Minister for Tourism are incompetent components of this Government.

PARA.TAB: I might add that the United States President-elect, Bill Clinton, in winning a massive mandate for change last week, said a number of things on the day after the election, and one statement I think is particularly salient, relevant and sensible.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said, `I am glad we have got rid of those conservatives'. That is what he said.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The Minister!

TALK.START.PARA: —He said, `There is only one President of the United States of America'. I want to say, likewise, in the terms of the Australian context, that there is only one Prime Minister of Australia, and he must accept responsibility for the recession we had to have. He must accept responsibility for the record unemployment, the million people without jobs right around Australia; he must accept responsibility for the record levels of net foreign debt gripping Australia now and gripping Australia in terms of future generations; he must accept responsibility for the record farm failures right across so many parts of Australia, particularly the drought affected areas, but far beyond those areas. In particular, the Prime Minister must accept responsibility for producing this shabby One Nation statement and then, in the nine months since that time, proceeding to do everything to divide Australia, to divide the cohesion and fabric of our society, particularly in the way he has attacked our great Australian national flag; in the way he has attacked our constitutional monarchy; and, more recently, the way he has attacked one half of the Federal Parliament, namely, the institution of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: When the Prime Minister loses the forthcoming Federal election, he will look back on 1992 for those key turning points, and he will pick out a couple of particular days when he blew it and in fact paved the way for the change of government that is coming here in Australia—whether this Government likes it or not. I refer in particular to the day when the Prime Minister said, `This is the recession we had to have'. I refer the Prime Minister to his further statement that `the recession ended long ago'. I refer him to his statement, `I saved Australia', and I refer him to his unforgivable statement that `the Senate is unelected unrepresented swill', and that `they are all pansies'.

In that context, I say to the House that the Senate is part of the governance of Australia; it is very much an important part of the constitutional circumstance of Australia. I warn the Prime Minister that, at this time of great economic agony, if he continues to pursue this agenda of a republic of Australia, and continues to pursue the denigration of the Senate, then he will set alight those forces of division and separation, particularly in some of the smaller States. For every day that he remains in office he has a responsibility to try to get this country back on the rails.

But the truth of the matter is that we have never ever had a Prime Minister so negative in attitude of mind and in activity than the Prime Minister that we have today. I say further to the House that he is going to pay a price for that negative attitude, with not one positive idea beyond the shabby document, One Nation, that he presented. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) will support me in this matter of public importance and will deal with aspects particularly in relation to a lack of road funding. But let me quote to the House from One Nation which, in a sense, says it all when we judge and assess its performance. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: This statement is very much about making this nation strong . . . A nation in which our rail, road, sea and air services serve us better and bind us together as a federation—as one nation.

Amen to that! Let us examine that statement. The honourable member for Wannon will deal with roads because we have had the extraordinary situation where the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) has had to revoke allocations to the States. Today, as we speak, and as the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) points out, the Port of Melbourne is closed at the behest of the Prime Minister, at the behest of Halfpenny, at the behest of Curran, and at the behest of Kirner. Some progress! The cost, for example, of moving newsprint across a wharf in New Zealand is $4 a tonne. Moving it across a wharf in Melbourne, when it is not strikebound, it is $24 a tonne. Some reform? I think not. Some reform in terms of actual cost delivery? There is none.

PARA.TAB: There is also the issue of air. We now have the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) and other senior Ministers, including the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), even refusing to condemn the prospect of an inevitable Christmas airlines strike across Australia which will flow from the conduct of the Prime Minister, the ACTU and John Halfpenny. It is unforgivable that the Prime Minister will not adopt the mantle of leadership to get this country back on the rails.

The One Nation statement states that the Government will revamp and revitalise our rail system. What a sad and sorry story we have in relation to railways, nine months later. The centrepiece of that development, the National Rail Corporation, is still not fully operational. Sure, it has been set up. It produces glossy reports. It has yet to run a train in its own name. It has yet to issue its shareholdings. The legislation is still before the Western Australian Parliament. The first part of a debate took place early in September. The Western Australian Government subsequently adjourned that debate. Maybe later today or in the near future it will bring that debate on again to allow for the passage of the National Rail Corporation legislation.

The truth of the matter is that this Government has failed in terms of delivering that legislation in accordance with the timetable to make the NRC operational. It has also failed in terms of developing the agreement with the trade unions to provide for the productivity and enterprise arrangements which were promised in relation to rail redevelopment. I highlight to the House that, whilst a memorandum of understanding was signed, very little additional progress has been made with the necessary union and industrial relations changes, which are so necessary to get rail to meet its performance criteria and to match world best practice. If we examined the detail of rail, we would find that Australia is a long way behind best world rail practice, and the situation is drifting further and further.

Some $400m was promised by this Government as part of the One Nation statement for the physical upgrading of rail in Australia. Guess how much of that has been spent? It is an amount a good deal less than 2 per cent. In terms of kilometres constructed, the whole thing is at zero. With a Labor Government in Victoria and a Federal Labor Government, for some seven months they still were not able to settle the standardisation of the rail route between Adelaide and Melbourne.

The Government has still been unable to settle the arrangements associated with upgrading and providing additional railway line between Campbelltown and the freight depots in Sydney. It still has not been able to issue the tenders for the key link line between Acacia Ridge at the northern end of the standard gauge in Brisbane and Fishermans Island and the Brisbane port. It would now appear that the tenders for that work will not be released until next year.In other words, the whole program of rail upgrading promised in the One Nation statement has ceased. It has not even commenced. It has dragged along at a rate which is a disgrace. It shows that this Government cannot deliver on its promise and cannot match its rhetoric.

I think it is timely to look at the number of statements that we have had in the last two years addressing the economic circumstances of Australia, remembering that this Government led Australia into recession ahead of the rest of the world, provided the framework, basis and lack of confidence to ensure that we had a recession worse than most of the world, and is now wrecking the prospect of recovery by the approach of, particularly, the Prime Minister who is, above all else, a political animal first and an Australian citizen second. It gives me no joy to give that description to our Prime Minister, but that is the truth of the matter.

I remind the House of the industry statement of March 1991. Honourable members might recall it. I am sure it is in the back of their memories. Do honourable members remember the industry statement of March 1991 when then Prime Minister Bob Hawke was going to bounce us out of recession? Then we had the Budget by that famous former Treasurer of the Labor Party, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin)—his famous first and last Budget, which did so much damage to the economic circumstances of Australia.

Then in November 1991 we had another statement, that last ditch statement by the then Prime Minister. Do honourable members remember what that was called? It was called the jobs statement. Thousands of Australians have lost their jobs since the November 1991 statement produced by the then Prime Minister in a last ditch effort to hold off the now Prime Minister. Of course, that failed too.

More recently, in February of this year we had the One Nation statement and an income tax cut schedule which is not able to be delivered, which is a pipedream and which, of course, does not alter the threshold level one dollar. As such, it is stacked against the spouses, the part time work force and the retirees in a very cruel way.

We, the coalition, have the fair dinkum approach for looking after the retirees of this country. We are increasing the threshold level from $5,400 to $7,000 and we are adopting a number of other initiatives, including an 8 per cent increase in age pensions and service pensions to provide a fair go, a fair circumstance, whereas One Nation has failed this country lock, stock and barrel.

Finally, I draw the attention of the House to the youth unemployment statement of July 1992. That was another failure. Nothing has been produced in fundamental terms as a result of that youth summit. More recently there was the August 1992 Dawkins Budget, with a hidden taxation agenda. We forced the Government to go back and do its homework and produce more definitive statements on that Budget, which was to set the parameters for recovery, but sadly that recovery eludes thousands of Australians trying to get a job.
We have seen all these statements. Labor has had its chance. Labor has had 10 years to get it right. This Prime Minister has had one

SPEECH.PARA: year to get it right, after his years of treasuryship in wrecking Australia. The sooner the Government brings on this election, so that we can get a real alternative and a vote for a change rather than more of the same, the better for all our sakes, and the better chance we will have of creating the real jobs necessary to get this country back on the road again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard the usual diatribe from those opposite. They do not take into account the consequences that their policy mix would have in addressing the problems this country currently faces. The Opposition's contribution always has an overwhelming emphasis on the negatives. I would like to point out a few positives that the Government has been able to achieve in recent years which put a different light on the claim that this Government has been completely ineffective in putting through major reforms.

PARA.TAB: When this Government came to office it had a tax system which, in the words of Professor Russell Mathews, one of Australia's leading taxation authorities, was such that the decision to pay tax was essentially optional for wealthy people. It was so full of holes and so riven with potential loopholes that it really was a matter as to whether they chose to pay tax or not. That tax system has been comprehensively overhauled with the introduction of the capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and a range of other measures. So we now have an income tax system which operates in some sort of worthwhile fashion. The Opposition neglected that system for years.

The Government has achieved major changes in its industry structure. Let us look at the composition of our manufacturing sector. A decade ago 13 per cent of our manufacturing production was exported. That percentage is now up to 22 per cent. Three-quarters of our basic metal products are now exported; textiles, 54 per cent; and processed food, 24 per cent; et cetera. There has been a major change. In the last few years we have had a rate of increase in elaborately transformed manufactures in the exports from this country which has been one of the highest rate of increases, if not the highest, in the OECD area.

Likewise, if we look at the whole area of research and development and go back to when this Government came to office, we see that we had an absolutely pathetic performance in investment in research and development in the private sector. There has been a virtual doubling since then of the proportion of research and development expenditure by the private sector as a proportion of GDP. In recent years we have had one of the most rapid increases in private investment in research and development in the OECD area.

The sorts of underlying structural changes that we need are taking place. We have also seen substantial micro-economic reform in a range of areas that those opposite have always mouthed slogans about, but when they were in office they did very little. In the case of the waterfront, productivity has more than doubled and turnaround times have been reduced by 34 per cent. Our ports are now internationally competitive. We have seen reform in telecommunications and aviation—I will not attempt to enumerate all the areas.

These changes have been achieved in the context of relative industrial peace. We are now looking at a major revamp of our industrial relations framework with a move towards enterprise bargaining, but that is being done in the context of consensus and cooperation with the trade union movement—a total contrast with the sort of confrontational policies that we have seen implemented by the Kennett Government in Victoria and which provide a stark prefiguration of the sorts of effects we could see from the implementation of the coalition's industrial relations agenda at the national level.

I will now address myself to the One Nation statement, because that is the main topic of this MPI today. In the One Nation statement the Government sought to do a number of things. Firstly, it sought to provide a significant fiscal boost which will be of the order of $1.8 billion this year. Effectively the Opposition is saying that it wants to cut the Budget deficit by $7 billion, which will have the effect of reducing employment by about 125,000. Bankers Trust Managing Director, Mr Ferguson, was quoted yesterday as saying:

Cutting deficits . . . would force down profitability in the private sector and it's already low, it will force people to shed labour and that's shedding consumers as well, and it will be a self-defeating process in the short term.

SPEECH.PARA: So, right smack in the middle of a recession, what does the Opposition say? It wants to tighten fiscal policy very substantially. That will only darken significantly the prospects for economic recovery.

PARA.TAB: I might also refer to the OECD economic policy committee, which said that it would be sensible for countries in our sort of position to relax fiscal policy to some extent to counter what it called the relatively weak and uncertain prospects for economic growth, current economic difficulties shared by the Western world as a whole. In fact, Australian growth, which is projected at 3 per cent in 1992-93, will be significantly above the OECD average, which is projected at 1 1/2 per cent in 1992 and 2.1 per cent in 1993.

Australia is well placed to deliver a fiscal boost. If we look at the state of our public finances, it can be seen that we have one of the lowest levels of public debt to GDP ratio amongst developed countries. This fiscal boost has taken the form of a targeted set of measures designed to improve long term competitiveness, and that includes major investments in physical infrastructure, particularly road and rail. This was opposed by the Opposition, which failed to recognise the central importance of physical infrastructure in improving economic productivity.

We had that rather silly contribution from the Leader of the National Party, who talked about the fact that, because we have not already spent all that money, the whole program is a failure. The reality is that with very major infrastructure programs of the sort that are being implemented, as outlined in the One Nation statement, a fairly substantial planning process has to be gone through. That is the reality, and to suggest otherwise—that we should just rush in and suddenly pour out buckets of money without going through a proper evaluation and planning process—is to put a ludicrous proposition.

Another element in the One Nation statement is a major boost to investment in education and training. Michael Porter, one of the world's leading experts in the whole area of the economic competitiveness of countries, has made the point that the education and training sector is one of the key points of leverage for government in improving international competitiveness and fostering industry restructuring. We have seen a major attempt to address the problems of particularly the vocational education and training sector, which complements the major expansion in the higher education system, the very large increase in participation, and the roughly one-third real increase in expenditure since the higher education White Paper. Again, these are crucial decisions.

The Opposition has tried to jump on the bandwagon with some of those. On the one hand, it says it will match our spending on education and training; on the other hand, if we look at the fine print in terms of what it is taking away, by means of very substantial cuts in labour market programs, for example—which largely parallel the purpose of the Opposition's training vouchers—we see that, far from boosting education and training expenditure, the Opposition is committed to a substantial fall in those areas.

In all those areas which are addressed in the One Nation statement—crucially important areas, which are entirely appropriate in current economic circumstances—the Opposition's position of opposition to those highly constructive measures ought to be seen as quite destructive of this country's economic potential. The One Nation statement also involved a number of proposals, particularly an improved tax regime to encourage the private sector to accelerate and bring forward investment—things such as the development allowance, the improved depreciation structure and so forth. These are measures which will all bring about significant benefits to this nation.

Since the One Nation statement, we have seen additional substantial commitments by the Government through the national education and training plan for young Australians. An additional $770m will be provided over three years, which is a very significant response to the education and training needs of young people. By the end of this decade we aim to make participation in education and training virtually universal for young people leaving school. The local capital works program and increased spending on labour market programs are crucial to the prevention of the entrenchment of a large body of long term unemployed people in our economy.

These programs have been the subject recently of some pretty comprehensive and thorough studies by international experts. There is no doubt that they have a crucial role to play in avoiding a situation where a large proportion of our labour force becomes permanently alienated from the world of work, the sort of situation that occurs in some European countries where three generations are unemployed—grandparents, parents and children.

We all know that throughout the Western world at the moment most developed countries are experiencing severe economic difficulties, the Anglo-Saxon world in particular. The United States, Britain, Canada, New Zealand and Australia are all experiencing severe problems. No honest person could possibly argue that, irrespective of what government was in office at the moment, we would not be experiencing a very difficult economic situation. I do not think anybody could seriously contest that. The governments I have just referred to are right across the political spectrum.

The relevant question to ask is whether the policy mix proposed by the Opposition would improve or darken our prospects. Let us look at the sort of mix that the Opposition is talking about—the introduction of the GST and the sorts of changes to the industrial relations framework—and what the macro-economic effect of that would be, what it would do to gross domestic product growth, to unemployment and inflation. The fact is that there is pretty much a consensus amongst economists at the moment that, for the next five to 10 years, those policies would have a detrimental effect on all of those variables.

The Sydney Morning Herald recently did a survey of economists in both the public and private sector. A clear consensus of those economists was that Fightback would mean lower, slower growth, higher unemployment, higher inflation and higher interest rates. If the margin is averaged out by which they say coalition policies would increase unemployment, it averages out at a figure of 1.6 per cent—that is 1.6 per cent higher unemployment than under the Government's policy mix. That represents 140,000 more unemployed people. Obviously that sort of policy will darken our economic prospects. The Opposition's own economic modelling confirms that.

It also shows a variety of possible outcomes—they are all bad. If we assume that the Opposition is unable to contain the inflationary impact of the GST on wages, then that is the worst case scenario and that will produce substantial falls in GDP growth and a significantly worse unemployment outcome. The reality is that the Opposition, through its industrial relations policy, has no framework with which it could hope to contain the inflationary impact of the GST on wages. On the balance of probabilities, we would have to say that the outcome would be at the worst end of the projections by these various economists.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has essentially admitted to these problems. He is quoted as saying: `I am not making promises about the level of unemployment. There will be transition effects'—transition effects indeed. What that would do is take an economy which is obviously encountering difficulties and coming out of recession, but slowly at the moment, and drive that economy into a hole. We would see the macro-economic impact of the GST on growth, employment and inflation. On top of that, we would see—for a period, undoubtedly—a state of industrial relations chaos. We would have an industrial relations system which would be incapable of insulating inflation from the effects of the GST on the price level. If we were to take the Opposition seriously, we would see a $7 billion cut in the deficit—a major contraction of fiscal policy. The effect of all that on this country's economic fortunes and, I believe, the social stability of the country to implement a range of policies of that kind, would obviously be catastrophic.

It is interesting that the Opposition tries to imply that our current economic difficulties are entirely a consequence of bad government policy. This is the thrust of what it has had to say. Let us examine this proposition. If the Government is to be criticised for getting anything wrong in a policy sense, it might be argued that we held back too long in terms of the relaxation of monetary policy that took place, starting in 1990. It could be said that that should have been done earlier and that we underestimated the impact of the tightening of monetary policy. What was the Opposition saying at this time? On every occasion the Government moved to relax monetary policy, it was subject to attack by the Leader of the Opposition. He accused us of politicising the Reserve Bank. He attacked every move to relax monetary policy from the middle of 1990 on.

If the Opposition is going to say that our current economic problems are a consequence of policy errors by the Government, then how much more severe would those problems have been had we followed the policy prescriptions of the Leader of the Opposition at the time? We would obviously be in a far worse situation than we are now. If the Opposition's Fightback package were to be implemented, there is not the slightest doubt that we would see the economy of this country driven into a hole and the creation of economic and social problems of a magnitude that I do not believe we have seen before in the history of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this matter of public importance, namely:

PARA.TAB: The Government's total incompetence in delivering reform and appropriate economic management, epitomised by the failure of the One Nation statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I endorse the words of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer). He made an excellent speech. Listening to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) reminded me of a book I saw in a bookshop somewhere entitled How to lie with statistics.

PARA.TAB: Last week we had a visitor to this gallery. He came to watch the proceedings of the chamber, particularly the shambles of Question Time. He walked out and said, `I think I have just seen a government in decay'. I think that really sums up this Government—it is a government in decay. We are now seeing what this Government has inflicted on all Australians.

What better way to illustrate it than the tragedy of the one million unemployed. Since the last election—I remind honourable members that this is only since the last election—the number of people unemployed has nearly doubled. Yet whenever the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is asked a question such as the one he was asked today, he continues to skirt around it and avoid it. As the Leader of the National Party put it so succinctly, it comes down to a failure to lead.

What has been the response of the Government? Basically it has been one of panic. The February One Nation statement was the sixth economic statement in the term of this Parliament; the Budget was the seventh. As well we have had three other statements, as my colleague the Leader of the National Party pointed out. The February statement was clearly very ill-thought out. Listening to the pathetic excuses from the Minister as to why it has not been implemented struck me as a rather direct backhander to his own Leader for his failure to deliver.

We are seeing a boost in public debt. Public debt is ballooning because the panic is spreading. Debt has increased by so much that the interest paid by the public purse in the coming year will increase by a massive 26 per cent and in the year after it by 36 per cent. Then we will see what the total incompetence of this Government has been all about.

Ballooning foreign debt and the current account deficit have become a constant source of embarrassment. Bankruptcies are at a record high. I have already mentioned the problems of unemployment. More recently we have seen the cover-up in the Victorian loans affair. All of this is clear evidence of a government in crisis and of a government so moribund and incompetent that it has had to keep changing its mind. If the decisions made affected only the Government, it would not be so serious, but they are having a serious effect on every Australian.

These policy failures have led to the worst recession in 60 years. We saw the problems which were created by interest rates in 1989-90, which led the Prime Minister to the excuse that `this is the recession we had to have anyway'. It all leads to the very serious problem of lack of confidence throughout Australia. Is it little wonder that there is such a lack of confidence in the community? Who would want to invest in the current climate?

After all, interest rates shot up to 25 per cent in the late 1980s and no-one doubts the capacity of this Government to do it again if it reaches another point of panic and sees another one of its failures. Without that investment the unemployment rate will remain tragically high. Contrary to what the Minister said, education on its own will not solve that problem.

In the September quarter we saw 43,900 people lose their jobs, and tomorrow's figures do not look all that optimistic either. One million people—nearly 11 per cent of our work force—are out of work; many of them as a result of the incompetence of this Government. I do not believe that anyone should stand by and accept the current levels of unemployment. The question must be asked: how can the Government miscalculate it so often? In his One Nation speech, the Prime Minister made this great statement. He said that he pledged to fight the battle against unemployment—which of course he largely created—and for economic recovery with all the energy he could muster. He went on to say, `Tonight we turn these words into action'. That was some action. The only job that he seemed to be trying to preserve was his own. He created unemployment in the first place and then he tried to promise to undo the problem. In fact, what has happened? There has been nothing short of a string of failures. After all, the One Nation statement was supposed to be about creating employment.

Let us look at some of those reform failures. Let us look at the area of land transport in which I have a direct interest. Nearly a billion dollars was allocated to road and rail projects, but hardly any of these projects have come to fruition and most are unlikely to until late next year. The primary focus was supposed to be on land transport infrastructure. There were supposed to be 21,000 jobs created in two years—15,000 from road and 6,000 from rail.

It is worth remembering that the money which was included for roads came from a very low base. It was supposed to create 50,000 jobs in one year. We have the situation with One Nation where there are only 13 months to go; and with the Budget there are only seven months to go. Yet very little money has been spent and very few jobs have been created.

My colleague has already mentioned some of the problems and failures associated with investment in rail. Rail spending was supposed to create 4,000 jobs in 1992-93, but less than $8m of the $454m that was supposed to have been spent has been spent so far, and we are nearly halfway through the financial year. There is little prospect of this in the short term because no project manager has been appointed, let alone any building contractors. It will be months before anything is likely to happen.

Back in February, the Prime Minister said that he would create jobs. The National Rail Corporation is in a marvellous position. It has not one, but three, headquarters but it does not have a train. One of those headquarters is on the forty-fourth floor of the Rialto building in Melbourne. It is hardly what one would call a frugal way to start a business. We have these three headquarters staffed by some people on very high salaries, but there are no trains. It is just like the Yes, Minister series. Do honourable members remember that episode when we had the hospital with everyone working there but no patients? It has a familiar ring.

The question has to be asked: how many jobs have been created? At the same time, we have a situation where some of the railways have been discarding jobs—including the Commonwealth's own railway, Australian National, where jobs have been cut. The question has to be asked: how many millions of dollars has this exercise cost and how little has the true gain been? We must also ask: when is the Prime Minister going to tell the Australian people why he has failed so miserably?

Let us look at the question of roads. There were supposed to be 15,000 jobs created in this area. How many have been created so far? Less than half the funds that were supposed to be allocated in the first quarter of this financial year have been spent. The Minister has suspended the payments. When honourable members look at the facts they will find that much of the cause of this delay has been the Government's own tardiness in approving projects. It has nothing to do with the States; it is the Government's own tardiness.

I come back to my point about incompetence in delivering reform. We should look at the question of physical problems. The Minister may say that it is not his fault that we have had a fairly wet winter and spring in some parts of Australia, but the point is that he was incompetent enough not to realise that when it comes to road building one has to take seasonal factors into account. Winter is not the most economical time to build a road, so why expect it to built. Even when it comes to spending the money—even when it has been allocated—the Government cannot get it right.

I think whatever way we look at it, we are seeing the total incompetence of this Government and we are seeing the impact that that is having on the confidence of Australians. We are seeing the fact that, contrary to what the Minister said a minute ago, the unemployment problem will not be solved because we are not coming out of the recession and the Government is not tackling the real problem. It is a very serious matter. This Government has failed to deliver reform. Its economic management is anything but appropriate and the One Nation statement is just a symptom of its incompetence.

The recession clearly continues, the debt climbs, and unemployment continues to affect virtually every Australian. In short, Labor has betrayed all Australians. While the Government may think what it is doing is good politics, it sure as hell is not good government. The Government and the media, which supports this politicking, should hang their heads in shame. I believe that Australia deserves better.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), made a freudian slip during his contribution to the discussion of the matter of public importance this afternoon. He made the comment that no government or Opposition should stand by when there is this level of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: It is this Labor Government which, through One Nation, has sought to make sure that we do not just stand by. But which party in this House has opposed every measure that we have put forward in this Parliament to try to boost recovery and create jobs? Who opposed our measures on rail? The Liberal Party. Who opposed our plans to spend more money on roads in order to create jobs? The Liberal Party. Who opposed our reforms on aviation, the national electricity grid, and a national TAFE scheme? Every step of the way, when the Government has tried to boost recovery and create jobs, the Liberal-National Party coalition has sought to oppose, frustrate and stop the measures which this Government has brought into the Parliament.

It is a bit rich for the honourable member for Wannon to get up in the House in February and March and say that his side of politics is opposed to any extra spending on roads and rail and then come into the House and thrash us with a feather, saying that we have not spent the money quickly enough. His side of politics said that we should not have allocated one dollar or one cent, and then Opposition members come in here and say that there have been difficulties and it is terrible that the Government has not spent the money quickly enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're like a tomcat.

—As the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who is at the table, says, they are like tomcats. They have more hide than an elephant at Taronga Park Zoo. What was the reason behind One Nation? The Government believed that the Australian economy needed an injection of about $2.3 billion and a whole series of measures to try to create construction and capital works projects which would provide an impetus to the Australian economy. It would result in extra money circulating in the economy and in that way create jobs not just in the sectors which received money, but in other areas due to the flow-on throughout the economy.

PARA.TAB: Where did we allocate this extra money first? We allocated it to rail. This Labor Government established the National Rail Corporation. Our side of politics insisted that we introduce international best practice. It was this Labor Government which insisted that there be a union agreement which provided a greenfields site and ensured that work practices in the Australian rail system improved. Throughout all its years in government—during the Menzies years, then Holt and of course Billy McMahon and Fraser—the Liberal Party made no effort to improve the efficiency of the Australian rail network.

It was this Prime Minister (Paul Keating) who decided it was time that we had the national grid. He decided it was time that we allocated the money needed to ensure that we could have a rail freight highway in order to get freight off the roads and back onto rail where it belonged and it was time that we had an efficient and competitive rail network. What was the Opposition's response to that? It said, `This is a mistake. The Government should not be allocating all of this extra money'. The Government has committed $300m to the National Rail Corporation. In One Nation we provided a commitment of another $450m over two years and $150m will be spent this year.

That is the colour of our money. That is the commitment which this side of politics has to the rail system to ensure that we have an efficient, competitive rail network. The Opposition believes that we should be back in the dark ages where there would be six State rail networks. The honourable member for Wannon criticises us because the National Rail Corporation has not got trains yet. It is just ridiculous. The honourable member for Wannon is running around saying that we should not have this National Rail Corporation, that it is wrong that it has a head office in Melbourne.
Honourable members interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Honourable members at the table should not be intervening in the debate. The honourable member for Bruce should resume his seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his own electorate.
—The Minister should not provoke activity across the chamber. The honourable member for Dobell has the call.

—If it were not for the Government pushing hard with the National Rail Corporation, we would be stuck with the six separate State rail networks that we had when they were in government. Rail is the first test. The Government is providing the funds. The Government is ensuring that we get an integrated national rail network. Who opposed that? The Liberal and National parties.

PARA.TAB: I turn to road funding. In 1992-93 the Government is providing a record amount of money for road construction—$2.1 billion. In One Nation, an additional $600m was provided, and it is my understanding that $600m will be spent. So much for the criticisms of the Opposition. The honourable member for Wannon says that hardly any of it will come to fruition this year. Perhaps the honourable member for Wannon has not driven through a few of the electorates of some of his colleagues on ring road 33 from Hornsby down through Pennant Hills. He should have a look at the work that is being done in the electorates of some of his colleagues. It is work funded by One Nation. In his own electorate I bet funds are being spent because of One Nation. Look at the high level Glebe Island bridge. The Liberal State Government of New South Wales could not afford to build it. It was only through One Nation that the funding was provided and the work is going on today.

How can the honourable member for Wannon say that there are no results from all this money flowing into the economy? Even the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) is out there trying to get a few brownie points from the work that the Federal Government is arranging in his own electorate, because ring road 33 did not get too far under his side of politics. But we have ensured that there is proper road infrastructure in Sydney and other capital cities. Every time we have spent a dollar, who has opposed it? The Liberal and National parties. So it not just in rail; it is in road. It is also in aviation.

In One Nation we made a few promises. We said that there would be a trans-Tasman market for aviation. What do we have? We have a trans-Tasman market for aviation in only six months. We said that Qantas would fly domestic. On 1 November what happened? Qantas began flying domestic passengers. People in the gallery have probably already seen the discount offers advertised by Qantas. There has been a saving for Australian tourists, Australian domestic air travellers, as a result of the initiatives in One Nation. In addition, very shortly we will have Ansett flying internationally and, as a result, a more competitive environment and lower air fares for the Australian travelling public.

In electricity, we have had the Government establish the concept of a national electricity grid. We have the National Grid Management Council about to bring down its report on pricing mechanisms. There has been a round table to ensure that there is a strategy for separating the transmission of electricity from the generation of electricity. Power stations will compete with each other so that domestic electricity consumers will get cheaper prices and industrial electricity consumers will get cheaper prices. That will mean that there is to be more capacity for industries to create jobs and investment, and that is good for the Australian economy.

What is the alternative offered by the Opposition? Not only does it criticise every measure that we bring in here to give the economy a boost and create jobs, but also its solution to Australia's recession is to impose a new 15 per cent consumption tax on every good and service traded in Australia. It is saying that there should be a new 15 per cent consumption tax on food, clothing, services, telephone bills, electricity bills and water and sewerage rates. It says that there should be zero tariffs; we should wipe out the Australian car industry. The $1.2 billion of exports that the motor vehicle industry earns every year for Australia would be placed in jeopardy by its zero tariff policy. The Australian car industry and the components manufacturers have made it clear which side of politics is going wipe out the 50,000 jobs in the Australian car industry. It is the Liberal and National parties that are proposing a zero tariff regime that will wipe out employment in that industry.

In Question Time today we had the Opposition's plans for tourism mentioned again. It is very clear that the Opposition's policy will do severe damage to the Australian tourism industry by affecting domestic and international tourists. When members of the public in the gallery choose between a holiday in Fiji or a holiday in Cairns, they will have to pay 15 per cent more for the holiday in Cairns because of the Opposition's GST. It has made it clear that your package holiday in Fiji or any other overseas destination will be free of GST, but your holiday at an Australian destination will be subject to the GST. At the same time we have had the Opposition running around with all these pamphlets. Its first pamphlet said that the best thing about a GST was that it would hit the tax dodgers and the international tourists. Version two suddenly deleted the impact on the international tourists and referred only to the tax dodgers.

It is very clear that these measures that the Opposition is proposing will not only wipe out tourism and jobs in the motor vehicle industry but also create havoc throughout the whole of the economy. It opposes the constructive measures we take. To demonstrate the impact of these measures, I seek leave to table these two documents to demonstrate beyond doubt the Opposition's deceit.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are afraid of the truth. They are afraid that their deceit is exposed in these measures. They are afraid of the fact that the lie is exposed. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—The time for the debate has concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Defence Logistics Redevelopment Project—Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre.

SPEECH.PARA: The defence logistics redevelopment project, which was announced by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) in June 1990, implements a rationalised and centralised strategy of wholesale storage and distribution for the Australian Defence Force. Substantial savings will be achieved through the reduction in operating and manpower costs. Revenue from the subsequent disposal of redundant property at Randwick, Zetland, Regents Park, Broadmeadows, Tottenham, Banyo and Toowoomba will largely offset the cost of the project.

PARA.TAB: A central part of this strategy is a modern tri-service storage and distribution facility, the defence national storage and distribution centre, which is to be established primarily at Moorebank. Additional warehousing accommodation at Leichhardt, Regents Park, Bathurst and Dubbo will also be used. Concurrently, each service will improve its regional warehousing infrastructure.

The defence national storage and distribution centre will accommodate most of Navy stocks, a small element of Air Force stocks and part of the Army national stocks plus those Army logistics functions currently the responsibility of the Moorebank logistics group. The accommodation provided will be a combination of new facilities and existing facilities which will be upgraded, where appropriate. This will give the Defence Force a modern and efficient warehousing complex which will enable current technology and systems to be best utilised. The construction of the defence national storage and distribution centre will allow the closure of warehousing operations at Randwick, Zetland and Penrith and will contribute to the part closure of Regents Park.

Environmental effects of the planned redevelopment works have been determined to be minimal as works are restricted to the confines of existing bases. An environmental certificate of compliance has been issued. The estimated cost of the proposed works at April 1992 prices is $100m.

In its report the Public Works Committee agreed to the defence logistic redevelopment project—defence national storage and distribution centre, but raised the following specific issues. Firstly, there should be continuing consultation between defence and the work forces at all establishments at which redundancies are programmed to occur to ensure that the personnel involved are assisted in finding alternative employment. A formal mechanism to achieve this objective should be established. Secondly, during the development of the proposal and after the work has been completed defence should continue formal liaison, including site visits, with the New South Wales fire brigades. Thirdly, as part of the study of fire risks throughout all defence installations currently being undertaken, a formal risk management analysis of existing and proposed facilities should be carried out by an independent professionally qualified fire safety consultant. Fourthly, for the defence national storage and distribution centre to be successfully implemented, it will be necessary for the supply systems redevelopment project to be completed on time. Defence should provide the funds and resources for the successful completion of the supply systems redevelopment project. Also, there is an urgent need for the provision of undercover parking for Army vehicles at Moorebank.
Defence agrees with the recommendations and will take action as recommended. I thank the Committee for its support and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion of the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall). As has been mentioned on previous occasions, it is appropriate that suitable accommodation for what is highly technical equipment be provided.

PARA.TAB: I previously raised the question of the asbestos roofs on some of the buildings and I made the point that we should put in place a program to replace that sheeting, rather than just put in place a monitoring program. I did not hear any comment on that, and I would hope that over time we can bring about a program either to properly seal roofing that is flaking or, more appropriately, replace that roofing. The Opposition supports the motion.
