TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—That point was not responded to in the reply I had from the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus)). I will make sure that it is and that an answer is sent to the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser).

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Hand:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence a detailed discussion of the Migration Reform Bill and some of its consequences and seek clarification from the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) as to the operation of some of the provisions, let me say first that the Opposition will not oppose these reform measures, even though it sees them as being somewhat belated and inadequate.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to understand the depth of the crisis that we now suffer in Australia. It is a crisis of quite enormous proportion. I saw an article in one of the newspapers today that suggested that this is a world-wide problem and that we ought to see ourselves as being no different to any other part of the world. It is often argued that there are people on the move throughout the world seeking new opportunities for themselves and their families and one ought not to be surprised that some people looking for those opportunities make their way to Australia. It is argued, therefore, that we ought not to be unduly perturbed at the facts which are relevant to this particular situation.

The facts cannot be forgotten and they cannot be glossed over. We now have something of the order of 21,700 asylum seekers in Australia applying for refugee status. Some 500 or so people who have arrived in small boats, small craft, have also sought asylum and are being held while their claims are being determined. There are some 20,000 or so Chinese students who were in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre, as well as their 7,000 or so dependents who have since come to Australia, whose situation remains unresolved and who, in many cases, might well be seeking protection after June 1994 in Australia.

The fact is that these large numbers of people who have entered Australia on a whole variety of bases have put our system for determining questions relating to refugee status under enormous stress. We used to deal with something of the order of 500 applications a year. When one looks at the large numbers of people now in the system, the enormity of that problem, I think, can be readily appreciated.

The fact is that this crisis has now been with us for almost three years. Some people remain held in detention. I am not one who complains about the quality of that detention in terms of its ability to deal with situations of relatively short periods of duration, but some people have been held in detention for a very long time. The fact that some people are held in detention for that length of time is now having a very disastrous effect upon some of those people who have been so detained. In other words, it is the detention that is now impacting upon them and mitigating against our ability to handle their circumstances in a way which might otherwise be seen at any other time as being reasonable and appropriate.

All of these situations are on the record. I have emphasised them over a long time. Many of them are detailed in the report that was presented to the Parliament: Australia's refugee and humanitarian system—achieving a balance between control and refuge. It is very important report that was prepared by members of this Parliament. It catalogues the problems that we face.

The Minister would have us believe that, in relation to that, he has taken a series of steps at appropriate times and, because of certain circumstances beyond his control, certain other problems have arisen and we ought not to be unduly perturbed or judgmental in relation to these factors so far as the Government's record is concerned.

I do not think that is a reasonable judgment. I want to take the House through some of the matters that are detailed on the public record simply to reveal why we are in this crisis. Australia is a country that has a unique advantage over most other countries in dealing with these matters. We have water boundaries which insulate us from people who have the ability to come here and remain on our shores. I am sure that countries in Europe, the United States of America, North America generally, would very much like to be insulated in the way in which we are.

We have had what we have been assured over a long time is the most comprehensive—and some people complain about it, particularly those people in the tourist industry—visa system to ensure that people enter Australia after some inquiry as to their bona fides and to enable us to regulate that entry. The Bill now before the House is designed to further refine those arrangements. Yet, notwithstanding water boundaries and a visa system, we have a crisis which I think is comparable with that in Europe and in North America.

Numbers of reasons are given for the crisis that we face, but the principal reason, I think, relates to the large numbers of students who were here in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre and the way in which that issue was dealt with by this Government, by this Minister's predecessors. It is important, I think, to note that at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre, there were in Australia some 20,000 students from the People's Republic of China. They came here under a system designed to promote the sale of education about which this Government, through its Ministers, particularly the then Minister for Education, the present Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), spoke with pride about its achievements.
Paragraph 8.10, on page 184 of the Committee's report, reveals:

The overstay rate for all overseas students in 1988/89 was 23.3 per cent and 40 per cent for PRC students in May 1989. This compared with a visitor overstay rate in that period of 1.8 per cent. Of the 15,111 PRC students who had arrived in Australia since 1 January 1986, only 1,685 . . . had left Australia by the end of May 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, the overstay rate of Chinese students at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre was well known, well understood and on the public record. From certain internal memos that later became known, I believe that the Minister's predecessor, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), was endeavouring to deal with that matter but other members of the Government resisted the efforts to constrain that program, which was already failing.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that because of a decision taken by the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to allow all those students who were here at that time to remain and their relatives to join them later, in the order of 27,000 people from the People's Republic of China were allowed to remain here on a temporary entry basis—a discriminatory policy applied to nobody else from any other part of the world. In the main, they are still here today. Just to be precise and to give the House some idea of what has happened, table 8.1 of the report states that at pre-21 June 1989 arrivals—that is, pre Tiananmen Square arrivals—there were an estimated 21,000 PRC nationals in Australia and as at 31 May 1991 1,990 of those PRC nationals had departed.

The decisions taken in relation to that group of people, where case by case determination of claims for asylum were abandoned—presumably because of the large numbers of people involved—led to a situation where the Government allowed a large number of additional students into Australia under arrangements which I find reprehensible. The record in relation to their departure, revealed in the same table, is that there were 24,838 students admitted as at 31 May 1991 and departures of those students totalled 2,125. Almost 23,000 students who were allowed into Australia remained here as at 31 May 1991.

Those students should never have been allowed to come to Australia without efforts to test their bona fides. It is detailed very clearly in paragraph 8.15 of this report that the Government put in place arrangements which it describes euphemistically as pipeline processing arrangements. I quote what Senator Robert Ray, the Minister responsible, said in the Senate on 21 November 1989:

SPEECH.PARA: The `pipeline' processing measures are less stringent than the global measures (which will apply to PRC applicants from 1 January 1990) in that `pipeline' applicants will be assessed against a lower education level criterion (year 10 compared with year 12 for the global measures) and will not be subjected to more extensive immigration bona fides testing (required under the global measures).

This Government put in place arrangements to pipeline process all of these people into Australia without proper bona fides testing. Is it any wonder that they then made applications? They then tried to discover how they could stay in Australia after their visas expired. Some 17,000 of them have lodged applications for refugee status.

PARA.TAB: The reason that we have some 21,700 unprocessed applicants today is that this Government applied pipeline processing arrangements which brought people into Australia who were not subjected to any reasonable bona fides testing. When we look at how long it takes the Government to act in relation to these matters, we find it was only a matter of weeks ago that, in relation to people who might still be seeking to come to Australia from the People's Republic of China, the Government has announced decisions that will in effect put a quota on the number of students and subject them to additional bona fides testing that is not applied to other students.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very small number.

—Yes, it is a very small number. The Minister has limited it to 300. The Minister's predecessors allowed in 23,000 students under the pipeline processing arrangements and now, only a matter of weeks ago, the Minister has brought in a restriction. It is a matter of very real concern because the system is in crisis.

PARA.TAB: In the Minister's second reading speech, which outlined these further proposals that the Government has developed, the Minister sought to indicate the various steps that he has taken to compel people to lodge applications and to put time limits on, including the steps that were taken to broaden the community representation on committees that were designed to consider refugee applications on review. The Minister also outlined the provisions that were made by him to provide legal advice and assistance to asylum seekers, but he then turns on those refugee organisations whom he has supported and funded and casts the blame on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all of them.
—Not all of them, but some of them. He also seeks to blame lawyers in relation to these matters.
—Some lawyers.

—Some lawyers, the Minister says. I want to make it clear that I do not put the blame on the legal profession. I do not find it in the least surprising that those in the legal profession—given their duties and responsibilities, given the nature of the training that they receive and given the employment difficulties that so many of them have in this recession, also a Government creation—use their creative endeavours to find their way through the system that the Government puts in place. That does not surprise me in the least. The lawyers have to be sufficiently adroit and flexible to be able to make the changes to deal with that situation. The Government cannot bleat about the fact that they find ways through the system. It also cannot complain that the refugee organisations would seek to offer advice and assistance because that is exactly what I would expect them to do.
—What about ethics?

—If the honourable member for Banks has some complaints to make about their ethics, perhaps he might like to contribute to the debate. I know of nothing that the Minister has had to say about the lawyers' ethics. If there are ethical problems associated with the way in which these matters are dealt with, there are bodies that people can go to. That information can be laid before those bodies and disciplinary action can be taken.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hand interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am one who puts great store in ethics. The system has been flawed and the Government has been counselled by us over time as to the sorts of steps it ought to take to deal with the situation. We have made a number of suggestions in relation to the way in which the system can be improved.

PARA.TAB: I do not have time in this guillotined debate to deal with this legislation in a more relaxed way as I would like to, but I do intend to make the points very strongly by proposing a second reading amendment to this Bill. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)deplores the Government's failure to control the refugee determination process, commencing with former Prime Minister Hawke's decision on the People's Republic of China Nationals in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre;
(2)notes the lamentable time delays in moving to reform the refugee determination system; and

(3)regrets that the further proposals put by the Coalition to limit judicial appeals, to require leave to access review procedures and to redeploy staff to the refugee screening process have been ignored".

I move that amendment so that these issues are put clearly in focus. This legislation is belated, and I still do not believe that it will enable the Government to get control of the process. That is a matter that will be on its head.

PARA.TAB: It is important to understand the role of the courts in relation to this matter. The Government has proposed a system which will retain for the legal profession its rights to be involved in this area. It needs to be clearly understood that for a long time we had a system in which the process of refugee determination and the bona fides of claims was left in the hands of the government of the day to determine. They were administrative processes in which the legislation at no time even sought to define `refugee' for the very purpose of ensuring that this remained a matter for the government of the day to determine.

The view was formed that people who arrive on our shore should be able to have their claims looked at but ought not to be able to access the full canopy of our Australian legal system, with all of its protections, administrative controls and review procedures. It was for a very good reason. Access is for Australian citizens and very often is at a cost to Australia and its citizens. To open Australia up to a situation in which the people of the world, at a cost to Australian taxpayers, can get access to our administrative review system and our legal system was never intended.

The Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Anthony Mason, after the Court had taken it upon itself to get into this area and to extend the law to ensure that the courts would have a role—and did so very creatively over time in a number of cases—is now concerned that the High Court, in its original jurisdiction, may have a fairly heavy workload in reviewing all of the cases that might come before it. I make it very clear on behalf of the Opposition that if the High Court, through its own endeavours, has sought such a workload and it believes it has the capacity through the decisions that it has taken to assume this responsibility, it ought to find it within its own resources and its own capacities to deal with these matters.

The idea that we ought to amend the law to provide extra rights of appeal and to delegate the matter to other judges in order to relieve the court of that responsibility which arose from its own decisions is a matter that I would not contemplate in the legislature, and I hope the Government would not contemplate it. I am disappointed that the Government has gone to water in relation to this matter, because the system that it seeks to put in place still provides access to a whole host of situations in which judicial review will be able to be obtained. That is a matter of concern to us. We are concerned that the review system that the Government intends is one that all of the applicants will be able to access, whereas in our view it is only those who have arguable cases who should be able to obtain that access. We are disappointed that it is constrained in that way.

I do not intend to deal with the whole schema. I am disappointed, because the Bill is complex and very detailed, that this Parliament will not have an opportunity to debate at length the very extensive reforms contained in the legislation. Some of the matters which I think people ought to be aware of, and which the Opposition has considered—and it certainly has not demurred in relation to them—relate to, for instance, the requirement that all arrivals will present for immigration clearance.

There may be some concerns amongst Australians who do not hold an Australian passport—dual nationals—that they may be required to present an Australian passport or other evidence of their identity when returning to Australia. We do not demur in relation to that. We think that Australian citizenship is important and is of value. My Leader has spoken elsewhere today in relation to that. We think that it does not reflect well on Australian citizenship if citizens want to travel abroad on a passport issued by another country. The Government gets support from us on that.

The Bill seeks to put the onus on people to provide evidence of their authority to be present in Australia. I have made some inquiries into the matter, and I seek the Minister's assurance in relation to the way in which that provision will operate. In the way in which the provisions are written, any one of us might be asked in the street for evidence. I am told that people should be approached only if there are reasonable grounds to believe that they are non-citizens. Action would be taken, presumably, against departmental officials who did inquire about a person's identity without reasonable grounds to believe that a person is a non-citizen. It is a matter that needs to be addressed very carefully.

The Government has determined in its wisdom to put in place a Refugee Review Tribunal. Instead of adopting the system proposed by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations whereby the Refugee Tribunal would develop its own ethos—a system in which senior members of a panel would be able to consider questions on which we might want to have a common approach—for consistency in decision-making, the Government has determined to refer those matters to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It almost seems to me, from the way in which it has been referred to that body, that the Government was worried about excluding it generally and needed to find a role for it.

I take the view that a body which has responsibilities that are much wider, when left remote from the issue of refugee determination and the particular issues that might be involved, could go the same way in deciding these matters as the High Court. In other words, decisions could be taken which have no real bearing upon the consequences that might flow from them. I think those people who are involved in the specialist tribunal will have that knowledge and awareness. Even though the senior member might be able to sit on that special body with other members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, my view is that that is a less than desirable way to deal with that issue. I would counsel the Minister, if he is going to look at any of these issues again, to take that matter on board.

There are several other matters that I want to deal with in the few moments that are left to me. The Minister in his second reading speech referred to the situation concerning New Zealand nationals. He made the statement, which I strongly welcome, that this Bill, in introducing visa requirements which are to be of universal application, will put in place a special category for New Zealanders. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: However, limited categories of non-citizens, in particular New Zealanders, will still be able to travel to Australia without a visa and enter with the same degree of convenience as at present.

I welcome that assurance, but I want to be sure that that will apply in practice. I notice that there are some provisions in the legislation which deal with the new system of visas. Proposed section 26(1)(3) in the Bill says:
. . . regulations may prescribe criteria for a visa or visas in a specialised class . . . provided for by section 26A, 26B or 26C but not by section 26D).
Proposed section 26A is the special category visas for New Zealanders. There is later a provision 26G(1) which says:
The regulations may provide that visas, or visas in a specified class—

As it uses the same terms as are seen in proposed sections 21 and 26(1)(3), it is clear to me from the way in which that provision is written that one could prescribe, through regulations, visas that would require people to present visas and, besides that, impose conditions in relation to them about the work that may be done in Australia by a holder. That would be a limitation that is not possible now. It is one that I do not think this legislation ought to authorise or be a matter that ought to be dealt with by regulation.

PARA.TAB: I would seek the Government's assurance that that provision does not apply to enable a government to be able to put in such a restriction. I would hope in another place it would be amended if it has that meaning, because I think the message that the Minister put in his speech needs to be clear and unambiguous.

I want to conclude by raising a matter relating to unauthorised arrivals in Australia. When people arrive in Australia at an airport they are given a statement of rights before they are turned around, if they are here illegally. I would like to know whether that same practice operates in relation to other unauthorised arrivals in Australia, and particularly in relation to the 113 or so people who were turned around last week. I have no doubt that that would have been done, but I would like the Minister's assurance in relation to it because it is a practice that is carried out with border arrivals at airports. It seems to me that it should apply elsewhere.

An article in yesterday's Canberra Times raised another matter relating to the maximum number of visas that might be granted and suggested that there could be quotas. That is a matter which is of concern to me. If this Bill authorises quotas that could be reached and the remaining applications lapse in the way in which it is described here, it would be of concern to me. I hope that the Minister, in his remarks, might clarify that matter as well. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak at a later time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Migration Reform Bill 1992 and, in so doing, to oppose the amendment. I listened very carefully to what the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), had to say. On a number of occasions he said that the immigration process in this country is in a state of crisis. I stopped marking down the number of times in which he used the word `crisis' when I got to seven. I then listened more attentively for the evidence he was going to provide to show that this system is in crisis. As evidence for this, he said that 20,000 Chinese students were given a particular status as a result of the events in Tiananmen Square in 1989. I listened very carefully and heard no more evidence for the assertion that our system of admissions is in as much crisis as that in North America or in western Europe. It has been reported recently in the paper that 400,000 people in Germany were seeking political refugee status. Large numbers are entering, particularly the United States of America and Canada, on this basis.

PARA.TAB: Let me remind the House that in 1989 we faced a very difficult situation, with about 20,000 PRC nationals in this country in an international context, of the democratisation of communist societies, which has gone ahead in almost every communist state other than the People's Republic of China, and a reasonable expectation that the democratisation process that was under way in China would continue. On that expectation, and in that context, 20,000 Chinese students had entered Australia, mostly with a view to studying the English language. Then, to the horror not just of our own society but that of the entire world, the Old Guard of Chinese communists in Beijing used armour in order to put down the democratisation movement, notably in Beijing, and later elsewhere in the country, moving in troops from regions not affiliated with the students whom they had to put down, murder, butcher, and run over with tracked, armoured personnel carriers and tanks.

Against this background we had to decide what to do with these 20,000 Chinese students who had a reasonable expectation of receiving some form of asylum and protection from the democratic society that is Australia. Within that context, decisions were made with the prime purpose of protecting these people against being sent them back with the likelihood of them being severely repressed, if not killed. In that context, decisions were made by the then Prime Minister of Australia, later endorsed by a second Prime Minister of Australia, and accepted by the decision makers of this Government that protection should be afforded to these people. It is that process that is now seen as producing a crisis in the refugee admission system that we have in this country.

This seems to me to be short of the evidence one would require in order to demonstrate a system in crisis. In any case, it is difficult to concede that the system is in crisis when it produces an amendment to the Migration Reform Bill which, in part, addresses this supposed crisis. This amendment says:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading . . .

That means, presumably, that the Opposition will not be opposing it. The amendment goes on to deplore, to note, and to regret certain aspects of government policy. Surely this is coming in with a bang and going out with a whimper. It is coming in with a bang of seven crises—at which point I stopped counting—and going out with a deplore, a note, and a regret.

PARA.TAB: In point of fact, the Migration Reform Bill seeks to address the central problem which we face in the admission of various categories of visitors and settlers to this country, including political refugees, by striking a better balance between the rights of people to clear justice and a fair hearing in our processes, as against the enabling of undue and extended delays in the lodging and processing of applications for residency status in this country. These changes will replace the legislative framework which currently underpins the regulation of entry to and stay in Australia, as well as the detention and removal of non-citizens here unlawfully. It will instead provide a new and greatly extended basis for merits review of immigration decisions and, for the first time, provide independent determinative merits review of refugee related decisions. No-one suggests that it is easy to make the balance between the two considerations.

People who apply for status as residents of Australia, in whatever category and under whatever provisions, have some right to be considered, particularly if they are in Australia at the time. On the other hand, they, and the Australian community at large, should have some expectation that this application will be dealt with expeditiously. At times it has to be conceded that under the present arrangements this latter expectation has not been met. For example, people have been asking, quite rightly, why and for how long can aspiring political refugees stay in detention in Australia, some without even lodging their formal applications.

This Bill seeks to resolve this dilemma by changing a few of the provisions in or reforming the Migration Act. It limits access to the Federal Court to those cases which are codified in the rules. In the case of onshore refugee applicants, it opens up the independent Refugee Review Tribunal, the RRT, which will expedite their processing. The RRT replaces the Refugee Status Review Committee, to provide determinative independent merits review of refugee status matters. In this particular tribunal, hearings will be possible whereas, at present, determination is made on the papers. In order to eliminate arbitrary decisions, it also codifies decision making by setting out the rights and obligations of applicants, and the obligations of the decision makers with respect to the applications. In addition, it then opens access to merits review in the Immigration Review Tribunal which has both a quicker and a wider range than the Federal Court, which in itself should speed up procedures.

As I said, the purpose of these reforms is to strike a better balance between the expectations of justice and speed in processing applications for residence. Under these reforms, all non-Australian citizens will now require a visa to travel, enter and remain in Australia. The reform Bill provides for the creation of a special category visa which would be electronically issued on arrival in Australia. This would be applicable to persons who were previously exempt non-citizens, including New Zealand citizens. Since there has been some publicity given to the matter, I should point out that this status accorded to New Zealand citizens is presently under review within the Government's decision making processes. While that may be changed at some future time, it is not proposed to do so in this Bill.

All arrivals will have to present themselves with evidence of Australian citizenship or a visa, or they may be detained pending clarification of their status. This reform Bill provides for a system of mandatory detention to be imposed on unlawful non-citizens. Except for unlawful non-citizens who seek to enter Australia in an unauthorised manner, unlawful citizens may be released from detention if they are granted a bridging visa. Bridging visas would enable them to remain in Australia pending the outcome of their visa application.

Unlawful non-citizens may be removed from detention either after being granted a visa or being removed from Australia. The decision making process which resolves their applications will be codified in this Bill, instead of allowing the decision makers to rely on the rather vague notions of natural justice which have hitherto prevailed. Certain categories of people will then be entitled also to an independent merits review, including, notably, onshore refugee claimants.

The reform Bill makes a technical change in the way applications for protection as a refugee are dealt with. In future claimants will not apply separately for recognition as a refugee and for permission to stay in Australia. Both processes will be combined in an application for a protection visa. They will be entitled to consideration by the Refugee Review Tribunal, which will operate in much the same way as the IRT. The IRT, being non-adversarial and normally excluding lawyers, has gained considerable public credibility and praise for its simplicity and the ease with which it is accessed. The RRT should do the same, having a similar format.

Extending merits review should in itself reduce the number of cases going to the Federal Court. It is important to take this step because of the increase in the number of onshore applicants seeking political refugee status, and hitherto the delays, as I have mentioned, that have been experienced in processing these applications. This number may well be augmented in the future by an increase in the number of people seeking that status who arrive by boat on the northern shores of Australia. This does deserve our consideration; although,to call this problem a crisis is exceeding the fact by a considerable margin. But a number of problems have been encountered in this respect.

Some of these people have taken an inordinate amount of time to lodge their formal applications—in some cases up to 18 months. It has been widely feared—and I believe the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) mentioned this in his second reading speech—that they have been encouraged to delay in this way by advice from Australian citizens for whatever reason. I must say that, during an inspection of a detention centre in Darwin last year, I came to a similar conclusion.

They then become too readily the objects of apparent human rights campaigns, wherein they may become party to political campaigns designed to impede or control public decision making through appeals through the media, which have considerations other than the lawful process. During 1992 we witnessed far too much of this sort of thing.

Applicants for political refugee status should apply promptly on arrival, and in return they should be dealt with quickly and fairly. Political refugees must be granted asylum quickly in this country if they are granted political refugee status. Those who are judged not to be political refugees should also be dealt with quickly and, if necessary, returned to their country of origin. In this respect, the Government's policy in removing on 30 October the 113 people who came to Australia from China by boat was a model action. It will deter persons who think they can readily queue jump into Australia by, for example, using relatively modern vessels, sophisticated satellite navigation systems, and a short cut to Christmas Island.

It will also deter racketeers in the place of origin, who have received considerable and quite warranted publicity in our media. But it should not affect genuine political refugees who have a right—and I should repeat this—to our asylum against persecution. Therefore, we will have a refugee processing system under this reform Bill that is clear, predictable, fair and quick.

The fact that people—and this should be said again and again—arrive by boat on our northern shores or on our island Territories does not automatically make them refugees. That is a decision that is determined by other processes. They must go through the same process as someone who arrives by plane or any other mechanism.

This reform Bill contains an integrated package of amendments which would codify for the decision makers the processes by which they grant or cancel visas. It would greatly expand the availability of determinative merits review, and it will ensure that the judicial review of migration decisions is available only on grounds which take into account the special nature of decisions on the status of non-citizens.

In the more general migration area, the Immigration Review Tribunal will handle the expanded case load that will no longer be able to go to the Federal Court for reasons of the changes taking place in this Bill. We need to remember at all times that over two million Migration Act decisions are made each year by officers of DILGEA. Uncertainty exists concerning what is required to make a legally valid decision, because of the uncertain content of natural justice, or procedural fairness—call it what you will—as that concept has evolved and continues to evolve in the courts.

This reform Bill provides for a code for decision makers, and decision making, to replace the current common law rules of natural justice. This reform Bill provides for codified procedures which will apply to all decisions made under the Migration Act in relation to the granting and cancellation of visas. This Bill sets out the legal requirements governing the making of applications. As noted above, the codified procedures to be established by the Bill will replace common law rules of natural justice and procedural fairness. This is taking codification a step further through a system which has been in the process of codification since the 1989 reforms. The Bill extends the current merits review regime in Australia so that there are broader merits review rights for decisions which affect the capacity of a non-citizen to remain in Australia. In certain instances, the President of the Refugee Review Tribunal or the Immigration Review Tribunal may be able to seek guidance from the AAT. But it is expected that, while only a small number of cases would be so referred, these may be of assistance in setting up the benefits of a judicial legal interpretation without the disadvantages of delay and expense presently associated with court appeals.

AAT review in such cases replaces the IRT and the RRT and is, therefore, not another layer of bureaucracy for the applicant. There will also be provisions for judicial review rights where merit review rights are exhausted or not available and codified decision making procedures have not been followed. An applicant will be able to appeal to the Federal Court if the codified procedures and criteria have not been followed by decision making. But a court appeal will only be permitted where the appellant has first pursued all merits review rights. Removal from Australia would then be by force of law, rather than as a result of a decision. A person will become subject to removal as soon as he or she becomes unlawful.

The aim of these amendments is to simplify the removal process so that all persons unlawfully in Australia will be subject to removal from the country. The Bill provides that non-citizens unlawfully in Australia will be liable for the costs of their maintenance, detention and removal. But the Bill also contains a power to waive such costs, which can be exercised by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

In introducing this reform Bill and changing these processes, this Government believes that it is moving to a better balance between natural justice and the speed of processing—although the balance between these things is always subject to controversy and reasonable argument.

I would like to conclude by pointing out that, while establishing the Refugee Review Tribunal will cost about $3.2m in 1992-93, it is expected that the savings as against the present rather lengthy processing system could be as much as $72m during the next four years. This is a Bill designed to improve our processing systems, and I recommend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the Migration Reform Bill this afternoon I would like to answer a few points raised by the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley), who has now disappeared. Nonetheless, I shall answer some of the points raised in his speech. In particular, his harping on the word `crisis' reminds me very much of a Supertramp album back in the 1970s which was entitled Crisis? What crisis?. In answering the assertion by the honourable member for Adelaide that there is no crisis, let me point to a couple of statistical matters. He raised the example of Germany being a country which is having a refugee crisis. I think the Germans have made that point perfectly clear. In fact, the Germans are now suffering some substantial social dislocation as a result of the refugee crisis within their frontiers.

PARA.TAB: Germany has in the region of 800,000 refugee claimants, having arrived there between 1990 and 1992 in an almost uncontrolled fashion. That matter was reported upon in the recent report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. The 800,000 refugee claimants who arrived between 1990 and 1992 represent around one per cent of the overall population of the now combined German nation of approximately 80 million people.

I will now turn to the Australian case. Australia is a nation which, as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has already remarked, has a coastline all around its frontier, and it should reasonably expect to be in a much better position to control its refugee influx. Australia currently has 21,700 cases awaiting determination and, in addition, of course, there are the 17,000 students from the People's Republic of China. That comes to a little under 40,000 people. Taking the ratio of those people to the overall total of the Australian population, they represent about a quarter of a per cent. So the Germans have a problem which is about four times worse than the Australian problem in that context.

I raise this matter only because of the use of those statistics by the honourable member for Adelaide. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) shakes his head in a somewhat bemused fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am listening.

—Not that we are surprised to see the Minister make demonstrations at the table. As he shakes his head, I might add that I made those calculations in a somewhat rapid manner in answer to those points raised by the honourable member for Adelaide.
—What is the point? You have taken a few minutes. What was the point you were making?
—Once again the Minister interjects, as he is wont to do. He is a known interjector. I now want to turn to the substance of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Dundas.
—Good on you.
—Thank you. The amendment speaks for itself:

SPEECH.PARA: ". . . the House:

(1)deplores the Government's failure to control the refugee determination process, commencing with former Prime Minister Hawke's decision on the People's Republic of China Nationals in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre;
(2)notes the lamentable time delays in moving to reform the refugee determination system; and

(3)regrets that the further proposals put by the Coalition to limit judicial appeals, to require leave to access review procedures and to redeploy staff to the refugee screening process has been ignored".

In looking at the Government's migration and refugee policy in recent times, one has to look with a certain amount of bemusement at the contrasts in the policy positions taken by the two most senior spokesmen for the Government—the Minister himself, who is sitting at the table, and the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). On 8 October, during the debate on the tabling of the report to the Parliament of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, I made some comments about the relationship between the Minister and the Chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is as good as gold now.

—It is as good as gold now! So there is no more fighting in the corridors: is that what the Minister is trying to say? Is the Minister now saying that there will be no more spats? Perhaps the Minister, in summing up the debate today, can point out exactly how he has managed to determine that, when this almost irreparable breach that was quite apparent to the users of Parliament House during those days was reported by the Telegraph Mirror as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: MPs in House Brawl, Wild Corridor Clash.

PARA.TAB: A long-running row between a senior Government Minister and a Labor backbencher has erupted into a wild shouting match in the halls of Parliament House.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unbelievable that these sorts of things take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: in all fairness, I draw your attention to the subject matter before the House and the relevance of a very inaccurate account of what occurred being quoted into Hansard. It is most unfair to the honourable member for Calwell, who is not here, and to me, for the report to be inaccurate. But there is a matter of substance before the House and the honourable member should stick to that.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Order! There is no point of order. If the Minister claims that he has been misrepresented there are procedures in the House to correct that. But the Bill deals with migration; the honourable member's comments are in order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I made the comment in support of paragraph (1) of the amendments moved by the honourable member for Dundas that the Government has lost control of the refugee determination program. One of the reasons for the loss of this control, this policy problem that the Government seems to have, may well be that the Minister has this enormous difference between himself and the next most senior spokesman for the Government on migration and refugee programs, the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, who is also the Caucus chairman on migration policy matters.

PARA.TAB: So it is quite logical, and it is quite in order during a debate, to draw a parallel between that physical confrontation between the Minister and the next most senior spokesman of the Government on migration and refugee matters within Parliament House. The Minister claims almost to have been misrepresented. I just say that he has had his opportunity. I am not aware of his having taken up the first opportunity to make a personal explanation following the witnessing of that wild brawl between the Minister and the Chairman by, I think, a passing delegation from the United States of America. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: Relations between the two have been worsening over differences in immigration policy, which resulted in open disagreement during an interview on the ABC's 7.30 Report.
The argument on this particular program followed conflict earlier that day between the two gentlemen at a meeting of the Caucus immigration committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —That did not happen.
—The Minister is now saying that that did not happen.
—I have never been on the 7.30 Report.
—No, not the Minister himself. I think they were the comments from the Chairman of the Committee.
—Order! The Minster should not interject. He will get his chance to reply in a moment.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, sometimes it is a good idea to give the Minister an opportunity to interject, because he sort of hangs himself by coming in with statements that can be rebutted quite easily during the debate.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have a point of order. Enough is enough. The fact is that there is a very important Bill before the House. This nonsense that is being talked about now is inaccurate. They have had their joke; it did not happen. I refer you to the matter before the House and call on you to ask the honourable member to address the substance of the matter before the House. I have allowed two or three minutes of grossly inaccurate comments to be made—

—Order! The Minister has made his point of order. I have already indicated that there is a procedure through which he can correct any inaccurate statements. But I would remind the honourable member for Moore that he does need to make his comments relevant to the Bill before the House.

—As I pointed out at the beginning of my speech, I was in fact talking to the Bill and, of course, to the second reading amendment which has been seconded by me. I think it is entirely consistent with the point I have been making that the loss of control in the refugee determination system is symptomatic of this loss of policy direction on the part of the Government in relation to migration and refugee matters.

PARA.TAB: That matter has been commented upon by the honourable member for Calwell. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 September stated that the Chairman of the Caucus immigration committee, the honourable member for Calwell, said that the Government was allowing the coalition to set the agenda on immigration policy. I happen to agree with that. I think that is entirely true. He also accused the Government of not doing enough to differentiate between its own policies and those of the coalition. He cited as evidence of the Government's departure from its traditional stance its decision to cut the migrant intake severely this year, its Budget measure denying migrant access to unemployment benefits until six months after entry, and its introduction of an English language test for some migrant categories. I understand that he is also bitterly disappointed and has complained about the Government's failure to curb its outspoken backbench immigration critics, most notoriously Senator Walsh and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell).

I might point out that this is not the only spat within the Labor Government in relation to differences in policy positions. I draw the attention of the House to comments made by one of the members of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. I might add that Senator McKiernan, the author of those comments, had a spat of his own with the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke—the person responsible in the first instance for what I consider to be the corruption of the refugee determination process by his emotion-ridden, emotion-laden unilateral decision to allow the PRC nationalist students to remain in Australia until 1994.

It was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 30 September that Mr Hawke, who was overseas when the report of the Committee was released earlier that month, told the Sydney Morning Herald that the commitment should not be withdrawn. He also rejected criticism that the decision to offer sanctuary had been ill-considered and emotive. The article, by Mr Mick Millett from the Sydney Morning Herald, went on to say in relation to Senator McKiernan:

SPEECH.PARA: `I think Mr Hawke is wrong', Senator McKiernan said. The commitment has got to be reviewed. There are 17,000 reasons why it should be reviewed. It has caused a big furore in other ethnic communities. They are claiming that if the Government can do it for the Chinese, why can't it do it for the Bosnians and the Sri Lankans, whose plight is demonstrably worse.

Need I say any more? That is strong evidence of strong policy differences among the Labor Government's immigration and refugee spokespeople and supports the contention in item 1 of the amendments proposed by the honourable member for Dundas that the failure to control the refugee determination process commenced with former Prime Minister Hawke's decision on the Peoples Republic of China nationals in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre.

PARA.TAB: The intention of any refugee determination program—certainly one being run by a humanitarian and rational nation—is to provide a fair system of determination, not to provide special categories with special rules that would cause others who might have an interest or who might be in the refugee determination queue to feel that they have been unfairly dealt with. It also contributes to a general perception in the community about the overall migration and refugee program.

In my electorate, as the Minister would well know, I have a large number of people who have migrated to Australia—just as I did—and whose relatives or friends have applied for immigration to Australia. I know that these are separate issues, and I would not for one minute pretend that they should be determined on the same grounds. However, the overall perception is that somehow there is an unfairness, that somehow there seems to be partiality on the part of the Government in relation to special criteria. In particular, as has already been pointed out, that unilateral decision by the Prime Minister went a long way to causing a substantial deterioration in the standing of the Government's migration and refugee program within the community.

As a member of an electorate where there are large numbers of people who have migrated to this great country, I find that a matter of come concern. Of course, a large number of them come to my office and make representations to me that somehow they have been unfairly treated. We know that by and large the system for assessment of migrants is essentially a fair system. Clearly, the use of objective tests of the eligibility of applicants for the receipt of a visa to migrate to Australia is a good thing. That is something that any reasonable person would support wholeheartedly. The reduction of the opportunity to use political or other types of influence to influence the outcomes is a good thing also because it allows those decisions to be made in an atmosphere of fairness and impartiality.

The difficulty is, of course, that the decision made by Prime Minister Hawke about the PRC students to a large extent undermined the standing of the policies within the community, and I think a lot of people, particularly in my electorate, were troubled about exactly which direction the overall program was going in. When we tell people that unfortunately their relatives or friends have failed to meet the quite high standards of eligibility requirements to migrate to Australia, sometimes it is very difficult for them not to believe that somehow they have been unfairly treated. I think that is one of the fundamental reasons that there must be an overall image, an overall perception, of fairness. Of course, one of the key elements in that process of fairness is the speed with which the refugee determination process takes place.

I see this face-saving exercise here at the front table between the Minister and the Chairman of the Joint Standing committee and the Caucus committee, who has just walked into the chamber—presumably as some sort of exercise to show that there has been a reconciliation between the two.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to take a photograph?

—Might I say, it is a reconciliation that many in Parliament House would be pleased to see because they would not want to have any of those sorts of incidents that were reported earlier during their time. The honourable member for Calwell will acknowledge the fact that I have come back into the House to repeat the assertions I made while he was overseas on a parliamentary delegation. I make those assertions again. If the Minister believes that there has been a reconciliation, I think it is important that the policy circumstances under which that reconciliation has been made be made perfectly clear to the House.
—Why?
—Because this is an important issue.
—Grow up and get on with the Bill. Get back to the Bill. The joke is over.
—Order! The Minister will cease interjecting.
—The Minister is a notorious interjector, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is like water off a duck's back. He is a notorious interjector.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, pull him up and get him back to the Bill. It is a disgrace.
—Order! The Chair does not require any advice from the Minister.

—In conclusion, while the Minister at the table raves, I would just like to point out in supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Dundas that it is clearly time now for the Government to reinforce the element of fairness, speed and, of course, impartiality in the refugee determination process. One of the first things that needs to be done in order to make that the case is to have a case by case determination of the eligibility of the students who have received their visa to remain until 1994.
