TALK.START.PARA: —There are three customs Bills before the House this afternoon. The first, the Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, deals with proposed amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Customs Administration Act 1985. The proposals contained in the Bill relate, firstly, to amendments to these Acts to provide the legislative framework for the electronic transmission to Customs of information relating to the reporting, screening and clearance of cargo and to permit limited on-line computer access to such information by other specified agencies.

PARA.TAB: The proposals also relate, secondly, to amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to improve waterfront security in accordance with recommendations of the joint review committee which examined the 1989 report of the National Crime Authority on port security; thirdly, to amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to extend eligibility for the diesel fuel rebate scheme to vessels servicing oil and gas operations in the North West Shelf and Timor Gap exploration areas when those vessels travel to and from Australian ship repair yards for repairs or refits; and, fourthly, to amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to effect minor technical changes consequential on the introduction of the electronic lodgment reforms to the import entry regime in Act No. 34 of 1992.

The Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1992 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 propose to amend the Customs Act 1901, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 and the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 as part of the legislative package announced by the Government. This introduces a new system for the imposition and collection of dumping and countervailing duties. The Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill provides the mechanism for the determination of interim and final duties, as well as introducing the two means by which subsequent adjustments of duty liability can be effected.

During the last sittings, as part of Act No. 89 of 1992, this Parliament passed legislation which reduced the total time allowed for the processing of anti-dumping and countervailing applications to the preliminary finding stage to a maximum of 125 days. I think everyone welcomes that measure. It extended to five years the period for which anti-dumping and countervailing measures remain in place. It has also made provision for a review to be undertaken by the Anti-Dumping Authority following a request by an interested party as to whether measures should continue after the five-year expiry date. It extended the life of the Anti-Dumping Authority to August 2001 and introduced a number of technical changes to facilitate the processing of applications.

As we all know, goods are said to be dumped if the export price of the product is less than the `normal value'—that is, the comparable price for the like product in the domestic market of the exporting country. Anti-dumping action is taken only if it is established as a result of inquiries undertaken by Customs and the Anti-Dumping Authority that goods have been dumped and that the dumping is causing or threatening material injury to an Australian industry.

It is important to point out in the brief time available that Australia has the best anti-dumping measures in the world. I seek leave to table a chart which shows the differences between Australia, the USA, Canada and the EC.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows that in our regime there are 125 days in which countervailing measures can be put in place—a total of 245 days; in the USA it is 280 days; in Canada it is 261 and surprisingly in the EC, which is very protectionist, the total number of days is 390. That is amazing and I am quite staggered at that. It is important that we reiterate that fact. There is no doubt that there is a lot of confusion in Australia regarding what is dumped product and what is product simply being sold in Australia. I guess all of us who are patriotic have said that products coming in and competing with our own industries, particularly from Europe, are dumped products. We do not necessarily mean that they are being dumped in GATT terms but that the products are simply being sold into Australia. To highlight and to identify what is dumped we have a mechanism, which is GATT related, to ensure that proper and fair play takes place.

PARA.TAB: There has been criticism regarding the timeframe involved. The Opposition has said that it would reduce the timeframe quite dramatically. The real problem I have with that is not that there is anything wrong with shortening the time, if it can be effective, but that it is like telling a police force that it has only a certain number of weeks to catch a bank robber. The problem is that we need a certain period in which to ensure that there is a case to proceed. That period is now 25 days. There is a further 100 days for Customs to bring about its initial findings. The Anti-Dumping Authority then has 120 days after that. If we shorten the time, in many cases we make things harder and disadvantage the Australian company or product that we are trying to protect through anti-dumping measures. There needs to be a balance between the shortest and most effective time and a time scale that allows Customs and the Anti-Dumping Authority to do their job. As I have said in previous debates on such Bills, I congratulate the ADA and Customs on doing an outstanding job.

In my area there has been a lot of criticism about snow peas being dumped in this country. To my knowledge there has not been one application lodged by any rural group or processor against snow peas coming into this country. Unless an application is lodged no-one can expect the Government or any instrumentality to take action. It may be the case that snow peas are being dumped; it may not. However, the avenues are there. Customs now has shopfronts and that is a great innovation. I congratulate the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) on that and for making Customs more accessible. Companies and individuals are able to go in, gain the information that is necessary and, if they see fit, lodge an application.

It is also important to point out what constitutes dumping. I have an anti-dumping guide that has been provided by the Australian Customs Service, which is good reading for all politicians and people in the community. The guide stipulates that material injury is what it is all about. I noticed that in a pamphlet which the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) has put out—in fact, it is entitled GST guide for canegrowers—the Deputy Leader has made some claims about material injury, about tightening the material injury criteria.

A letter from Senator John Button to the Comptroller-General of the Australian Customs Service clearly indicates that all the concerns that the Deputy Leader of the National Party has raised have been addressed. I will not read out the letter, but it is good reading and is there for all to read. It may well benefit the Deputy Leader of the National Party to read that. He may have been in error simply by not being aware of those facts. It is also important to recognise the comments in the GST guide for canegrowers that we have to lose 20 per cent of our domestic market before anti-dumping measures can be implemented. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's current policy does not even allow an application to be made against subsidised sugar coming into Australia until our producers have lost at least 20 per cent of the Australian market.

That is not correct. In fact, it is total and utter nonsense. It does not help rational debate to make such silly statements and send them all around Australia. I understand the pressures that are on the National Party, particularly with tariffs are coming down, and the fact that it is trying to hedge the issue when speaking about anti-dumping. This pamphlet from the National Party is confusing. Again it is inaccurate because it states:

Tariffs mean nothing to the European Community and some Asian countries and even if Australia increased its sugar tariff, any country wanting to get sugar into Australia would simply lift its export subsidy to override that tariff.

For this reason the only way we can guarantee that sugar from countries which subsidise their producers or exporters cannot be dumped in Australia is to have much tougher and quicker anti-dumping and countervailing legislation. . .

I have already commented on the fact that if the process is made much quicker it can actually harm the case for the Australian product. Another point to make is that tariff has another mechanism—I am sure the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) recognises this, even if the Deputy Leader of the National Party does not—and that is price support. A tariff is a price support mechanism. It is totally different from anti-dumping. While the Deputy Leader of the National Party might not understand that, I can assure the House that every cane farmer understands that a tariff is a price support mechanism. That is why they are so vocal in wanting to keep it. It is totally separate from the issue of protecting the product, or the sugar, from other countries.

PARA.TAB: Over the ensuing few weeks, the Federal Government will assess the committee of inquiry that I am chairing into the tariff. I am quite sure that the honourable member for Barker and the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) will watch with great interest to see what recommendations are brought down and what action the Government takes. Those opposite will have to remain in suspense for a few more weeks—perhaps two or three weeks—before a decision is made. I make that distinction between tariff and anti-dumping because there is a massive distinction. At present a tariff of $55 a tonne applies to sugar and the sugar industry would like to keep that. I am sure that if the Deputy Leader of the National Party told sugar growers that shorter anti-dumping time frames will be as good as that tariff, he would have difficulty convincing them.

Because of the time constraints in debating the legislation, I conclude by supporting the Bills and congratulating the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs on the way in which he has pushed through these changes. I also congratulate the Australian Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority on the way in which they administer their organisations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to confine my remarks this afternoon to the Customs Legislation Amendment Bill. My colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) has already addressed the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill. Before I commence my remarks I would like to place on record again my concerns about the limited time given both to the coalition and industry to consult and to study this Bill. There is a pattern emerging over the years of the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) not introducing Bills into the House in sufficient time to allow both the coalition and industry to study them, address their impact and develop a considered position.

PARA.TAB: Given that I was advised back in August about the impending introduction of the Bill, I can only conclude that in leaving it so late and giving us so little time, the Minister is either a very bad manager or else is playing some sordid political game. Either way, it is at the expense of both the democratic process and the efficiency of the customs industry as a whole. The Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 is an omnibus Bill which makes a number of amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Customs Administration Act 1986.

The Bill comprises three main elements. It also includes a number of minor amendments of a technical nature. The coalition will not be opposing the Bill. However, I would like to make some comments about each of the major initiatives being proposed.

Firstly, the Bill provides for the introduction of a cargo automation system. To this end, it puts in place the legislative framework for the electronic transmission of information relating to the reporting, screening and clearance of cargo brought into Australia via air or sea. The Bill also gives limited access to this information to Australian port authorities and the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service. The proposed cargo automation system is the third element in the Australian Customs Service program of improving and updating the customs entry facilities for imports and exports.

The first two components, known as COMPILE and EXIT, were supported by the coalition. There have been some teething problems with COMPILE, such as out of date profiles and incorrect assessment classifications of goods. Indeed, many honourable members would be aware of the recent problems, where a loophole in the COMPILE system failed to detect the hypothetical arrival of potentially hazardous products. A customs broker has advised the coalition that some 31 consignments of potentially hazardous products which should have been quarantined for checking had technically been allowed to enter the country. Nonetheless, and in spite of these teething problems, the coalition is generally satisfied that both the COMPILE and EXIT systems are working well and are of considerable benefit to the industry.

However, I put the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs on notice that we are carefully watching the refinement of COMPILE. If, once complete, it does not satisfactorily resolve the problems I have outlined, we will not hesitate to raise the matter again.

Under the present arrangements, airlines, shipping companies and other freight forwarders manually provide Customs with a report of cargo to be discharged at Australian ports in advance of the arrival of that cargo. This information is then screened against various Customs profiles, including those to single out prohibited or dangerous goods. Once cleared, the importer is given an authority to deal, which allows him to collect the goods. Given that cargo manifests can be up to some 200 pages long and must often be produced in triplicate, the current cargo reporting procedure is lengthy and cumbersome. It is also very costly to both business and the taxpayer.

The amendments proposed in the Bill will correct this by allowing cargo information to be transmitted electronically to the Australian Customs Service. The assessment of this information against COMPILE profiles will be done electronically. Accordingly, the new regime will reduce the paperwork burden on carriers, give importers faster access to their cargo, and reduce the cost to both cargo carriers and importers. The Australian Chamber of Shipping has noted these benefits. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that ACA (Australian Cargo Automation) when fully implemented will generate substantial savings to all participants with the added benefit of greater customs and quarantine control. This will mean faster import clearance, hence cheaper clearances and improved protection from illicit goods and quarantinable product.

I welcome these benefits for the industry. Indeed, in these hard economic times and with record business bankruptcies, I welcome any measure which will reduce industries' costs and make them more competitive. That is what the coalition's Fightback plan is all about—removing costs from business—but unlike this Government, which throws meagre crumbs of assistance at business, we will undertake meaningful reforms in this area by abolishing $20 billion worth of taxes on business.

PARA.TAB: The cargo automation system will allow Customs to react more quickly to changing information and maintain effective risk assessment and management. Again, any measures which enhance community protection are also welcomed by the coalition. Port authorities will be provided with limited access to the data on incoming cargo in order, firstly, to calculate wharf charges and, secondly, to facilitate the collection of statistics. The Australian Quarantine Inspection Service will also be given limited access to cargo report details to allow for the detection of possible breaches of the Quarantine Act.

The Australian Quarantine Inspection's service charges are outrageously high. As such, they impose further considerable cost burdens on business. The coalition hopes that the efficiency gains made through electronic transmission of data will be passed on to customers in the form of lower charges. As I mentioned earlier, in these tough economic times, business needs every break it can get.

Finally, I was pleased to note that the Bill provides for security of information and minimises the possibility of fraud by putting in place a comprehensive security network. I was also pleased to note that the Bill puts in place a contingency mechanism for use when the computer system is down.

The second element of this Bill implements a Budget announcement in respect of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Specifically, it proposes to extend eligibility of the scheme to include those ships travelling to and from Australian ports for repairs or refits. This measure is particularly targeted at vessels engaged in servicing oil and gas operations off the West Australian coast, including the North West Shelf. Currently, those vessels have the option of having repairs or refits undertaken in either Singapore or Australia. However, because diesel fuel taken on board is Singapore is at the international price, which is much cheaper because it does not include Australian excise, many ships elect to have their work undertaken in Singapore. Obviously, this is at the expense of our own ship repair yards.

The proposed amendment is intended to remove the disadvantage suffered by Australian repair and refit yards by reducing the cost of Australian diesel for those ships travelling to Australian ports for repairs. I point out that the coalition will abolish the diesel fuel excise lock stock and barrel. Under a coalition government, consumers will save 19c a litre on petrol and diesel, while businesses will save a substantial 26c a litre. Under our plans businesses will not need to fill out cumbersome forms to get the rebate, nor will they suffer cash flow problems while they wait for a refund. Most importantly, under our plans, struggling businesses will not be held to ransom by disgruntled public servants working to go slow and delaying repayments. Honourable members will recall that I brought to the attention of the House last year the adoption of a go-slow tactic by Customs officers in Tasmania and the devastation which it was having on a Tasmanian logging contractor.

The Bill proposes amendments to improve waterfront security by requiring persons in customs areas to produce satisfactory identification upon request by a Customs officer. Satisfactory identification is defined in the Bill as being identification issued by an employer—such as a ships master—a passport or some other document containing name, photograph, address and date of birth. These amendments are the result of a joint review committee established by the National Crime Authority to examine port security. The committee noted that the inability to control or identify wharf visitors and waterfront workers hindered barrier enforcement.

I have already pointed out that the coalition welcomes any measures which will enhance protection of the community. I mentioned at the outset of my remarks that the coalition will not oppose this Bill. However, we do take the opportunity to draw attention to the high costs which this Government has imposed on business and its reluctance to undertake any meaningful reforms in the wake of the worst recession in 60 years and nearly one million people unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has failed absolutely in its approach to manufacturing industries and to ensuring the survival of a decent and proper manufacturing base in Australia. The headlines of Australian newspapers deal with closure after closure. I take honourable members back only 12 months ago to the closure of Carringtons. Maybe people have forgotten that great shipyard. It is now closed—forced into receivership and sale, resulting in the loss of great skills, great abilities and the loss of a most effective Australian shipbuilding industry. Recently we have seen Nissan decide to take its plant offshore and other car companies making rational decisions to sack people or to contract their businesses to a smaller scale.

PARA.TAB: During this period of failure in this recession `we had to have', the Government made a conscious policy decision to jack up interest rates and bring down tariffs—a recipe for certain failure of Australian industries. The Government has put a competitive demand on Australian industries which it has been impossible for them to meet.

What the Government in effect has done is open up Australian shops and stores to imported goods because of reduced tariffs. By crazy cost structures the Government has made it impossible for local manufacturers to compete. Part of the goals of the Kennett Government is to see that Australia is competitive. If we can judge the results in New Zealand, where similar contracts and labour relations already exist, 96 per cent of salaries have actually stayed the same or have increased. The other 4 per cent are unidentified—that makes 100 per cent—and are contracts that are so complicated that neither union nor employer group can assess whether there has been a rise or a fall in actual salaries.

When one State government—following the example of the New South Wales Government—seeks to make changes which will benefit employees and which will make Australia more competitive it is castigated by the Government that has brought about the closures and the recession. It is a height of hypocrisy both from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his Government to behave as they have towards Australian manufacturing industries. The recession that we had to have has bludgeoned Australian industry to death.

Today, we belatedly have the second part of a change to anti-dumping legislation. It is a natural follow-on because if there is going to be appropriate removal of protection the international cheats need to be stopped. That is, those people who would take advantage of wiping out Australian industry by using false subsidies or falsely priced goods to undercut Australian manufacturers, thereby putting more of them out of business and gaining complete access to the market for themselves. Having destroyed their opponents, they then come into the market and range supreme. It seems to have been the Government's objective to preside over this.

The Senate was the first to decide that something should be done and so the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology took this issue up and looked at the anti-dumping procedures. Belatedly, Senator Button and the Government decided something ought to be done. The Senate Committee looked at the whole range of mechanisms under the anti-dumping procedures and came forward with an invaluable report for the Parliament. But long before that it should have been the Government's role to take an initiative and to understand that its policy was crucifying Australian industries by forcing people out of work and causing closures. As my colleague the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) has said, the Government has caused record unemployment and record bankruptcies as industry after industry has lost important elements.

The great cry out there in the Australian manufacturing industries at the moment is, `We won't survive until there is a change of government. We can't hang on'. Those industries are looking at a week by week process as to whether they can keep their doors open. Victoria is just like a scorched earth desert with all the landscape and trees destroyed. Driving through Dandenong, that great manufacturing heartland of Victoria, one sees factory after factory with empty car parks or with only two or three cars in those car parks. People are just offering a care and maintenance basis only to those great manufacturing plants.

The Government goes on belatedly taking steps to rectify some of its crazy policies and crazy decisions but with no incentive, no understanding of the totality of what is needed for a dynamic, effective, competitive Australian manufacturing industry. What the Government did was to reduce tariffs by a flick of a pen which is an easy thing to do. It is an administrative process for the Parliament or the Minister. It has no effect anywhere else. It does not mean any hard work in getting down and talking to people in manufacturing industries to try to solve some of their cost of employment problems, their cost of component problems, their cost of raw material problems, the cost of transport problems and the cost of the infrastructure that they have to put up with. None of that is dealt with.

The cost of electricity alone is criminal in some areas of Australia. Victoria has treated some of its great manufacturing plants in a criminal way with what it has done in order to falsely subsidise the private consumer. I have no problem with the consumer being subsidised, but it has jacked up the price of electricity to major manufacturers to a point where it is an intolerable overhead.

We have seen the policies of this Government and its counterpart governments in the States working to destroy Australian employment capacity all for the mad, ideological sake of trying to keep an accord in place and trying to remain friends with the leaders of the union movement. It is an impossible regime that recognised belatedly that the international cheats will come into the Australian market and try to knock off Australian industry by falsely subsidised or falsely priced goods. Therefore, amendments are needed to the anti-dumping legislation. The coalition is not opposing the current second leg and, as the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) said in his second reading speech:

The proposed amendments represent the final change to Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing provisions which were announced by the Government on 5 December 1991 following a review of anti-dumping policy and administrative arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is a great shame because the Government is nowhere near finished in this area. Today we have heard members of the Government quoting Australia's excellent record in these areas and comparing the time scales that are available to Australian manufacturers in order to bring dumping cases. I notice the Minister put out a statement that was reported in the Focal Point, which is the Government's propaganda rag that goes around the place. I do not know who reads it, but in it I picked up the Minister's claim that we have now got one of the most dynamic and forward looking—the adjectives which pour out of this thing are completely false—processes in the world.

PARA.TAB: When one comes to analyse the anti-dumping processes that the rest of the world uses, the time factor is basically irrelevant. In an excellent presentation given by Brian Gallagher from the Australian Customs Service here in Parliament House on Australian anti-dumping processes and on other competing or relevant countries, he drew comparisons between Europe, the United States and Australia. He clearly set out the fact that in America and in Europe the time scale factors do not mean a thing because there are so many other mechanisms in place. I quote from that address where Mr Gallagher uses an example. He stated:
As J. Michael Finger, from the World Bank, and Tracey Murray, a professor of the University of Arkansas, indicated in an article in the August 1990 edition of the Journal on World Trade:
"Petitioner's—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, a petitioner for anti-dumping—
interests are served by any outcome or influence that will disadvantage his competitors. A formal anti-dumping duty order is only one of the ways.

In drawing this conclusion, Finger and Murray referred to the lack of success of dumping and countervailing applications that I mentioned above, but pointed out that in nearly half the 774 cases lodged between 1980 and 1988 the desired result for the domestic industry was achieved by negotiated, or `voluntary' export restraints.

The hoops that people have to jump through in order to import goods into the United States are considerable and they include: the way in which charges are applied, the way in which the process of damage is assessed, and the bonds that are placed on goods. These make it quite incomparable with the factors that the Australian Government has been espousing. The Ministers in the Australian Government need to do a bit of study about what the rest of the world is doing. They are so naive in their approach to these matters that one wonders whether they in fact really understand what they are doing.

PARA.TAB: The Minister's claims about Australia's approach to anti-dumping are grossly exaggerated, as are his claims in his second reading speech. One of the key factors that could still be implemented without going into the mechanisms adopted by the Europeans or the Americans, and something which the industry is currently crying out for, is a more expedient hearing of the process so that industry can get a decision as to whether there is dumping. The drawn-out, legalistic, crazy approach that we have had, which has changed slightly under the Government, but needs to go further—without becoming protectionist—is obvious. A newsletter put out by the KJC organisation entitled the Canberra Report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government recently revised Australia's anti-dumping system and Senator Button announced the outcome of the review in the Senate on Thursday, 5 December 1991.

Unlike the Coalition's proposals, however, the Government review failed to come to grips with the real issues of concern to Industry in combating unfair trade—and in particular with the need for prompt and effective remedial action when dumping/subsidisation occurs.

The real issue is the time factor. The coalition proposes that there should be a big change in the time factors. That is what the industry wants. Industry needs to know where it is going. It needs certainty. The Government, step by step, has first of all created a great chaos, a wrecking of industry, and then, belatedly, tried to apply changes to anti-dumping processes, without recognising the full scope that is needed to effectively deal with these issues.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has a complete package. Yes, we believe that there should be a run-down of protection for Australian industry. Yes, we do believe that it is possible, unless that is done, for people such as Halfpenny to grab every bit of extra protection as unjustified wage claims. Australia has been in a vicious cycle in which wage claims jack up tariff protection, which jacks up wage claims, which jack up tariff protection. That is the way we have gone on. It is time to stop it.

If the Government is going to remove tariffs, it must give some incentive support to the industries that it is exposing to world competition. That is where our complete package comes into real life. We will provide an incentive by removing $20 billion worth of taxes currently applied to industry. Industry will have the advantage of the payroll taxes, the wholesale sales taxes and those other five taxes being abolished, amounting to $20 billion worth of support to Australian industry, plus strong anti-dumping processes, to put a bottom in the whole thing so that the cheats do not get in.

The Government has moved in a certain direction, but the thing that is lacking in this anti-dumping area to conclude the process is a speeding-up of the hearings. It is our proposal that within five days we can establish whether or not there is a case to be heard and within 60 days we can give a determination; then there is a review period. The Canberra Report, put out by KJC, said:

SPEECH.PARA: And it is further understood that the Coalition, when in Government, intends to make proper use of the provisions that exist in the GATT (and in Australia's anti-dumping legislation)—but so far infrequently if ever used in this country—for duties to be levied retroactively in certain circumstances, and during the period of provisional measures, on dumped/subsidised goods entered into Australia 90 days prior to the notification of the provisional measures.

There it is: a complete package of reducing impost on Australian manufacturing industries; one of encouraging competitiveness and a reasonable, applicable, realistic and internationally understandable anti-dumping process. That is something the Government has not done. I am extremely critical of the Government's attitudes in these matters. I know that my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) will further support the previous speakers and me on this issue. It is critical to preserve our Australian manufacturing industries. They will meet the challenge that we are putting to them because they know that it is realistic and it is one that will offer them real opportunity. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) are the Government's final step, initially announced on 5 December 1991, to introduce a new system for the imposition and collection of anti-dumping and countervailing duties. For the first time, interim duties will be collected on each importation of goods that is subject to anti-dumping measures. To the present, it has been relatively easy for exporters of products dumped in Australia from other nations to raise the price to a normal level for that country and, hence, to try to avoid dumping duties in Australia. These new provisions will make this avoidance procedure much more difficult, as interim duties will still be payable even if the export price increases.

PARA.TAB: This Bill's most important feature is probably that it places an onus on the importer, who might have interim duties imposed on him by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), to show cause why any excess duties should be repaid. A number of industries and farmers have been very keen to bring this about. Everywhere we have gone around the country, people have been advocating this. The coalition is pleased with this change.

This is different from putting the onus on importers to ensure that imported goods are not dumped. Neither Australian law nor the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade condemns dumping, as such. A company can seek action against dumping only if there is material injury. Again, there is a considerable amount of conflict on the definition of `material injury' as it affects local industry. If this were not so, consumers would lose by not having cheaper goods available, as would many industries which use the imports as the basis for their manufacturing.

Dumping cannot be proved by just having cheap goods; they must be cheap goods causing more than an insignificant level of damage in market share to the producers in Australia. I support the Anti-Dumping Authority's interpretation of the criterion for anti-dumping action, as noted in its 1990-91 annual report as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . dumping, of itself, is causing or is threatening material injury to the Australian industry producing like goods to those which are being dumped or is hindering the establishment of such an industry . . .

Again, `like goods' is a matter of some debate. Dumping claims are always contentious. This is emphasised by the eight out of the 43 proposals investigated by the Anti-Dumping Authority between July 1991 and October 1992 in which the Anti-Dumping Authority disagreed with the initial findings of the Australian Customs Service.

PARA.TAB: The way these reforms are being implemented by these Bills is in accordance with GATT and also with the way in which the European nations, as well as the USA, deal with the problem of dumping. If an Australian Customs Service inquiry now finds that there is a difference between the exported price of goods from another country and their normal price, the margin will be the interim dumping duty. Should the export price fall further, that difference will also be collected.

It is important that there is no re-emergence of the failed doctrine of protectionism, which was referred to by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). It calls for a monitoring of imports to ensure that they are not being dumped, and will not solve Australia's chronic balance of trade problems. The evidence before the Anti-Dumping Authority is quite strong. Some industries can suffer from much greater contractions in demand from other sources than the level to which they are affected by dumping.

The vinyl floor sheeting industry was a fairly recent example. Although information available to Customs showed that the sheeting had been dumped into Australia from the United Kingdom, there was no evidence of material injury available to either Customs or the Anti-Dumping Authority. This was because the Australian market for the product fell by 16 per cent between 1987-88 and 1989-90, but the dumped exports from the UK fell by 26 per cent, and other imports, which no-one claimed were dumped into Australia, rose by 20 per cent.

Initially, many people would have said, `Yes, the vinyl sheeting industry has been hurt', but when the figures were examined some other cause apart from dumping, such as the Prime Minister's recession we had to have, was the major cause why the industry was not performing as it previously had. I support the shadow Minister in our coalition's position that the important thing is the timetable of the dumping procedures. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up a couple of matters that the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) raised when he said that many of us have ascribed the connotation `dumped' upon goods which have come into Australia as healthy competition for Australian goods. I hope he does not mislabel anybody on this side of the House in that way because we understand healthy competition very clearly: we understand it absolutely. We did not all come from the various rabbit burrows of the ACTU or from academia. We understand that competition is the only way in which this country will get into a healthy international position, and having to have a manufacturing base and a services base which will take us forward into the next century.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member said that this is the shortest possible time that these procedures can go through, and compared our procedures with those of other countries. I can assure the honourable member and the Government that we on this side of the House have been through what is possible with people who have been involved in anti-dumping procedures all over the world. We will be making a productivity increase in regard to these procedures, and we do not believe that we have got to the fastest position now. It is just a tragedy that the Government has not had the courage to increase the pace of these procedures, and we can go to a far foreshortened one, or a series of them, as I said a minute ago. We will improve those procedures further by coming close to halving the timeframes required for anti-dumping and countervailing duties action.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank my colleagues in the Opposition for giving me the opportunity to sum up in the second reading debate on the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2). I want to address particularly the issue of time, because I think it is fair to put on record what is the reality rather than the objective. The objective of the Opposition of 60 days is a noble objective that cannot be achieved. If we are going to comply with GATT, we must give 30 days for all parties to register submissions. Under GATT again, there must be seven days to allow for delivery of all documents.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's proposal allows a total of 60 days. That means there would be 23 calendar days left for the Australian Customs Service to make sure of its preliminary finding. That means that we would have to get Customs officers overseas to undertake normal values in a 23-day period. What in effect would happen under that Opposition proposal is that we would have continuous negative findings because of our obligations under the GATT. In effect, that extends the process to 165 days. There was some criticism that this proposal had taken so long to come into effect. In fact, the previous anti-dumping regime—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten years.

—In 1988 we set up the new system, as the honourable member for Barker is aware. We gave it a three-year gestation period, then an automatic review in 1991, with these legislative changes coming out of that. It is a very difficult and complicated area, as the honourable member for Barker knows, with a lot of misconceptions, particularly in the rural sector, about what is dumped and what is a cheap imported product. To get it right—and we think we have got it right—has been a difficult task, and it is with great pleasure that I see these particular reforms coming to fruition.

Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had some histrionics in the House of Representatives in the last couple of days. It seems that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) regards our policies as being designed to do to Australia what he has already done to Australia, but tomorrow we are back to reality because then there will be some unemployment numbers coming out. They will be bad news for the Government, and reality will come home to the Prime Minister when these new and tragic unemployment figures appear. In a couple of weeks there will be more bad news for the Government because the national accounts figures will be out. They will almost certainly blow out of the water the assumption of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) of a growth rate of 3 per cent for the current financial year.

PARA.TAB: This Government has created an unfair society. We now have more than one million unemployed. We have a growing number of people under the present Government's policies who are unemployed for life. We have large numbers of unskilled or poorly educated young people who have little or no hope of ever getting a permanent job, and we have another bunch of people who, although employed, are terrified that in the course of the next year or so, under the present Government's policies, they will lose their jobs. One family in four has no employed parent.

These comments are relevant to the Qantas Sale Bill, firstly, because the Qantas sale episode is an example of the Government slowly and reluctantly following coalition policy. For five years now we have said that the ownership of Qantas should be transferred from the public to the private sector. We have been belted by the Government on that issue, and were accused of `stealing the family jewels' and all this sort of stuff by the Prime Minister when he was the Treasurer. But now slowly and reluctantly the Government has adopted our policy. It has adopted our policy in violation of its own Party policy. It is not Labor Party policy to privatise 100 per cent of Qantas; it is Labor Party policy to privatise only 49 per cent of Qantas.

These comments are relevant to the Qantas Bill because we have an example of a Cabinet, of a Prime Minister and of a Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) who are unable to keep to a schedule. It is an example of ministerial incompetence and an example of how to keep an economy under sedation. The people who are really suffering from this incompetence are the unemployed. The jobs that might have been created by a revitalised Qantas have been lost or delayed. The investment that might have created more jobs and increased national productivity has been lost or postponed. Four senior Ministers have been responsible for this: the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley). The senior Ministers on the Government front bench have been responsible for this Qantas sale fiasco. That Government front bench is so tired of office that it has had to fight the next election on our policies instead of attempting to resolve the economic difficulties that it has created. Instead of implementing policies to pick up the recession that we had to have, the Government is trying to put the focus on us.

Instead of attempting to resolve the economic difficulties that it has created, instead of implementing policies to pick up the recession that we had to have, the Government is trying to put the focus on us. That is because the Government has no policies of its own. It has no answers to Australia's economic difficulties.

What is happening in this Qantas sale fiasco is further evidence of the Government's inability even to conduct a simple sale. It is further evidence of its mismanagement not only of the economy but of this issue. The history of this Government's aviation policies and of the Qantas privatisation program is a history of delay and incomprehension. I have no doubt that my colleague the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), when he gets his chance in this truncated debate, will have something to say about the extraordinary mismanagement of the Government's aviation policies.

Not one Government Minister has an understanding of the aviation industry or of the processes of privatisation. I am pleased that the Minister for Finance has now come to the chamber, because he ought to be listening to what I have been saying about the mismanagement of the economy and of the process of privatising Qantas.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a lot of rubbish.
—We heard from the Minister today about rubbish. We heard from him today about what Kennett is doing in Victoria, yet the Minister's Party practically destroyed Victoria.
—I did not say anything today.

—We have been recently told by the Minister—who is interjecting on me now—that the sale process would proceed, after many delays, this calendar year. Now we learn that it has been put back until at least March of next year. I draw the Minister's attention to the explanatory memorandum in which, under the `Table of financial impacts', it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The table. . . has been prepared based on the following assumptions. . . :
.the substantial minority sale day is 1 March 1993;
If this process were really going to be completed in this calendar year, why would the Government put that in? It is just another attempt to—

PARA.TAB: Mr Willis interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister said that the trade sale process would be completed this calendar year. Now we see, by his own admission, that it will be delayed at least until 1 March next year. The Minister cannot even run an assets sales task force properly. He had one, but now he has a second one. What a way to run a department! A department is not run by setting up separate streams. A department is run by giving people a job to do and vesting the authority in them.
—You've never run a department. What would you know about it?

—I have run a hell of a lot more things than the Minister has—and a hell of a lot better, too. The Government has so little understanding of privatisation that it has ignored the chance to spell out the advantages of staff shareholdings in the Bill, despite the fact that this is alleged to be Labor Party policy. If the Minister does not know his own policy and how to organise, how can he be expected to run his Department?

PARA.TAB: This matter of participation in the ownership of Qantas by the employees is an important one. The Minister made a glancing reference to it in his seconding reading speech in relation to previous discussions, yet he passes up the opportunity to enshrine in this legislation a mechanism whereby the employees could participate in the ownership of Qantas.

It is very important to the coalition and to its industrial relations policy that employees are put in a position where they can participate in the ownership. Under our industrial relations regime and under our workplace agreements, we would envisage that negotiations between employer and employee would lead to a situation where the motivation for the employees was greater as a result of their having part ownership of the organisation, or in this case the enterprise, in which they work.

This oversight, this failure to include in the legislation a provision for employee ownership, arises because essentially the Government is treating privatisation as a money-grubbing exercise. What the Government wants out of the Qantas sale is money—just money. It does not care about the wider benefits of privatisation. It is not using this privatisation to create a more competitive framework. It is not using this privatisation to subject Qantas and its management to forces associated with the financial markets and the share markets. It is not using this privatisation to encourage employee ownership in Qantas.

The Government has even failed to spell out in the documents associated with this Bill the extent to which there will be a broader spread of shareholding in the community. It is simply treating this as a money-grubbing exercise. The reason it is doing that is that it has some real difficulties with its Budget deficit. It will have even more difficulties if, as we expect, the Government does not complete this privatisation by 30 June 1993. The real reasons for privatisation, and the ones that the Government has failed to grasp, are increased efficiency and productivity, reduced union control, easier capital raisings and, most of all, more jobs.

There are some other comments that the coalition parties would like to make on this Bill. I suggest to the Minister for Finance that he make a public statement as soon as possible, spelling out the entire program for the privatisation of Qantas, so that the employees can be in a position to determine what they want to do, so as to assist those associated with advising the Government on the way in which the Qantas shares will be publicly listed, and so that the share markets can adjust.

I suggest to the Minister for Finance that the Government should amend the Bill in the Senate in two other ways. It should be amended to make it clear that the Government can at any time use the Qantas organisation or assets for national security or defence purposes. The second thing that I suggest to the Minister is in the context of clause 7(1)(f). There should be some modification to that clause. As I understand it, Qantas flies to Taiwan under the name Australia-Asia Airlines. If it continued to do that, it would be demonstrably in breach of clause 7(1)(f), so some modification needs to be made to the Bill to ensure that Qantas's interests are protected in that way.

If the Minister for Finance will amend the Bill in the Senate in respect of those two matters, he will have the coalition's full support when it comes back to the House of Representatives—not only full support but, because this matter has been raised by the coalition now, we would not need to detain the House for any length of time in discussing those two matters.

I want to conclude my comments in order to give my colleague the honourable member for Fadden a chance to speak on this Bill given this absolutely disgraceful guillotine that is sitting over the top of us. Jobs are what privatisation is all about, and jobs are what the privatisation of Qantas should be all about. Unemployment and jobs are what the next election will be about. The Prime Minister will get a startling reminder of those facts when he reels before the unemployment figures tomorrow. The coalition parties welcome the Qantas Sale Bill 1992. It has long been our policy to privatise Qantas. Despite the shortcomings associated with the management of the privatisation, we are glad to see this legislation before us, and it has our support.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale), finished his contribution on a very sour note in seeking to pre-empt what unemployment figures might be out tomorrow and issuing an ultimatum to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that he should be very disturbed about the higher unemployment figures. There was almost a touch of glee in the expectation that unemployment figures might be higher tomorrow. I hope that is not the view of the honourable member, because in the contributions he makes in this House he usually shows more concern for his fellow Australians. I trust he joins me in the hope that the unemployment figures which come out tomorrow show that there has been an increase in employment throughout the nation.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member would be aware that during the last 10 years there has been an increase of over one million in the number of Australians who are employed throughout the country. Despite the fact that during the recession total employment has fallen several hundred thousand, we still have one million more people in employment today than we had when the Hawke Government was elected in 1983. I will let that matter go and concentrate on the proposal before the House to sell the Government's shareholding in Qantas Airways Ltd.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), who is at the table, deserves full credit for the way in which he has steered this proposal through some pretty rough waters during a difficult period. The measure we are discussing today will be in the interests of Australia, in the interests of Qantas and its employees and, more importantly, in the interests of the Australian travelling public. They are the reasons that this Minister deserves full credit for negotiating this proposal through some rocky waters.

The previous speaker was critical of the proposal we are negotiating because, he claimed, it is in breach of the ALP platform. When he makes criticisms like that he tempts me to compare the Labor Party's processes of working out these issues with those that apply in his own Party. Of course, a Liberal Party national convention has all the power of a Tasmanian CWA meeting in seeking to bind the Liberal Party to policies which it should pursue. That is why more people who attend those Liberal Party conventions spend more time at the balls and the afternoon teas than they do seeking to argue and persuade delegates in negotiating the policies which might be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't talk nonsense.

—The shadow Minister interjects that that is nonsense. How much consultation was there amongst Liberal Party members, or even the Parliamentary Liberal Party, to introduce a 15 per cent consumption tax? We all know that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith), perhaps with some consultation with the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), decided what that proposal would be and how it would affect all the different sectors of the Australian economy. There was no consultation with the Liberal Party's parliamentary party, no discussion at the Liberal Party national conference, or the National Party conference for that matter. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that during a recent Queensland National Party forum there was some criticism of the impact that proposal would have on tourism.

PARA.TAB: For the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), to criticise the Labor Party for the way we go about consulting our membership and giving our membership a say in determining our Party's policy on Qantas and other issues really shows a great deal of hide on his part. Nevertheless, my Party believes that there should be some private ownership in Qantas.

When the Government set out on this journey it intended to sell only 49 per cent of Qantas and keep 51 per cent in the hands of the Australian Government. People may well ask: why did the Government decide to sell more than the 49 per cent of Qantas originally proposed? The reason, I think, goes back to the three aims which I believe are behind this Bill: is selling more than 49 per cent of Qantas in the interests of the Australian community; is it in the interests of Qantas and its employees; and is it in the interests of the Australian travelling public? I think it meets each of those three conditions.

The Government has introduced some very radical changes in the Australian aviation industry. It has made the historic decision to open up a trans-Tasman aviation market. Negotiations with New Zealand have already resulted in more competition in that trans-Tasman market. I believe we have set out on a journey which will ensure that air fares throughout that trans-Tasman market will remain quite competitive for many years to come.

On 1 November the Government's decision to allow Qantas to fly domestically came into effect. Perhaps members of the public in the gallery have already seen some of the advertisements which Qantas has placed in the newspapers advertising cheap air fares. I am sure that Qantas will be offering those very competitive fares for many years to come, because it can fly Australians at relatively cheap marginal cost. That is another measure that is good for the Australian travelling public. In the not too distant future there will be an increased number of flights by Ansett. Perhaps one day there will even be Compass flights travelling internationally.

Those measures are quite radical. I think the Minister for Finance was responsible for one of the most important decisions for Australian aviation: the decision to allow Qantas to purchase Australian Airlines, to allow those two airlines to amalgamate. I believe the combined organisation has the capacity to make substantial savings in the total cost structure of that combined entity.

The shadow Minister for tourism and aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), would certainly be aware that the management of both Qantas and Australian has been doing a lot of work on ways in which to rationalise operations and reduce costs for the combined entity. That is a proposal which I think will improve—that is, lower air fares for the Australian travelling public and allowing the combined entity to remain as competitive as possible with other international airlines. We all know that the large American airlines—United, Continental and others—when seeking to sell international air fares through their companies offer very cheap additional sector flights throughout their own domestic networks in the United States. It has been unfair that Qantas has not been able to attract tourists to Australia away from those airlines by offering cheap air fares on the Australian domestic market. The Minister for Finance is the Minister responsible, with a bit of help from the current Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), for making sure that that amalgamation has taken place so well and so quickly.

There may still be one or two members of the Labor Party who have some doubt about this proposal to sell 100 per cent of Qantas. There are two reasons that we have a great deal of affection for Qantas and a great deal of affection for not only the airline but for the people who work there and the commitment they have to the airline and Australia. There are two main reasons that I think it is in their interests and the interests of Qantas and Australia for this sale to go ahead.

The first reason is that if this sale did not take place Qantas would face a great deal of difficulty because of the debt to equity ratio it now has. To be able to remain competitive Qantas has had to buy aircraft which are extremely expensive. I think a jumbo jet these days costs over $250m. If Qantas is to maintain its reputation as a carrier with some of the most up-to-date aircraft, then it has to borrow a lot of money to ensure it can remain competitive with other airlines flying into and out of Australia.

As a result, Qantas has a very difficult debt equity ratio. If the Government were not prepared to sell any shares in Qantas, then the Government would have to face up to a major capital injection of the order of perhaps $1 1/2 billion. That would be $1 1/2 billion which would have to come from rail and road capital works projects, increases in pensions which are due next January or other measures which those of us on this side of the House believe are required to give the economy a boost and provide greater equity in the community.

I would strongly oppose a Labor government seeking to divert funds from social programs so that a Japanese tourist flying from Tokyo to Kingsford-Smith Airport could be in an Australian government owned airline instead of an Australian owned airline. I do not think the tourist would care whether it was a government owned or an Australian owned airline. That is the first reason why members of the Labor Party strongly support this proposal to sell 100 per cent of Qantas.

The second reason why I think it is important is that it is in the long term strategic interests of Qantas for it to have a strategic shareholder which offers it support in international aviation negotiations for air traffic rights. That might be an argument in favour of two of the bidders rather than the third, which is not a large player in international scene. I believe that certainly there is the potential for that strategic shareholder to be able to offer some support to Qantas in future negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by `support'?

—For the education of the shadow Minister, let us take a theoretical example using British Airways. If British Airways is successful in bidding for a strategic shareholding in Qantas then it would have a vested interest in Qantas remaining profitable. If Qantas is applying for additional air traffic rights into the United Kingdom—which is where British Airways often has a fair amount of say—then that would mean that that airline would have an extra person on that side of the table.

PARA.TAB: If the honourable member is not aware of such a scenario, I refer him to the fact that Air New Zealand was able to negotiate very favourable air traffic entry rights into Japan because JAL, in addition to Qantas, was a shareholder of Air New Zealand. Because there was a Japanese shareholder Air New Zealand was able to use that strategic shareholding to help increase its chances of getting a favourable outcome. I hope that helps to explain why I believe it is very important.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it does raise the question as to why you had a 25 per cent limit on one.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Order! The honourable member for Bruce!

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very interesting interjection and it shows the Opposition's real agenda on this. The shadow Minister believes that if British Airways, Singapore Airlines, Air New Zealand or someone else is allowed to own 25 per cent of Qantas and that helps Qantas, then we should allow that other airline to own up to 100 per cent of Qantas. The Opposition's view is that there should not be any limits at all on what the foreign strategic shareholding should be.

PARA.TAB: That is where the Government and the Opposition part ways. We believe that Qantas should remain an Australian airline. We believe that it is important to protect Australia's national interest through—what we call—the golden share. That allows us to guarantee that there will not be any more than 35 per cent overseas equity in total. It guarantees that the name Qantas will always be there and that Qantas will not have its name changed to British Airways, Air Kangaroo or some other name. At the same time, the golden share guarantees that the head office will remain in Australia, that the main operational bases will be in Australia and that the majority of directors on the board will be Australians.

That golden share is embedded by legislation into the Articles of Association. In the unlikely and unhappy event that there is a Liberal government elected at the next Federal election, it could only allow 100 per cent of Qantas to be sold to foreigners, to move offshore, to change its name, or a majority of overseas directors on the board by altering the Articles of Association by trying to amend the Act. That would require legislation to pass through both Houses of this Parliament.

In the very unlikely and unhappy event that the Opposition wins the next election, I believe that it is extremely unlikely that it will control both Houses of the Australian Parliament. This will ensure that it will not be able to allow, as it has indicated tonight, 100 per cent of Qantas to be sold to foreign persons.

I was surprised at how few criticisms the Opposition had of the proposal. Oppositions being oppositions have to criticise, but I had hoped that it would have come in tonight and in a spirit of bipartisanship congratulated the Minister on negotiating this proposal through these very troubled waters. Perhaps the next speaker will congratulate the Minister for Finance.

The first speaker for the Opposition was critical that there is nothing in the legislation which provides for an employee shareholding in Qantas. That was one of the major criticisms he had of the proposal. It is quite clear that he is not aware that the Minister for Finance, from the very outset, has made it clear that it would be a condition of sale that there be an employee share ownership scheme. That is another reason why he should be congratulating this Minister and not seeking to criticise him. The scheme does not need to be in a legislative proposal, and the Minister has made it clear that that there will be employee share ownership scheme as a condition of sale. The reason the Government believes it is a good thing is that it will help encourage productivity and, I am sure, a greater commitment on the part of the employees of Qantas.

For those reasons, I believe that this proposal is not only good for Qantas and its employees but also good for Australia. It is going to be good for the air travelling public. It is a proposal which was negotiated through some pretty troubled waters and it is a credit to this Minister that this has been negotiated in such a manner that Australia's interests have been protected and the interests of Qantas as a whole have been protected.

It should not be forgotten that Qantas has been criticised by one or two members of this House in days gone by. The next speaker has made some strenuous criticisms of Qantas and has argued that we should not be as protective of Qantas as we have been. I think it is fair to say that if Qantas had its way it would have preferred that the Government had not made the radical changes it has made to aviation policy by introducing the trans-Tasman single aviation market. This allows Qantas to fly domestically, the domestic airlines to fly overseas and quite a few new air routes to be opened up and negotiated.

The Government has done this because it is in the interests of the Australian tourism industry. Each year we set new records for the number of international tourists that come to Australia and spend money in Australia. This helps create jobs in Australia. This has been one of the great success stories of the 1980s. A lot of credit is due to Qantas, Paul Hogan, John Brown and many others.

I think it is a great worry to all of us who have watched the tourism industry in Australia grow so quickly and create so many jobs that the Opposition has a proposal which threatens the viability of that industry. It is a proposal that will result in overseas tourists having to pay a new 15 per cent consumption tax when they make purchases of goods and services in Australia. If members of the public in the gallery are choosing between a holiday in Fiji or a holiday in Cairns, then there will be a new 15 per cent tax on that holiday in Australia; a new 15 per cent penalty on doing the right thing and trying to create jobs for Australians. That is why I can understand their concern about these proposals.

As I have made clear, we on this side House will be doing all we can to ensure that that does not take place. We are very pleased that the Minister has been able to bring this proposal to its fruition. I am sure it is in the interests of Australia, Qantas and the travelling public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the years the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has made a number of intelligent contributions to this House. Unfortunately, his contribution today was not one of them. I must say that he is fairly wide of the mark in terms of his interpretation of some of the great aviation policy initiatives that we have had from this Government.

PARA.TAB: The real tragedy is that this privatisation of Qantas is happening in 1992-93, and not in about 1975 or 1976. As one who advocated the privatisation of Qantas in 1978, I am pleased that the process is finally starting to come to fruition—although none of us really knows exactly what we will have at the end of the day when the time limit of March 1993 comes up. That will be fascinating. The most fascinating part is that the Opposition parties, who will then be in government, will be left with the mess. It will be fascinating to find exactly what in fact is there.

It is also quite fascinating if we go back to 1990, to that very big dispute within the Australian Labor Party and the special conference about the privatisation of Qantas. A little over two years later we are in the House now addressing the whole business of its privatisation. In the last two years we have seen the demise of the Soviet Union, we have seen the split of Aeroflot—and, in fact, we have already seen great chunks of Aeroflot being privatised. But not here. We are taking as long as we possibly can.

I do not say lightly that the worry is that we are probably too late. It does not matter what government it was, of what particular colour; Australia really started to miss the boat in the development of international aviation during the early and mid-1970s because it was at that time that there were massive changes happening in world aviation circles. Qantas had been part of that whole British Commonwealth group of international airlines. Honourable members would remember those old pink parts on the world map and the air routes which linked them. There were cross-arrangements between Qantas and BOAC, as it was then, and Air India, South African Airways and the other major players. That started to break up and we then saw an emergence of the ASEAN carriers. That is where we did not learn our lesson, and that is where we were caught. It was at that time, when the ASEAN countries were starting to emerge, that we should have been making some very definitive changes to our whole approach to aviation. Indeed, that was the time when we should have seen the proper capitalisation of Qantas so that the right expansion could take place.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) smiles, but which are the world's four most profitable airlines? British Airways, Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific and Thai International. British Airways is a 100 per cent privatised airline, making a very real play on the requirement to have a staff shareholding in that particular operation. The honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale) was spot on: we must make sure that within a privatised Qantas we have maximum staff shareholding, because that is all part of the secret. That is all part of the success of British Airways being able to get where it has.

Singapore Airlines has government money in it, but there is also a very large private sector holding. We know of its tremendous successes. Singapore Airlines is now at the point where it goes off to the Boeing Corporation and pays cash for brand new 747 400 aircraft. It has only about 60 on order at the moment! Along it goes to Seattle with its bag of money and says, `What's the best deal you can do for cash?'. While airlines such as Qantas have had to negotiate some pretty torrid deals for their aircraft acquisitions, that advantage in itself has put Singapore Airlines a long way ahead.

Cathay Pacific—which is, of course, part of the Swire group and is basically very much a privatised airline—came in with profits in excess of $400m last year. Thai International, which is undergoing a privatisation process at the moment, is also one of the most highly profitable airlines.

So, as I say, the early and mid-1970s is really when the changes should have been made. We should have been getting out of that protective cocoon of the old British Commonwealth routes and made changes. We should have got Qantas set up with a proper game plan and with proper planning, and perhaps then we would not have the financial difficulties that we have at the moment.

I would like to make reference to one quote that the honourable member for Dobell made in his contribution tonight, and that concerns the opening up of the Tasman. Obviously, under the CER arrangements, the Opposition is very much in favour of that. We would want to see that transpire to its nth degree as soon as we possibly can. It is fascinating that part of the One Nation project was, of course, to make sure that that was all opened up by the end of the year. I was going through the One Nation statement earlier today and I saw that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at the time said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government expects that Australian and Ansett Airlines will be operating across the Tasman by 1993 at the latest.
He does not have long to go. I really wonder what is going to happen there and whether we should not be looking at moving a little faster in opening up that whole area.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Dobell was talking about strategic alliances—and obviously there is an argument abroad that if we can get some of that foreign investment in place, it can be strategically helpful—but when the time comes and the bidders come up to the gate, and on the assumption that the British Airways-Air New Zealand combine and Singapore Airlines are the bidders, what in fact will happen if we do not have the buyers there, or if the amount that is offered for those private stakes in Qantas is not acceptable to the government of the day? We know, as the honourable member for Bruce mentioned, that this is very much about getting some money into play for the $7 billion extra in the Budget last year, but in reality we do not want to sell short on Qantas.

One of the difficulties we could well have is that, if we accept those lower bids, the whole of the exercise could be devalued. So it could well be that, when we get to that particular time, we may have to have a look at another whole new process for the privatisation of Qantas. Qantas itself is talking about an absolute public float. Maybe that is right, too.

In that respect, it is interesting that the prime player has to have 25 per cent. It has been put to me that, if we are going to reduce the holding to that size, we may be better off taking it down to 20 per cent to give some institutional investors a bigger slice of the action. That might push up the value in that trade sale.

The tragedy of this debate is simply the fact that one of the most significant pieces of aviation legislation in this House for many years is under guillotine and we are constrained by the time. In the last couple of moments that I have available to me, I just raise with the Minister a couple of areas of this Bill that cause us some worry. My colleague the honourable member for Bruce made reference in particular to the situation regarding the national defence requirement, or the emergency requirement, with Qantas. Under the old regime Qantas did not have that requirement. One probably can do it with a golden share. It was interesting, for example, that during the Gulf War the Americans moved all their troops into the Gulf states from the United States using civilian airliners. That was under the acquisition provisions that apply in the United States for private airlines.

The honourable member for Bruce also mentioned the Australia-Asia airline that operates into Taipei. He referred to the Qantas Sale Bill. I refer to clause 7 (e) and (f) under part 3 of that Bill. Under section (e) the explanatory memorandum says:

SPEECH.PARA: Qantas' company name must not be changed to a name that does not include the expression "Qantas".

I think we need some clarification of that because that Taipei market is an expanding market and there are some tremendous opportunities there. I would hate to see any access to that market diminished purely because of an oversight in that Bill. The other one—and this may be a long bow but I think it probably needs clarification, too—is under that same clause of the Bill, but in subclause (f). It reads:
Qantas must only conduct scheduled international air transport passenger services under its company name or under a registered business name that includes the expression "Qantas".

What would happen, for example, if the buy were undertaken by Singapore Airlines and if, at some stretch of the imagination, Singapore Airlines convinced the company that it may be better to act as a megacarrier and perhaps paint the Qantas aircraft in Singapore colours? Does the legislation allow that, even if we have `Singapore Airlines' all down the side of an aircraft with a tiny dash and a tiny `Qantas' on the side of it? I just wonder whether there should not be more emphasis on that to make sure that the flying kangaroo is still well and truly displayed.

PARA.TAB: My time is just about up. The Opposition will not be opposing these particular Bills. We would like to see this process completed as soon as possible. It is not the Opposition's intention to sell 100 per cent of Qantas to overseas interests because that is physically impossible under the international aviation regime. There are requirements that state that when it comes to bilaterals there can be no more than a 35 per cent foreign ownership of airlines. In fact, in the case of British Airways in the United States when its foreign ownership actually hit about 37 1/2 per cent, the company was in a few difficulties.

The other thing I would like to see in a future debate is the development of the issue which has been raised by the honourable member for Dobell about what happens after the privatisation if there are no overseas bidders, or if we do not accept the overseas bidders and the opportunity of perhaps developing our own megacarrier in the south-west Pacific. That would require looking at what the future may hold for Air New Zealand and perhaps the Pacific Island airlines.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that this Bill be now read a second time.
