PROCTEXT.PARA: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING BILL 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National Training Authority Bill 1992 and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill 1992 are designed to establish and fund the Government's new National Training Authority. This Authority will have responsibility for establishing a new national system of vocational education and training. The Authority is designed to report to the council of Ministers concerned with vocational education and training—that is, the council comprising the Commonwealth and State Ministers in this policy area. The Authority will advise the council on a strategy plan for the development of vocational education.

PARA.TAB: It will also have responsibility for determining whether the plans for the development of vocational education for each State fit in with the national plan. If they do, the State will be eligible to receive growth funding from the Commonwealth. If they do not, growth funding will be denied to the State.

The establishment of the Authority is supported, I understand, by all of the States and has some support in industry. The Opposition will not oppose this legislation. However, honourable members should not think that the mere establishment of this Authority will by itself, or without a great deal of effort, produce a satisfactory national system of vocational education and training. There is a huge task to be performed. A great deal of uncertainty and many unanswered questions remain as to how this Authority will operate. Very real dangers and risks exist in the charter and the framework which is being provided for this Authority.

The size of the task facing this new Authority is all the greater because of the quite dramatic failure of the Government in its almost 10 years in office to pursue policies which will lead to the development of a vocational education and training system of international standard. Indeed, I will be moving on behalf of the Opposition an amendment to the second reading motion condemning the Government for this failure and for the bureaucratic and centralist approach which it has taken to training through its so-called national training agenda.

The development of a national framework for vocational education and training is essential. Employment opportunities and international competitiveness are dependent on a work force with skill levels of international standard. Professor Michael Porter of Harvard in his seminal book on the competitive advantage of nations states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is little doubt from our research that education and training are decisive in national competitive advantage.

However, it is crucial if this country is to have a national framework for vocational education and training that it should be a framework of the appropriate kind. I had occasion to speak in an earlier debate today about the way in which the Government has totally neglected the central issue of schooling—that is, the quality of learning that young Australians are achieving. In that debate I pointed out how the Government has been distracted from this main mission to raise the levels and standards of learning of young Australians onto other agendas by its preoccupation with numbers and by the concerns of its friends in the teaching unions for nationally uniform awards and their willingness to approve only changes and reforms which do not threaten in any way their position within the education or industrial system.

PARA.TAB: Regrettably, the same story has been repeated with equally damaging results in relation to vocational education and training. Here again the Government has dropped the ball very badly, while chasing an agenda which has much more to do with the industrial relations objectives of the ACTU and its desire to inflate as far as possible the influence of the trade union movement in industry than with ensuring that young Australians have access to employment related vocational education of an international standard.

I suppose there are a number of milestones which mark the progress—or perhaps one should say regress—towards what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) now admits is Australia's `training emergency'; a phrase used by the Prime Minister in announcing the Government's intention to establish this authority. These milestones stand out quite clearly and I thought it might be of value to the House if I were to remind honourable members of some of the steps along the way which have brought Australia to this training emergency.

The first matter that I think all honourable members will be aware of is the decision of the Government to destroy the colleges of advanced education as institutions focused on high quality, advanced vocational education. When this Government came to office in 1983 Australia had an outstanding system of colleges of advanced education—a system established as a result of the initiatives of earlier coalition governments and a system in which there were strong institutions, other than universities, focused on the issue of vocational education.

Of course, when the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) was Minister for Employment, Education and Training, under the influence of college unions and in a sustained attack on the so-called elitism of the universities, he decided that all the colleges of advanced education should become universities. In doing so, Australia lost a very large number of institutions which had established strong regional links and had developed courses which were appropriate to the vocational needs of students in the region and tied in particularly with local industry. These institutions were told that from now on they were to become universities and assume the university model. The results of this have been quite tragic in a number of regions of this country. The Government started out with a very strong foundation in the area of vocational education and it threw it away.

What did the Government have to say about TAFE? I am sure honourable members will recall that TAFE had been the recipient of a very significant series of policy initiatives from the previous coalition Government which realised that there was a need to build up technical and further education. The Fraser Government invested very heavily in this sector of education and training in the latter part of its term.

When Labor came to office in 1983, it had a TAFE system which had made significant advances, was flexing its muscles and offering a wide variety of courses to students—a system that was growing. What happened under this Government? The system effectively ground to a halt. There was not a role for TAFE in the vision that the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training had. He was too interested in the universities and in pulling them down and teaching them a thing or two to worry about what was happening with technical and further education. As a result, the demand for university places was pumped up. TAFE was neglected and there was a declining interest in TAFE among precisely those young people who would have benefited from undertaking TAFE courses.

Members of this chamber will be appalled to know that in the last two years the number of teenagers in TAFE has fallen by some 33,000—a drop of 12 per cent—at a time when this Government says it is committed to building up technical and further education as an alternative to university education for young Australians. After 10 years of Labor, TAFE, sadly neglected by this Government, has lost its appeal to young Australians.

Another milestone along the way to the training emergency was the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs in 1984 which led to the establishment of the Australian traineeship system. The traineeship system was an attempt—and one must admit this—to provide an alternative entry point, apart from apprenticeships, for young people into industries and occupations where formal training and entry level training had been non-existent. A target of 75,000 traineeships a year was nominated by the Government. In the last two years, the number of young people undertaking traineeships dropped to 9,000. So much for the national target of 75,000.

The fact is that the Australian traineeship scheme, a scheme relying on employer subsidies, simply did not work. Of course this is a grave embarrassment to the Government. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) treats us regularly in Question Time to an update on the number of young people undertaking traineeships on a monthly basis because he is very concerned by the fact that this scheme is widely perceived in the country to have failed. He wants to show that there remains some interest. But despite the increase in numbers, the fact remains that there has never been any approach to the target of 75,000 a year for this scheme under the Government. It was an initiative which simply did not get off the ground.

It is also worth noting that over the last two years of the recession apprenticeship intakes fell by 35 per cent. So a government which is promoting the concept of the clever country has to face up to the sad and very regrettable fact that the number of places in vocational education and training for teenage Australians fell by some 36,000 over the last two years.

Along the way the ACTU got interested in training. The report Australia reconstructed, based on a mission to Sweden, outlined how the training area could be a whole new territory for the centralised industrial relations system to invade—how training could be a magnificent opportunity to help promote further the power of union officials on whom the Government has become so dependent. In 1988 and 1989, the Industrial Relations Commission at last made the link in the national wage case that the ACTU had been waiting for and it formulated the structural efficiency principle which linked wage increases to evidence of training or other workplace reform.

The National Training Board was established with the specific task of approving standards for industry training agreements as part of the award restructuring process. The National Training Board is specifically a part of this agenda. As is well known, however, this process also has been exceedingly slow to achieve very much. I do not say that nothing has been achieved, but what has been achieved falls a thousand miles short of what is required to boost productivity in this country to the levels that we need to become internationally competitive. That is the ultimate and the real test.

The report which Ivan Deveson brought down on training costs noted—the report was commissioned by the Government—how little had been achieved through the award restructuring process and how Australia was `back of the pack' internationally in its training effort. Mr Deveson also warned that training must not be allowed to become enmeshed in the industrial relations system, which is precisely where the Government and its mates on the ACTU want it. What they want is to develop a rigid and bureaucratic system in which qualifications will be linked into award structures and linked to payments and promotions. They want the training system to be an extension of the system of industry unions and industry-wide awards, administered nationally by central bureaucratic agencies.

If this agenda were to succeed in becoming, as indeed it aims to be, the national training agenda, the effect would be quite disastrous for Australian industry. This system will reinforce the rigidities of the present industrial relations arrangements and be a further incubus on the back of Australian enterprise.

Then we had the Finn report. The Finn report talked about something that the Government was most uneasy to have talked about, and that was the very serious deficiencies which young Australians are exhibiting in their employment related competencies. Quite simply, the Finn report concluded that there is overwhelming evidence that very large numbers of young Australians are emerging from the schooling system with literacy and numeracy standards which simply do not fit them for employment in internationally competitive industries and many find themselves unable to get jobs at all.

Finally, we had the Carmichael report, which proposed a system for making sure that the training standards identified by the National Training Board and the industry training advisory boards under it are locked into a system of certifications and come to control and dominate the courses at TAFE and among private providers.

The Australian National Training Authority, provided for in the Bill, is to be the vehicle for implementing the Carmichael agenda, once it is established, and to service the industry training advisory boards. Presumably this agenda will be reflected in the national strategic plan for TAFE, which will be developed by the Authority and will become an important element in whether or not a State's TAFE profile is approved for growth funding. Is that profile in conformity with this industrial relations training agenda?

I say `presumably' because that is doubtless the Government's intention. Whether it will be the intention of those who are appointed to the Australian National Training Authority will be another matter. They can, if they wish, exercise a degree of independence in their judgments. If they do so, I have no doubt that they will be running into some difficulties because there is a mighty juggernaut behind this national training agenda and it will not easily be deflected. I have no doubt that this agenda poses a major challenge to those who have accepted in the public interest positions with the National Training Authority.

The Opposition supports the concept of a national system of certification for training. However, we have serious concerns over a system of certification which is to be based exclusively on industry standards. Where industry standards which are appropriate to all enterprises within an industry can be developed, that is a good thing. But the driving force of national prosperity is not the industry, but the enterprise. The ACTU may want its members organised on an industry basis, but the key thing is the productivity of the enterprise. It is vital that the enterprises of this country are not locked into training frameworks which force them to pay for training they do not need, into training frameworks which discourage innovation in training at the enterprise level.

The Government has so far failed totally to face up to the need to ensure that training arrangements are suitable for a system based on enterprise bargaining and with a strong enterprise focus. We hear the rhetoric, but we do not see the reality. There is also a risk that industry defined competency standards may come to inhibit the development of high quality training because they require providers to jump through a set of prescribed hoops which may not be appropriate to the needs of particular trainees or particular enterprises.

There are tremendous pressures, within the training bureaucracy which is being established, for uniformity. Uniformity means bureaucracy and uniformity means mediocrity. There are very real risks that this National Training Authority will have forced on it an agenda which is not the training agenda which this country needs if it is going to move towards international competitiveness.

There is a huge public investment in the committees and boards which make up the current bureaucracy. Some $15m is spent on the industry training advisory bodies, but what have been the productivity gains of this expenditure? Ultimately, of course, that is the test. If we are going to spend millions and millions of dollars on this agenda, the public is entitled to know what contribution it is making to the productivity of Australian industry. No country has implemented such an integrated and bureaucratic system of training as is proposed through the Carmichael report.

We have seen this year, of course, on the part of the Government a prolonged period of confusion. There has been a great deal of sound and fury with the Prime Minister in the threatening mode typical of the New South Wales Right, indicating that the Commonwealth might walk in and take over the State TAFE systems or set up its own. In its desperate search for an initiative before the election to show that, in the Prime Minister's blatant admission, it is doing something, anything in the training area, it has finally come up with the proposal embodied in this Bill. The Australian National Training Authority is the compromise.

But the key questions are these: will the Authority be an effective vehicle for encouraging the development of a national training market responsive to the needs of industry, or will it become a new source of rigidities and bureaucracy in the training area? Will it contribute to the development of a national training system which will be flexible enough to have an effective enterprise focus, or will it persist with the Government's approach of compulsory industry based standards which may or may not be appropriate to the needs of the enterprise? There are also significant issues of accountability around this body. It operates between the Federal and State levels, not at either level, and is reporting to an institution which is not itself an accountable institution to any parliament in this country.

I want to register the Opposition's concerns over a number of aspects of this legislation. There are some obvious absurdities. The States are required to pay to this Authority their own purpose funds for TAFE and then they are guaranteed by this Bill that they will receive these funds back again. So, the Authority is to act simply as a post box. There is to be a costly process of administration involved and nothing is to be achieved. The only explanation for this that one can come up with is that there is a hidden agenda here, that there is the desire for the Commonwealth at a future time to make it clear that these funds are no longer the State's funds, that they are the Commonwealth's funds, and that they will be directed according to Commonwealth policy.

There is another unsatisfactory feature of this legislation—its dual system for hiring staff. It may hire staff independently under agreements or it may hire staff under the Public Service Act. That is a strange provision within the legislation. It was intended, presumably, to cover the fact that employees from the present Department of Employment, Education and Training may well flood across to the new Authority, but the provisions in the Bill go beyond that.

The Bill also provides for the development of State training profiles. Each State is to give to the Authority a profile of its training plans and if the Authority likes these plans, it will provide the State with growth moneys. This system of profiles has failed completely at the university level. It is not an effective system for planning the university system and it is most unlikely to be an effective system for planning the development of the technical and further education colleges in this country. Indeed, it is a system which has a real danger in it on the one hand that it will lock the TAFE systems into a uniform framework when what we need to see is developments in the direction of greater flexibility.

There are some very interesting developments taking place in Victoria at the present time under the new coalition Government. The coalition is prepared to give the TAFE colleges the right to hire their own staff. It gives the colleges a good deal of autonomy and it provides for the colleges to be responsive in terms of their own policies to the training needs of industry in their area. It would be a tragedy if this Authority were to deprive these colleges of their independence at the very moment when the coalition in Victoria is very sensibly moving to give them greater flexibility.

Our whole strategy is a very different one from the Government. The Government is still clinging to the separation of training from jobs. It is still relying on subsidies for employers to get them to take on trainees. It is still relying on centrally controlled labour market programs and it is establishing an Authority which may effectively seek to centralise control over TAFE. Its whole approach is centralist, and the fundamental reason for this is the ACTU's agenda. We do need a national framework, but that framework should concentrate on providing for national certification, ensuring that this is flexible, so that training with an enterprise focus and excellence in programs for both public and private sector providers is encouraged.

The coalition aims for decentralisation, not merely in relation to TAFE and not merely in relation to the encouragement of private providers; but also through the policy of community-based employment and training programs for the unemployed through local employment boards. There is a world of difference. The two programs are poles apart. This Authority is going to have a huge responsibility before it to act independently to ensure that we do get a national training market developed, and this is a great challenge for those who have been appointed to it. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not opposing the passage of this Bill, the House condemns the Government for:
(1)its failure over nine years to ensure the satisfactory development of vocational education and training in Australia and for creating a training emergency; and

(2)the excessively bureaucratic and centralist character of many aspects of the Government's national training agenda and for the confusion, complexity and uncertainty created by its current proposals".
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment. I rise in this cognate debate on the Australian National Training Authority Bill and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill particularly because the establishment of the Australian National Training Authority is going to be in Brisbane. This signifies, in my view, a turning point in the perception of Queensland held by the rest of Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you are not too far from Queensland. We call you an honorary Queenslander.

PARA.TAB: In years gone by, we in Queensland have had our share of being called the poor cousins, the banana benders and many other names that would be unprintable in Hansard. We have taken all this on the chin because our Queensland philosophy told us that there is no wheel big enough that it does not eventually turn. The wheel has turned in that regard.

The establishment of ANTA in Brisbane is a recognition by all States and Territories in Australia that Queensland's future is looking bright. No longer will head offices be located exclusively in Sydney and Melbourne. Over the next decade we will see many more national operations, both in the public and private sector, moving their headquarters to sunny Queensland. Honourable members will notice that I am not so foolish as to say that all these headquarters will be based in Brisbane, because to Brisbanites, those who come from Sydney and Melbourne are Mexicans; to those who live in Rockhampton, Brisbanites are Mexicans; to those in Townsville, Rockhamptonites are Mexicans; and to those in Cairns, we are all Mexicans who live on the wrong side of the border. In Queensland, parochialism is alive and well.

I am truly pleased that ANTA has been established in Brisbane, but I am even more pleased with the fact that ANTA has been established at all. For too long vocational education, like Queensland, has been the poor cousin. For too long we have let the gap between industry and our education system grow. For too long each State has been running its own show in this area with no national coordination.

With the establishment of the National Training Authority, we have seen a refreshing coming together of the Commonwealth, States and Territories in a mature way to establish a national body that is not attached to any Commonwealth department, as has often been the case in the past. ANTA began out of something called `new federalism' but has now fallen into that refreshing framework called commonsense; something which in this game is often hard to achieve.

The heads of government made an historic agreement in July 1992 leading to the establishment of the National Training Authority as part of a national vocational education and training system. This legislation sets in place the framework under which ANTA will operate. ANTA will be established by Commonwealth legislation as an independent statutory authority responsible to a ministerial council.

The Commonwealth and all States and Territories will channel their funding for training through ANTA, creating a unique national system which will provide assured funding requirements, a consistent national approach to training, close involvement of industry and a high quality network of training providers. There will be more opportunities for young people and higher quality training for industry. It is this training which will forge Australia into the twenty-first century in helping to rebuild our manufacturing industries, extend our service industries and create the needed expertise in developing export networks throughout the Asia-Pacific region.

The legislation provides for a chairperson, a deputy chairperson and three other members of ANTA to be appointed by the Governor-General for terms of up to three years. Appointment of members will be on the nomination of the ministerial council. In fact, the ministerial council appointed the inaugural board of ANTA earlier this month. Its job is to oversee the future development of vocational education and training to take Australia successfully into the next century.

The Chairman of ANTA is Mr Brian Finn, Chief Executive Officer of IBM who was appointed earlier this year, while the Deputy Chairperson is filled by Ms Anne Rein, Executive Director of Tourism Training Australia. The other three board members are Dr Michael Deeley, former Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of ICI Australia; Mr Stuart Hornery, Chairman of Lend Lease Corporation; and Mr Bill Mansfield, Assistant Secretary of the ACTU with special responsibility for education and training. I know that Mr Mansfield, and I know that he will do a very good job on the board, as will, I am sure, all the other appointees. ANTA epitomises the new face of training, the new level of commitment to a more highly skilled work force by industry, educators and governments.

All sections of industry over past years have come to similar conclusions in regard to gaining long term competitive advantages in the ever-competitive marketplace, particularly the international marketplace. We have already acknowledged that we have had to become a clever country, but this is another example of how the words are being put into action by this Government, contrary to everything said by the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). It is hard to be clever unless one has had the appropriate training, and it is the job of ANTA to define and implement that training. The establishment and running costs of ANTA will be funded by the Commonwealth. ANTA's budget will be determined when its structure and size has been settled upon by the ministerial council prior to mid-1993.

The Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill 1992 will provide funds for expenditure on technical and further vocational education and training in respect of the 1993-95 triennium. Part 2 of the Bill amends the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1989 to make provision for these funds. Part 3 of the Bill provides for funds for vocational education and training to be paid to the Australian National Training Authority in respect of 1994 and 1995, commencing on a day to be fixed by proclamation. The Bill provides for a total of $552.187m to be made available in 1993; a total of $630.795m to be made available in 1994; a total of $709.825m to be made available in 1995; and an additional $5.028m to be made available for recurrent purposes in 1992, bringing the total 1992 recurrent program to $261.317m.

When the current Federal Government came to office in 1983, it reached a view that Australia was at risk of losing its competitive edge in the international marketplace. As has been said many times in this place by honourable members on the Government side, Australia was too heavily reliant on its natural resources. We dug things up or grew things, shook our heads in wonderment at what to do next, shipped everything overseas to smart countries, then bought our own produce back when it had been made into something useful.

I often wonder, as those opposite gravely shake their heads at balance of trade figures, what Australia would have been like if Labor had never come to power in 1983. We would not be talking about a recession at this point; we would be talking about something like the black hole of Calcutta. At no time during these years did the Opposition give any indication that it was willing to bite the bullet, willing to let Australia take its chances with the big players in the international market. Given a chance, conservative governments will always revert to the past rather than look to the future. The Kennett Government in Victoria is a good example of how to take a bad situation and make it worse. A lot was said about that at Question Time today.

Luckily, the Australian National Training Authority looks as though it has a little more security of tenure than a working person's right to a decent standard of living in Victoria. All State Premiers and Territory leaders are behind ANTA. Under a Keating Government we can guarantee that ANTA will never be starved of funds but, unfortunately, one could not make the same guarantee if those opposite were ever to gain power.

We see the importance of training for a smarter work force in a rapidly changing technological world. That is why we have numerous Government training programs in operation; programs the Opposition openly scoffs at and threatens to cut if it wins government. How is this attitude going to make us value add? How is this attitude going to help us meet the challenge of the twenty-first century?

Even though there has been a rapid rise in school retention rates and in higher education during the reign of the Hawke and Keating governments, TAFE, unfortunately, has not shared this growth. This is reflected in the stark comparison between the number of young people with university degrees, which rose by 43 per cent between 1983 and 1991, and the number of young people with trade qualifications, which fell by 11 per cent during that time. A community attitude embedded during the reign of successive conservative governments has seen TAFE, apprenticeships and traineeships as something one did if one was not too bright or did not cut the mustard at the private school, or did simply because mum and dad did not have the shillings or dollars to rub together to support one in long term education.

The perception was that someone who did a trade was poor, either intellectually or financially. Not many kids from well-to-do families during my time went into a trade. If anything it was seen as a social stigma for the upwardly mobile. This attitude not only labelled those who went into trades as poor, but it also made this country so much the poorer for letting our industrial heart, our labour force, degenerate.

With the advent of ANTA we are signalling to the world that these days are over. We are saying to the future adults of Australia that those who choose to work in a trade are just as important of those who do law or become doctors. Some would argue that they are even more important and, given some of the charges that some tradesmen make, I would vouch for that. The establishment of ANTA is the beginning of an attitudinal change; a cultural change that will reap great benefits for Australia during future decades.

The old thinking has to go, and it is going. Going to TAFE no longer means coming home with dirt under the fingernails or with grease on the overalls. TAFE these days is as much about the services sector as it is about manufacturing. The largest single field of TAFE enrolment, by a substantial margin, is business administration and economics—no intellectually poor there, I would suggest. Under Labor TAFE has come of age. It is no longer the poor cousin of the academic elite.

With the establishment of ANTA we have created a truly national vocational education and training system with agreed objectives and priorities, assured funding arrangements and a network of providers delivering high quality, nationally recognised programs at the State and local level. That ANTA has been established in Queensland makes me proud, but that ANTA has been established at all fills me with hope for this country—hope that our young people will gain the skills necessary to propel us into the ever-competitive marketplaces of the year 2000. I commend the Bills to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to join in the debate on the Australian National Training Authority Bill 1992 and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill. The new authority known as ANTA arose out of the One Nation statement. The attempt of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to divert the national agenda and attention to training away from the real needs in our tertiary, secondary and primary education system was rather clumsy and heavy-handed. It attempted to force the States to agree that, for some recompense by the Commonwealth, some additional funding to go into the national training agenda, the State training authorities would give up their control over their individual TAFE colleges.

PARA.TAB: The States propped, TAFE propped, and the State training authorities propped and said, `No, thank you very much'. So the Prime Minister tried it another way, as he was trying to win the hearts and minds of the Australian people. He said, `What we'll do is give extra growth funding to those States which agree to our agenda'. The States propped at that, too. They did not really want DEET to take over control of the training system as it has taken control of the universities. A compromise came about in order to be able to fulfil the Prime Minister's promise of an additional $750m over the course of this decade to be pumped into vocational education and training. The compromise is there purely and simply because the States wish to retain control over their own training agendas. Thank goodness for that.

ANTA is a creature of compromise. I am not yet sure in my own mind whether ANTA will fulfil the high objectives that we all hold for it or become simply a vehicle for Laurie Carmichael's agenda of Australia reconstructed. I do have hope that it will work, because the States have such a heavy involvement in the Training Authority through the ministerial council. Unfortunately, the voting system is loaded in favour of the Commonwealth, with two deliberative votes and one casting vote.

The Commonwealth has control, and that is why the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) is so delighted that ANTA will be located in Queensland. I have no rancour against Queensland whatsoever—I think it is a terrific State—but the agenda of the vocational training system has truly been set by the Victorians. I give credit for the fact that it was set under a Labor Government. It was set by a group of individuals led by Ivan Deveson and consolidated with Terry Moran as Director of the State Training Authority.

What they have done in Victoria is create a series of more or less independent State TAFE colleges which operate, largely, on their own agenda, working together in each location with their industry towards trying to achieve vocational training objectives that will satisfy the needs of the marketplace at that location, satisfy industry's objectives for training in that area, and help improve the profile of training and the quality of output, as well as the number of students who are served by the system.

Victoria is light years in front. As soon as Haddon Storey implements in Victoria the final aspect of devolution—that is, devolution of the industrial relations function—we will have in that State a series of more or less independent State TAFE colleges operating just like our independent universities have operated for decades, able to deliver off their own bats very high quality vocational and technical training courses which should be attractive to both the young and the mature student populations.

It is clear that all sides of politics agree that we have neglected the training agenda in this nation, and we have done so to our peril. I believe I have said before that the country in which I was born got it all wrong. It listened to the Chairman of IBM in the United States years ago, who said of the secondary school system, `If you will take young people and give them a good general education and teach them how to think and how to learn, we in industry will take those outputs and give them the specific training they need in order to satisfy our requirements in industry, business and commerce'. It flunked.

That country has created a gigantic system of tertiary education which today means that a person damn near needs a diploma to get a job to pump gas or clean the streets. It has been highly unsuccessful. University graduates today are a dime a dozen and they number highly amongst the ranks of the unemployed. Australia needs a different agenda. I think everybody agrees with that. One of the things that we have not accomplished yet, which I am concerned ANTA will not accomplish, is to give status to the system. As the honourable member for Bowman rightly pointed out—and I give him credit for that—young people decades ago saw that vocational training was a second-class training, leading to second-class jobs.

For that selfsame reason, in Victoria at the beginning of the 1980s we closed down our over 100 vocational secondary colleges. These were vocational high schools that took young people and gave them, in addition to a broad and general academic education, specific vocational training in either highly technical subjects or crafts and trades. We produce carpenters, boilermakers, metalworkers and auto mechanics. The list goes on and on—from hairdressers to chefs and people in the hospitality industry. Unfortunately, over time—and I think driven by the teacher unions as an agenda—the public saw that as being second class, so we ultimately rejected it. In doing so, we implanted in the minds of our young people that training is somehow not as good as education, and that education is obtained from a university and training is obtained from TAFE.

We have to change that impression, because some of our TAFE colleges today, particularly those that are able to drive themselves on their own agendas towards excellence with minimal control under the State authorities, are really showing the way. They have courses now which are overloaded. They keep rejecting students by the tens and sometimes the hundreds. That is because they are seen in the community as providing an excellent product. We should encourage that.

The place where it needs to start is out in the community. One way to encourage vocational education and training and technical training is to introduce a system in our senior secondary schools—in years 11 and 12 of high school—of giving those students who are not headed towards academia, who are not headed towards the universities, who are not destined to study English literature or Russian history, or to be doctors, scientists or lawyers, the opportunity to have a leg up into their real life's vocation where they can earn a good living and have a good life.

If we can establish in our high schools—without going back to a system which failed, with vocational training being viewed as second-class education—these kinds of courses which lead to these new modern TAFE colleges running their own agendas, we will serve our young people better. The people in the country that I came from have served their young people poorly in terms of industry's needs and building a modern economy.

I am delighted that Brian Finn will be the Chairman of ANTA, because I have a great deal of respect for him. His report was a major event in the history of vocational training in Australia. That report is what leads us to this agenda today, although it was preceded by a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, the Deveson report, and other reports. I am not as confident about the Carmichael report. Whilst there are many things about the Carmichael report that read well—that is, about industry and the training authorities working together in cooperation to build the national agenda—I have some concerns that we will revert to bureaucracy and prescription.

DEBATE.TITLE: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted, I was talking about prescription. I would like to finish my remarks in that vein. Prescription concerns me. Without question we do need some kind of system to give us some cohesiveness and some relatability between States. There are people who would have us go back to the days when the Commonwealth was a minor player, and the States were the major players running the States rights issues. There are those who would have us get rid of the States, and there are those who would take a more moderate and in-between line. I suppose that I am one of the latter. The States are important to us in that they are certainly much closer to the people. They are closer to industry and they are closer to those who need the training than are the bureaucracies located in Canberra.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that DEET, through the profiling process, has not served the universities well. I am confident that the universities would say that, whilst they have learned to live with the profiling process, it is heavily bureaucratic and it does affect, unfortunately, the way that the universities direct their own resources. This may be because of something a bureaucrat says, or because of the bureaucratic system itself. The inherent nature of bureaucracies means that those who respond to those bureaucracies wind up being caught up inside the system. I am concerned that ANTA does not become caught up in the same sort of bureaucratic nonsense.

Part of the nonsense is inherent in one of the items that the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) talked about today. He said that it is up to ANTA to deliver that training. I hope he is wrong. I really do. ANTA will not deliver anything. It is up to our TAFE colleges, our independent providers of vocational training, industry bodies and individual workplaces to provide the training—not ANTA. It should be a coordinating body. It should be able to take the best ideas from the best States, the best TAFE colleges, and the best industry training groups, and help to encourage other States and other parts of the sector to work towards what has proved to work well, and to offer excellence. ANTA should not deliver that training. If ANTA does wind up delivering that training, the system will fail and the people will desert it in droves. We have lived for a long time in Australia with our craft based industrial relations and training system. Most people on both sides of politics recognise that, while that system served us well in times past, it is no longer suitable for the dying days of the twentieth century and the beginning of the twenty-first century.

We have to move beyond the tight, confining prescription of craft and allow people to have more flexible work lives and more flexible training to allow them to do the jobs that will be available in a more enlightened and—if I might say so—enjoyable manner. It is no good saying to a plumber, `All you are allowed to do is to change tap washers and sit on your backside for the rest of the day'. We have gone beyond that, and I applaud the Government for establishing ANTA. I will wait and see.

(2)(b), (3) and (4) The details sought by the honourable member are not kept centrally and I am not prepared to authorise the considerable time and resources necessary to assemble it. I would be willing to consider a request from the honourable member about information on any specific project.

(5) This information is not kept centrally by the Department and I am not prepared to authorise the considerable time and resources necessary to assemble it. I would be willing to consider a request from the honourable member about information on any specific project.

Current Departmental instructions require that the procurement of all goods and services of a value exceeding $20,000, that are not covered by a standing contract, will be advertised as a public tender. Criteria for choosing the successful applicant are based on value for money; the extent to which the proposal reveals a proper understanding of the matters involved and outlines a sound approach; experience and demonstrated capabilities of the organisation; the quality of the personnel nominated by the organisation; the proposed timescale; and the adequacy of arrangements for and the level of detail in reports and other documents to be produced.

(ii) and (iii) Research and interviewing skills were assessed by the committee from applicant's responses to hypothetical scenarios presented at interview. Script writing and other journalistic skills were assessed by both the written assessment completed by applicants prior to the panel interview and from responses to questions at interview.
(b) Yes.

(c) They were assessed by the senior journalist on the selection committee for script writing ability, journalistic news judgement, and ability to identify salient elements of news items and develop them into radio news stories and/or current affairs segments.

(d)(i) An administrative officer at SBS supervised the assessment; (ii) at the conclusion of the interview, the senior Journalist on the selection committee gave an assessment of the applicant's journalistic skills and ability.

(e)(i) Yes; (ii) applicants were asked to explain how they would develop current affairs segments and documentaries, and what sources they would draw upon in order to provide an accurate, balanced and complete assessment of events. Many questions were posed as hypothetical scenarios requiring the application of knowledge and skills to real situations. These ranged from significant events in the relevant community in Australia, in the homeland or elsewhere. This gave applicants the opportunity to demonstrate programming and journalistic abilities rather than merely to reiterate learned "facts".
(7) (a) Yes.

(b) No. The selection process which was negotiated with M.E.A.A. provided for a committee member who possessed an intricate knowledge of community demographics, issues and needs. SBS Radio obtained the cooperation of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs which provided officers to assess applicants' knowledge of the relevant language base community as well as their knowledge of government departments and the services that they provide.

There should be some explanation as to the reason for the committee not including a representative of the relevant community. It is a reality that in many communities there are different factions or groups. During the previous restructuring process, there was the perception that an applicant may feel that they were disadvantaged or advantaged by the inclusion of a particular community representative. The SBS believed that, in order for the selection process to retain its integrity, it was necessary to eliminate this perception.

(c) Yes. A level of proficiency in a certain language is implicit. It is not merely sufficient to possess linguistic skills alone. Successful applicants must also be able to demonstrate that they possess broadcasting and journalistic skills. Where an applicant meets the criteria for a Broadcaster or a Journalist but fails the language assessment, then that applicant cannot be recommended for any position with SBS Radio as a Broadcaster, a Journalist or a Broadcaster/Journalist.

(d) Yes. As programs on SBS Radio are determined in accordance with language spoken not country of origin. For example, there are no Lebanese programs but programs in the Arabic language. Similarly there are no "Chinese" programs but programs in Cantonese and Mandarin. Therefore, the French language program "homeland" includes all places where French is spoken and includes France, Mauritius, New Caledonia, etc.

Hypothetical scenarios, which were developed at the interview, required the applicants to draw on their knowledge of homeland issues. It also ensured that those applicants without journalistic "ability" could not bluff their way through the interview.
(e) No. The process was uniform. All applicants were questioned and assessed in the same manner.

(8) Yes. In order to conform with established standards, SBS has a clear obligation to conduct selection processes and appointment of staff in accordance with the provisions of the Public Service "Streamlining Act 1986". Under the guidelines relating to this Act there is no provision for appeal against the appointment of a successful applicant to the Public Service.

(9) (i) and (ii) In 1986 SBS Radio embarked on a restructuring process with the aim of employing professional Broadcasters and Journalists at SBS Radio 2EA and 3EA. In the following 18 months, 39 permanent Broadcasters and Journalists were successfully recruited for 16 language groups at 2EA.

This was a positive outcome. The recruitment process, however, was suspended in 1988 pending a reappraisal of the allocation of air-time. The motivation behind this was the need to make the schedules reflect the needs and expectations of the various linguistic based communities. The previous schedules were devised in 1979 to meet the information, entertainment and cultural requirements of Australians from non-English speaking backgrounds.

In the ensuing thirteen years there has been a significant change in the SBS Radio's client population—not only in its composition but also in the information needs of those communities. The new schedules, which were brought into operation in February, cater for over sixty linguistic based communities in Sydney, Newcastle, Wollongong, Melbourne and Geelong.
Following the release of the schedules in early 1992, and after extensive negotiations with relevant unions, SBS resumed the recruitment of professional Broadcaster/Journalists in April 1992.
(iii) It is not possible to assess the cost of the restructuring process in 1986-88 as all costs were contained within the divisional operating budget.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: Has the Government introduced measures to prevent or limit the number of bankruptcies resulting from the present recession; if so, how was the basis of support for businesses in difficulty calculated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Measures contained in the Bankruptcy Amendment Act 1991 are expected to reduce bankruptcy numbers. Mandatory income contributions for example, should discourage some from going bankrupt as an "easy way out" and encourage others to enter informal or formal (Part X of the Act) arrangements instead. Provision is also made for a simplified early discharge procedure which should assist in the early rehabilitation of bankrupts. A bankrupt will be able to apply for early discharge at any time 6 months after the time when he or she files a statement of affairs with the Registrar. To be eligible for early discharge the bankrupt must have no or insufficient divisible property to enable a dividend to be paid; not have disposed of property in a transaction that is void against the trustee; and earn an income which is unlikely to exceed the actual amount on which his or her contributions have been assessed.
Additionally, the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia has been increasingly committed to advising individuals in financial difficulty who may be contemplating bankruptcy.
Any "measures" relating to general economic conditions, or specific assistance for persons or businesses in financial difficulty, are not matters which fall within my portfolio.
